But if the price of getting coffee from this place is involuntarily wearing their coffee on my clothes for the rest of the day until I get home and can change, then yeah, I'm going to one of the hundreds of other good coffee places in San Francisco next time.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Cash only. This is a cozy little coffeehouse with good coffee and exceptionally chill staff. Also a great spot to strike up conversation if you choose. The chairs and tables are arranged in friendly way. I've never tried the food. But I did get a coffee to go, and didn't have any problems with the lid leaking. 

I'm a fan, since I think coffee shops have gotten way too corporate, and uncomfortable. They want you to get your coffee and leave. It's always refreshing to find one that feels like the way coffee shops used to be. A place for reading, thinking, visiting with people in the community.
author: Brian C.

description:
God I love coffee shops that stay true to themselves unlike that damned soulless starbucks.

So I've been dying to go to Blue Danube for a while. However, space is a commodity in the city so finding this place was quite difficult (I drove by this place twice without realizing it). But once I found this unassuming little hang out and stepped inside, I felt like I was home. It had everything I wanted in a coffee shop. Two desktops were located in the front. Comfy couches in one corner. The tables didn't really match (they look like they were taken out of some guys house). Jazz was playing too. Furthermore, it was good jazz and not that new, smooth kenny g stuff. Also, I love the fact that the menu was hand written on a blackboard instead of being ready-made like the dollar menu at some McDonalds because it makes me feel like they actually care about what they do. 

So I ordered the mexican hot chocolate (a chocolate bar melted into some milk with cinnamon, nutmeg and other stuff). It was one of the best hot chocolates I've ever ordered. While other coffee shops create a rather disgusting hot coco that becomes chalky towards the end, Blue Danube's version is quite smooth throughout. Instead of a clump of coco powder at the bottom of the cup, these guys have REAL SUGAR! 

The service was alright. They seemed friendly enough.

In short: Mexican Hot Chocolate is rather good, Love the vibe, Price may be a bit high, I will be back for sure and suggest I suggest that you stop by if you're in inner richmond and have time to kill or just want to relax.
author: John B.

description:
Cozy bordering on cramped ,good coffee interesting decor and a nice selection of sandwiches  pastries and snacks

-1 star for crampedness  and tv though the volume is off
author: W M.

description:
Waiting for your cell phone to ring with Burma Superstar on the other end?  Come over across the street and get a pitcher of sangria to share with your crew.  Sitting in this cafe bar is a refreshing alternative to standing in the sun (or the dark) on the curb with the rest of the crowd.    

When Burma Superstar finally calls, take your time going over there.  Chances are the patrons on your to-be table haven't even paid the tab yet.

There are two terminals, perhaps connected to the internet, available in this cafe.
author: Winnie L.

description:
Dating scale: special category.

When you know you've got something special: when a fellow agrees to walk several freezing blocks with you so that the caffeine monster can be tucked in with their usual evening beverage.  Around 9:00 pm on a Sunday night, to be exact.

Fabulous spot.  Located on the not so busy strip of Clement and after the cold blustery wind had whipped up my skirt a bit, popping into the warm coffee shot was a nice welcome.  I felt at home.  Immediately.  Interior is done up as an afterthought to the flourishes of possible Austrian influences.  Lots of antique gilding and scrolled frames.  Instead of a Rubenesque nude, one will find fluffy subjects of the yarn/furry variety, an ode to plush existentialism thinking.  Chairs and couches are strewn in the small lobby of this cute space, took a seat while my Breve Latte, extra hot, was being made.

"Breve Latte large," the barista called out.

Another patron at the counter, bundled up in a black pea coat, moved my hot drink over to me for easier accessibility.  "Thanks," I stated, showing my appreciation.  Nice people here too.  Another special category mark.

I took one sip prior to doctoring it up and have to say, I've had nothing so creamy and delightfully hot against my lips and palate.  It warmed me, even as I held it in my other hand on the walk back.

Great selection of brunch and lunch menu items, not to mention live music on Monday and Thursday evenings.  WiFi and people who sit here minding their own business.

Perfection.  And special.  My kind of place.
author: Miika M.

description:
Good food, nice ambiance, friendly staff. BUT they charge for wi-fi. There's a sign on the door that says there's a wi-fi hotspot. When I asked the staff if I need a password, they said no. No warning there would be a charge. I'd already ordered lunch, so I had to pay $3.95 for access while I ate because I needed to get back to work. I'll only be here for two hours! Lame. The sign should say what it'll cost, or the staff should have warned me. 

If you don't care about connecting, it's a nice little place.
author: K C.

description:
Best Coffee in the Richmond!

Whenever I'm in the area, I actually look forward to spending $2 for a large cup of coffee -- if I need it or not. Something about the house blend produces such a refreshing taste compared to all the franchises and other coffee shops and the best part is that I don't get the crash hours later. I speculate that it might not be coffee but sure as hell I don't care because it gets me through my day smoothy!
author: Albert L.

description:
I love this cafe. It's such a friendly little neighborhood spot and you can tell it is adored because there are always tons of people chatting or reading. 

The smoothies are delicious and I really like the avocado sandwich (I think that is what it is called) and the salad dressing on the side salad is great. 

I keep coming back for more and they consistently meet my high expectations...Although, truth be told, I like the coffee at Cinderella Bakery on Balboa better...
author: Brittany N.

description: Great sangria!
author: Clinton C.

description:
Cute, Cozy, Comfortable, Coffee... do I need anymore C's to describe this place?

Stopped by here for late night coffee with a couple of friends. Love that it is open late. I ordered a single shot Latte... the espresso wasn't as strong and flavorful as I was hoping it would be. The drip was pretty cool though, shaped like a candle hah. However, the ambiance and service was great, I'd be down to chill here again.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Good sangria and cozy spot to warm up to a book! If you arent a drinker then id get their latte! Its is foamy, creamy and strong. 

Btw- this place is CASH only.
author: Manu M.

description: Really awesome ambiance here! Cozy seating and very inviting. I ordered the Mocha Mint and it was delicious! It was rich and had bits of chocolate in it. Definitely recommend. Just a reminder: Cash Only
author: Jaclyn N.

description:
Good coffee (though wish they'd put in a warm mug to keep it warmer longer).

Decent service.

Food is cafe food (this is not a restaurant calling itself a cafe). With a few gems for breakfasts. (french toast) Baked goods are so-so. Anything prepared is a better bet.

The vibe is eclectic, with a blend of antique store bohemia with a san francisco twist.

You have to pay for wifi, but to me that's good. It cuts down on the freeloaders. Finding a seat would be much harder if the wifi was free. 

Comfy couches for hanging out with friends. Cafe's are for bringing people together afterall, only recently do people lose themselves in their laptops, iphones, and ipads.

Great music selection. Mix of not-so-overplayed 80s, willie nelson, recent alt rock, rodrigo y gabriella, 60's hippie music, etc.

Wine, beer, mimosas, great fresh smoothies!!

How could you go wrong? eh?

(well, it's cash only, so stop by an ATM before entering)
author: Boris C.

description:
Great place to grab a coffee, smoothie or light bite while waiting for a table at Burma Superstar, directly across the street. 

Good pour over coffee, try the Guatemala dark roast. Recommendation for the cafe: have more than just 2% milk and half-and-half available outside.

Nice smoothie and juice selection too.
author: Arvindh K.

description: Decent cold brew and an excellent almond croissant. Place is super cute and totally has a locals feel about it.
author: Karen G.

description:
PAID WIFI?! What is this, the 90's?

I want to make it very clear this is a protest vote. I love almost everything about this place- food is good, ambiance is nice, dude working the counter is cool, and having a journal for the customers is really awesome. 

But come on. WiFi costs what, fifty bucks a month? If you don't want people camping out you can have a "please do not sit at table without buying food" policy, but why punish folks who do pay and need to get work done? Seriously, this is kind of a deal breaker. There are a lot of cafes in Dreamland and I need to get work done while I eat. (There are even outlets and powerstrips all over the place!)

I'm turning my phone into a free mobile hotspot to write this, so at least for a little while customers here can have free internet and enjoy this lovely little cafe.
author: r. e. m.

description: Great coffee shop with lots of seating and also outdoor seating. Friendly staff. Order up front and have a seat.
author: Christine L.

description:
You know how you're suppose to read the fine print before signing an agreement?
I really should've read the reviews about Blue Danube a little more closely instead of looking at how many stars it got.

I mistakenly assumed this place served a good cup of coffee when what they're are better known for is their food and atmosphere.
Lesson learned.

I tried their mocha and was besides myself.
I like the initial chocolate taste but kept waiting for the espresso to eventually seep thorough and balance out the sweetness.
It didn't.

Instead of a mocha, I was drinking a watered downed hot coco: a diluted and marshmallow-less Swiss Miss serving of blah if you will.

I don't know if I'll go back.
But I will thank Blue Danube for reminding to read reviews more thoroughly before trying a new place out.
author: Dan B.

description:
The city asked me to work on Sunday, and work in the Richmond District. From an unknown yelper,that person told me to go to the Blue Danube Coffee-shop for the Mint Mocha. 

Normally I would start my work with coffee,but this rare occassion I drank the "minty"mocha. I bought it, and indeed it was beyond-outstanding. I might be wrong,but it is the only coffee-house that serves Mint Mocha. 

My co-worker ordered the Caffe Latte and I took a sip from her drink it was good as well. Both of us enjoyed each other's drink. We also splitted the Ham and Cheese Croissant, which was equally delicious and became the breakfast of Champion for us. The highlight of my day was the Mint Mocha.
author: Matt G.

description: Good coffee.  Good service.  Funky (in a good way) ambience.  Good local flavor.  Well worth the visit.
author: Gary A.

description:
Love this place!  

Their Mocha Mint is the best ever.  I don't normally like coffee flavored & related drinks but I needed something while I was waiting for a seat at the overrated Burma Superstar across the street.

They even have an interesting book collection where I discovered Snark Inc., a satirical fable on corporate America.

The coffee house is cute... it opens up to the street so while you're drinking your coffee, you feel like you're experiencing Inner Richmond as well.
author: Shannon L.

description: Love this place but it's TEMPORARILY CLOSED for renovations. Just wanted to leave an FYI because I tried to call in to order a sandwich and they weren't picking up. So I went in person only to find that they're closed.
author: Morgan M.

description:
Oh, I like this cafe. Nothing fancy, but it feels inviting especially when it's a nice day and you can enjoy your coffee and the weather.
I did not try their sandwiched, but I did have some good coffee and fresh juice. :)
author: Jasmina T.

description:
This place is has some real high points.
*varied menu (coffee, wine, beer, snack and more substantial food)
*Cafe Communal Journal
*Juice Bar!! (Beet, Carrot and Grapefruit mix is AMAZING!)

Just a few low points
*pretty small
*only 3 outdoor tables
*pay for wi-fi
author: Chelsey G.

description: Pretty awesome cafe! Cute little journals customers write in that you can read. Smoothie was delicious, as was the Mocha Mint Late. Bagels were okay, but I am from the East Coast, where bagels kick ass. Service was quick and friendly!
author: Hannah B.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy! I love that they serve their warm drinks in miniature mason jar mugs (with handles). Their chai is fantastic, and their cafe au lait was a hit among my friends. I dock them points for having weirdish seating options, but it's a cool place overall. I'd go back!

They sell single Oreos if you need a chocolate fix!
author: Monica D.

description:
Blue Danube reminds me of some of the eclectic, bordering-on-grungy, boho cafes I used to inhabit during college years. Mixed media artwork graces the walls along with chairs and tables that have seen better days. I had to smile as my mom sat at the table with the laminated pencil drawing of the naked couple making love and awkwardly pretended not to notice. 

I had a basic Americano ($1.80) which was okay. The beans are sourced from a local place in Oakland, but the packaging looks Italian. I forgot the name. I hate to say this, but I prefer Peet's coffee more.

Minus one star for being cash only. 

Like the fact that you can bring your mug out front and sit watching the people go by. Very Continental.
author: Tiffany K.

description: I had some semi-strong house coffee in this cafe that has a lot of visual distractions amongst its decor. It's a far departure from your typical SBUX or PEETs, which adds to its charm. Along with drinks, you can also order food as well. The prices seemed competitive too. 3.5 rounding up to 4.0.
author: Derek N.

description: Cute neighborhood coffee shop with tasty lattes. Kinda feels like you're hanging out at your friend's living room. I like it.
author: Mel G.

description:
I was waiting in a 2 hour line across the street at Burma Superstar and decided to venture across the street to grab something that would prevent me from being hypothermic. I ordered a Mexican hot chocolate and it was amazing. I've had a many hot chocolates (Mexican included) and everything else paled in comparison. Any other place I have been to since Blue Danube has just disappointed me. The space was warm and quaint. Seemed like a great place to hang out and have a conversation with someone.

UPDATE 1/27/2008: Went back here and actually hung out on a couch for a bit. It seems like a great place to hang out and do work. They have couches and books. The scene is lively and they have actual food as opposed to just coffee and drinks like that. I will definitely be coming back. Again, my mexican hot chocolate was killer.
author: Carlos A.

description:
So i hop onto the Alaska airlines on my way to San Francisco, wearing my Seattle superbowl  championship t-shirt on my way to tahoe. On the plane I met a girl who tells me of the best coffee shop in all of SF, in which she conveniently also worked out. I was scoffing the whole time thinking to myself that there is no "best" in SF especially if it was a coffee house! 

But since i had nothing better to do and had to burn some time before my friend got on madden. I decided to go. 

Here's me review:

The shop is packed the entire time i was there, which is great and puts you in the working atmosphere. I imagine its like when Russell Wilson goes to the film room and somehow everyone is there, including marshawn who has no idea how he ended up there.  

Other than that the menu/playbook is extensive! thats the best part! you want a Power I formation? check. 4wrs spread? check. wildcat offense? check. If you are a play calling fanatic, you would love this place. 

BB original LOB out
author: William S.

description: This place is the cutest! Stopped by to grab a chai latte, and fell in love with the decor. It's a pretty small cafe, and had to wait in line for awhile.. but it was worth it because the chai latte was just stellar! It was the perfect mix of sweet and spicy and I had to come back the next day to have it again!
author: Sarah S.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy! I had some time to kill before my acupuncturist opened at 10am so I headed kitty-corner across the street to grab a bite and some much-needed coffee.

I had the "Greek wrap" which was eggs, spinach, sundried tomatoes and a little pesto in a thin/crunchy and perfectly grilled hot wrap with a very cold and delicious side of fresh fruit (cantalope/honeydew melon & some grapes).

The Americano was just right and the wrap was  - oh.. so good. I was hungry and I couldn't finish it. For $10 - and yeah of course I tipped (people who don't do that at coffee bars are, in my opinion, flinty, mean people).

Great way to start the day. Bring cash - it's an all-cash spot.
author: Jennifer O.

description: The smoothies and coffees there are very good! Awesome spot in the inner richmond! The atmosphere in the shop is also very nice and comfortable for a cloudy or chill day.
author: Romain D.

description:
My favorite coffee shop in the Richmond. Chill atmosphere, nice baristas. A great spot to grab lunch with friends, talk over a cup of coffee, delve into that book you just bought at Green Apple, study.. oh and the Mexican Mocha is simply divine! Blue Danube always puts me in a better mood.
PS it's cash only
author: Robyn B.

description:
Very crowded, i guess this is why people like it..
I only tried the juice drink, it was half pink half foamy, wasn't a fan at all.

I guess I will need to try the coffee and update this review though.
author: Dalu Q.

description: The hipster smirk is alive and well at Blue Danube since their re-opening. The place was fairly empty on an evening at 20 minutes to closing, but that didn't prevent anyone from charging me $2.00 despite my other purchase for an hour of internet time which did not work. Still, this is a good place to meet up friends. Coffee was so-so.
author: Moonbird G.

description: I live in the hood and always walk past this place, not sure why it has taken me so long to stop in.  Had a café au lait on this visit, will be back for more. Will need to try some of their breakfast and lunch offerings.
author: Dilly M.

description:
It's only open until 10PM
They need to change yelp & door to reflect that. 
Cash only.
author: Carmie K.

description: This is my favorite cafe in SF! Though I cannot have claimed to have been to all of them, I still think Blue Danube would have my heart. It is eclectic, serves lattes in bowls, and delicious food. I always feel lucky to get one of the tables next to the windows!
author: Lindsey R.

description:
This is the 2nd time we came to this place to give it another chance. The first time we were here the baraista was not well trained & have the steamer for the milk make that loud annoying sound and the chai latte had no real flavor & my espresso was lacking the good taste.

The 2nd visit the baraista was different & the chai latte was better & also tried the pour over coffee instead which was way better than time I wanted coffee. The service was too slow & it wasn't busy when we came in. With these factors in play we won't be visiting again.
author: Rodney R.

description:
ROCK CHALK JAYHAWK!

the owner has a kansas tattoo (so do i) and is a diehard KU fan (as am i), the lattes are good, but it is cash only (buhhh). i wish it was a bit closer to me--i'd go there all the time! when i find myself on clement, this is where i pop in for a coffee.
author: Shannon C.

description:
What cafe nowadays don't provide free wi-fi??
Cash only 
Almost no outlets
Very hard to get a table 
Stale desserts 
Average iced tea and coffee

The cafe itself is pretty hipster and chill. 
The croissant, ham, and cheese was good 
I usually only come here to eat outdoors (or near the wide open window) on a nice day. 

But i would not study here, very inconvenient (no free wi-fi and hardly any outlets)
author: Lily S.

description:
Stumbled upon this spot on my way somewhere and it's totally rocking!! I loved the couch on the corner with a book section. Sooooo cozy. Had some snacks and coffee, yummy! Can't wait to come back :)
P.S.- internet not free.
author: Maya B.

description:
I love this place. I've worked/hung out/read here many times, and it's always pretty comfortable. Atmosphere is great, coffee is decent, sandwiches are delicious (though a little on the pricey side). Smoothies are also pretty good. 

Pro tip: read/write in the Blue Danube journals. They're great and go back many years.
author: Michael B.

description:
I LOVE this coffee shop, and everything I've ever gotten has been delicious. I was a religious Hulk smoothie drinker, but after deciding I needed to decrease my sugar intake (fruit juice has a ton), I tried the Purple Rain and it is AMAZING too. 

Their breakfast croissant sandwiches are to die for - flaky, crisp croissant, melty, gooey REAL cheese and fresh scrambled eggs. My mouth is watering thinking about it.

They also make a mean mocha, with the perfect balance of chocolate to espresso. I hate those places where a mocha just tastes like some "essence of chocolate powder" BS.

Oh, and it's cash only, but there's a Chase across the street - cha-ching!
author: Tammy L.

description:
I'm trying not to be too easily impressed with everything in SF (including the air. you guys need to stop taking clean air for granted), having been in Shanghai for the past year and some change.

I've walked over here for coffee and snacks every morning since arriving back in SF, and felt a little put off by the sincere, nice people at the counter. But not too nice. Just right nice. I hoped they wouldn't notice me fumbling with my oddly uniformly-sized bills (why are they all the same size?? It's so confusing..) and frantically trying to add 25's and 10's and wondering why the fuck my wallet has already become a cesspool of pennies in the span of 2 days in America. FUCK PENNIES. At least the coins make sense in China. I digress. what were we talking about?

The funky monkey. The smoothie. It's delicious and tastes like lots of desserts and creamy sweet dark things mushed up into a cold cup. Oh right, that's what smoothies are supposed to be.. sorry, been in China and all. 
The coffee is okay. Nothing revelational, but nice. Better than China's (have I mentioned I've been living in China?). 

I also had a bagel melt with avocado (OMG AVOCADOS. NO SUCH THING IN CHINA) and french toast (OMG FILLED WITH CREAM CHEESE AND DRENCHED IN SYRUP, NO SUCH THING IN CHINA EITHER).

It's also very hipster-y (NO SUCH THING IN CHINA- China wins this round). I walked in out of the sun blinking a bit and was met with the vision of a girl with sleeve tattoos and giant glasses talking on a rotary phone handset. That was hooked up to her cell phone. I thought I was dreaming. The situation has deteriorated, folks. When I left I'm sure the infestation was not this ridiculous, you guys have failed somehow. 

There's also lots of people with beards. Is that a thing now? Beards and weird cell phone attachments? I'm uncool.
author: Stef H.

description: Came here for a latte this morning, enticed by the 4-star rating and this close proximity of this place to USF. Lots of parking early in the AM and you don't have to pay the meter until 9am. The shop itself is cute and the latte was decent. However, they charge $2 if you want to use wi-fi. Seriously? Even McDonald's gives you free wi-fi. Also, when I handed the guy my credit card he said there is a $5 minimum and he was really strict about this. It's not posted anywhere so I didn't know beforehand. I've been to a few places that have a minimum for credit card use but they have always been nice about it and let it slide since I didn't know. It's too bad this place did not turn out to be 4-star material. I was hoping to have found my new morning coffee shop.
author: Megan P.

description:
would've given this place 4 stars, but our table number was 415.
I had the strawberry citrus drink and a bagel with cream cheese. I would put more ice in the drink, but it was really good! I like the mixing/matching for fruit drinks.
this place is really cute and cozy and they have outdoor seating for nice days. staff was really nice and they played cool music ;D
- Cash only!
author: Isabel L.

description:
Want to wait 10 minutes for service, only to pay for overpriced salads and sandwiches? Then this cafe is your spot.

Seriously though, $9 for a veggie avocado sandwich? $5 for juice?
author: Andy A.

description:
It was the picture of the french toast on Yelp that had me hooked to try this coffee house.  The place was packed when we got there around 12:30 on Sunday but because it's a quick bite place, seats opened up fairly quickly.  PARKING is a pain but I suggest circling the block and looking for parking on Clement...one is bound to open up.  

OK -- to the food!  I got the half sandwich/salad combo with Mexican hot chocolate and my bf got the french toast with a 12oz orange juice (also have 16oz).  The french toast DELIVERED...the best I've ever had.  The hot chocolate had a cinnamon-y/subtle spicy flavor that was OFF THE CHAAAIN.  My tuna sandwich had new, unique flavors I've never had in a tuna sandwich (it was orange-y in color!) and my mixed green salad was fresh and well-tossed (had onions, tomatoes, cucumbers and dark leafy greens)  We sat out in the sun and enjoyed a filling, yet light brunch.

They have a really wide selection of beverages and foods that I want to come back and try.  WHAT A TREASURE!  

Only thing that kind of caught me off guard was the CASH ONLY.  There's a WAMU across the street but it'll charge u $2 if you're not a WAMU (oh, sorry...I mean JP Morgan) customer.  It's ok, it was worth it for Blue Danube.
author: Kat C.

description: The coffee was alright.  I paid for 2 hours WIFI, but it was slow as a snail.  It took me a whole minute to check my email that was really frustrating.    I didn't even finish my coffee and went to Cumaica where they have free and fast WIFI.
author: Perry L.

description:
Pros: Cozy spot to grab coffee, share a snack, read, study. Love the vibe here. :)

Cons: Wi-Fi isn't free :(
author: Joanna M.

description: Love the interior design and ambiance here...the food and coffee was good too
author: Leo C.

description:
Crowded cozy little coffee shop with lots of food to offer.  I stopped by for a coffee and  fresh squeezed juice.  I love their coffee lids. It has a really cool slide cover to protect spills!  I appreciate small details like that.

This place seems like it gets crowded, I was in mid day on Monday and every seat was taken.  There was even a girl laying down and dozing off on the couch!
author: anita h.

description: Two stars for service.  The gentleman was not very accommodating when I requested an order change due to an allergy and refused to juice just ginger when I had already paid for it.  Thanks for the $6 Orange juice.
author: Laura K.

description: An absolutely adorable coffee/drink shop. Lots of seating. Great artwork on the walls. Great location (can stop here for a drink as you wait for your name to be called in nearby restaurants). I enjoyed a glass of wine here on a cold evening. Loved the ambience!
author: Siv L.

description: Great salads and sandwiches. They're coffee is fine. Chai is better than expected for a coffee shop. The space is pretty good for studying, esp. if the internet is distracting b/c they charge for wifi. I see people ordering their smoothies/juices a lot. They have a TV and are willing to show sports games while on (i.e. giants game, ku games)
author: Vicki T.

description: Love this place. Great coffee, great food, beer, wine, lovely atmosphere. You have to pay for wifi, but there are plenty of places where you can get free wifi, and this cafe always has more people socializing and reading. Also a fun spot to watch the World Cup semifinal :)
author: Jeff F.

description: I used to love this place however after exploring the city more there are definitely better coffee houses out there! Still, their coffee is good and the place is really cute inside. Also, they don't have unlimited free wifi!
author: Page F.

description:
Blue Danube is a self-conscious place. 
Or is that me?  Let's say it's not me.

Blue is reaching for something, trying... 
Blue wants you to think he's cool.
That makes me squirmy.  
Just be you, Blue.  
See my therapist, he's right down the street.
 
Blue charges for internet.  I refuse to pay.  I stare at the wall.
Blue wants more from me than I can give.

I arrived as a refugee from Cumaica, driven away by their strong but tasteless espresso drinks. 

Do you think they'll take me back?
I don't really want to go back.

An extra star because of their "don't ask, don't tell" policy for Those Whose Sole Need Is To Expel Urine.
author: Lame Lake Meese Z.

description:
My fab friend Fawn practically lives here, and she's the expert. You can stay all day or eat and run. Your choice. 

Their breakfast wraps and bagels with the eggses are awesome.

Their coffee is just fine.

They are comfy. They are friendly. They do not have their hipster heads up their hipster arses, which, at my cranky age, is just exasperating, so I like them especially.

Warning: Carry cash. That's all they take.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Spiced Hazelnut Chocolate!! :9

it was under their special's. i actually went in there to order coffee because i was feeling tired, but the name of that drink was just so tastey sounding... i had to get!! o_o and wow. it was amazing. rich chocolate taste. didn't taste watered down or too sweet. the hazelnut tasted amazing with it too :) mmmmm. it tasted high quality. definitely recommend :)

and i love the coffee house itself also. it's so cute and cozy! when you walk in there are two computers you can use for internet. you can swipe your credit card and  use their computers/internet. 

they had a couple chairs and tables and a cute little couch :) . table and chairs outside also. wasn't too busy or loud. it's a nice and quiet place to read or work on stuff. unlike starbucks where people to go sit and chat so it's a bit louder. 

also it's CASH ONLY. make sure you remember that.
gotta come back to try their coffee and see how they are :)
author: Sachiko K.

description: Nice cozy spot with good food, however their coffee is overpriced AND you have to pay for wifi
author: Yodit M.

description:
I think I am slowly becoming a coffee lover, usually I love sipping a hawt cup of Tea. I love brewing up some fresh tea, watching the leaves open up and let the smell permeate my nose. Lately I have been going to different coffee shops to get my study on, school has been consuming my life and I hate it. Sadly there isn't much i can do, I am going to graduate after this up and coming spring semester so i need to crack down and get my shit done! So lately I've noticed that i have been choosing coffee over tea and I am really not sure why...

I was here at Blue Danube last nite, but not to study. Just to relax, enjoy a Bright Eye(Ghirardelli chocolate and Expresso blended with ice) and chat with one of my good friends Jan S. One thing i noticed that i really loved was large window panes or more like window doors that open up and allow some natural air to flow through the cafe. The walls were covered with various different art work and the menu was packed with different food items, smoothies, coffee and alcoholic drinks. I've decided that i won't be coming here to study because this will be my spot to chill and chat with people. It has a relaxing environment which helped me unwind and mellow out. 

One thing i really wanted to try, sadly the kitchen was closed when we got there was the FRENCH TOAST...ive been drooling over the pictures that ive seen of it. I will be back for you French Toast!!!
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Absolutely dig the atmosphere here. There is quite a bit of seating, couches if you prefer that, and outdoor seats for nice sunny days like today!  I was able to snag my preferable corner seat and people watch while doing work.

Ordered a mexican hot chocolate ($3.85) and a cupcake ($2.50) - the hot chocolate was very good, though a little too big for my liking.  And the cupcake was sweet sweet sweet, will probably opt for something else next time.  As I looked around, their food kinda reminds me of Cafe Velo Rouge - same bright plates, side salads with sandwiches, full salads, everything that looks really fresh and good to eat.

My only complaint (as in other reviews) is the paid internet.  This place is so nice to relax and do work in, it's unfortunate that you have to pay $2 for 2 hours.  And it will cut you off at your two hour mark. ):  Bumped my rating down to 3 stars.  If it had free wifi with purchase, I would definitely come around here more often.
author: My An V.

description:
This coffee shop is cute and cozy, but my experience on a Saturday night left me understanding why some yelpers go off the rails when complaining about place, I'll try not to...

Ambiance, background music, and my cappuccino were wonderful :) Chai tea latte here is nice, not super sweet like Starbucks. If you're willing to cough up $2 you can log on their decent-speed wifi, which doesn't mean $2 worth of food, it means $2 for your wifi code.
author: Lana L.

description: Blue Danube, y'all been slippin as of late. Average coffee but common man, where is the customer service?  $2 for 2 hours of wifi?! We don't live in the dark ages anymore.  EVERY coffee shop except yours has free wifi.  After I finished my double latte, I asked for water and your barista put the water inside my cup without cleaning the it first! It's the little things that count BD!!
author: Alex G.

description: This place is way too cluttered and makes me feel like every inch of the place is covered with bric-a-brac! Espresso is "meh" and pastries are too. I wish there was a better cafe in this neighborhood.
author: Josie C.

description:
I've heard complaints about this place being too busy. More accurately, Blue Danube has a high turnover rate. If you want a table, you never need to wait longer than 5 minutes for one to turn up. Once you grab a table, you never feel pressured to leave. I think it's a good combo.

My favorite food item on the menu is the tuna sandwich. It has boiled eggs. My favorite food item used to be the berry pie. But then I ordered it too often and realized I was eating pie more than once a week, and that seemed wrong.

Great people-watching, especially if you like overhearing conversations of people waiting for their Burma Superstar table, couples on first dates and groups complaining about how long the wait is, etc. This is a favorite pastime of mine.

Internet is not free. 4 bucks for 24/hours last I was there. This might not be so great for you. But it was great for me, considering how much work I got down loitering at Blue Danube.
author: Zachary M.

description: This is quirky cozy little cafe that's great to curl up in a corner with a cappuccino in. I especially love the BLT panini. The pressed juices are great but at a slightly unfortunate room temperature. Very comfy cool atmosphere. Tip: check out the bookshelf of sketchbooks filled with documentations and doodles by patrons.
author: Cailey C.

description:
This place has some great items that keep me coming back:

-Breakfast Bagel - it has cheesy scrambled eggs, tomato slices, and several huge pieces of bacon. Great power breakfast.

-The Hulk green smoothie - one of the best green smoothies I've had. They got the blend of flavors just right - not too sweet, not too bitter.

Plus, the coffee here is solid. And the place has a bunch of those cute little touches that give a good coffee shop its charm, like their cookie jar full of Oreos at the front (25 cents each).

BUT:  - 1 star for charging for wifi! Since none of the other coffee shops in the area charge for it, it's just annoying that this place does.
author: Laura L.

description:
My daughter coffee place too go.
My wife and I tried it and liked the coffee house.
I like walking Clement St. and this is a great place to start or end the walk.
author: Ed N.

description: Great smoothies , coffee, and sandwiches
author: Niraj H.

description:
A very cute place. Since we knew we had a long wait for Burma Superstar, we crossed the street to enter this cute place. I'm sure it gets a lot of patrons because of Burma.

It's a coffee house that services alcohol (beer, sangria...) and food (breakfast, soups, sandwiches). They also have a small collection of books and 2 computers to read / use. I liked the eclectic feel the place exudes from its furniture and wide drink selection.

We got the Mexican hot chocolate, which is basically a bar of chocolate (prob not Mexican) melted in to the drink with cinnamon and nutmeg mixed in. It was yummy in my tummy.
author: Margaret R.

description:
Came here for coffee after eating dinner at B Star. I brought a dozen cupcakes for my friend's birthday. Sitting outside, drinking coffee, eating cupcakes and chatting it up with the table next to us, what a Saturday! 

The coffee here is ok, I got the Hazelnut Latte and it was good, not great. 

My friend got regular house coffee (black) and he asked for another cup. So I assume it was good (not too strong and not too light). 

The barista was really nice and got our drinks to us fast. If I was in the neighborhood and wanted coffee, I would come back here again... unless I get distracted with boba. HAHA
author: Erica T.

description:
I have been hitting this spot since the early 90s and I still enjoy it.  Good coffee goes a long way.  The rest varies over time but you can expect good food and a fun environment with a diverse clientele.  

It can sometimes take them forever to get your food out to you - I think they have been cycling through staff the last couple of years - but if you can chill out and enjoy a real coffee house that is not a corporate starbucks or petes, you might just dig it.  For a kick, read the shop's customer journals that go back years - drawing and musings from the over caffeinated customers show you that students both serious and not, neighborhood freaks and normal people have been mixing here for years.  

I like going their for coffee when Clement is closed for the Farmer's Market, grabbing a bagel and coffee and then talking to my neighbors.  

I would give them 5 stars but they never have cinnamon rolls.
author: Why N.

description: My aunt and I went here any morning for a latte, and I'm glad we did. The white chocolate was delicious though a tab bit expensive however about the same price at Starbucks so I was not surprised. It took up a little more time than I would've liked to get my drink but like I said the coffee was delicious and a pleasant wake up in the morning. I did not eat here but I certainly will be getting the French toast next time as it looked incredible!
author: Mandy E.

description: My chai tea latte with soy milk was delicious and their impressive and extensive menu almost brought me back for lunch.  Lots of options for the veggie or meat lover alike.
author: Emily J.

description:
Good:
Tasty coffee
Damn good smoothies - try 'The Hulk'
Decent pricing

Bad:
Male cashier has a nasty attitude

Comments:
It's very full on evenings and weekends, but you can usually still find a seat.
I like the background music they play.
author: Jesse M.

description: Overall cozy vibes and good coffee. Poor wifi reception :( ... also is $2/hr fyi. A little on the loud side with the folks that come here, wouldn't recommend working or reading at this spot. But would come back again to grab coffee.
author: Nisa C.

description:
I like the simplicity of Blue Danube. It's not trying to be something it's not.

I often come here to get some easy lunch and a cup of coffee. The food is good but the main reason for me to love this place are the tables outside in the afternoon sun. I can sit here for hours reading and going from lunch to a beer and some chips.

The staff is really nice and the prices are good.
author: Lisa A.

description: This is such a wonderful café! The atmosphere is welcoming and the people working the counter/baristas are nice and helpful. The drinks are delicious! Would definitely recommend the Bananarama smoothie. Definitely going to be back here the next time I'm in the area!
author: Jennie L.

description:
I like the vibe at this coffee shop...I get the feeling that I could just camp out here for hours on end.  Haven't tried any of their food, nor much of their menu at all really, but the coffees they serve look totally delicious.  Service was nice, and they have even have some beers available too (bottled, not on tap), but I just wish they stayed open later at night.

Tried their Mocha Mint, figuring that it was the closest thing to a seasonal brew that I was actually interested in.  Upon delivery, it was mmmmm mmmm good.   Imagine one of those chocolate Andes mints, but melted down, and a little thinner (could stand to be creamier for my taste buds).  I was admittedly skeptical as the order came out of my mouth, but I had all faith restored (and then some) after that first sip.  I know it was a short experience, but five stars are warranted when I think I might have found my new favorite coffee brew.
author: Mike L.

description:
I try to stop by here everytime in the Inner Richmond because their Americano is good. There are mixed drinks and beers too if you want to have them early in the day. 

It's a charming cafe in an easy to find location, on a sunny day, bright, big open out windows, a diverse crowd, sofas to lounge in, tables and chairs bunch up where it's practically communal...it's the best.

Their only TV was showing the Gold Cup Final, where the US soccer team losing to Mexico, grrrdmit, (with the workers hootin' and hollerin' for Mexico) ruined the atmosphere a bit, but not totally, as I was too chill.
author: Peter L.

description:
Chill. Cozy. Charming.

I've been coming here a lot lately to do writing, and I've always felt super comfortable and relaxed here, which makes for very productive writing sessions.

The staff here are super friendly (tip them, please!), and they offer a great variety of food (sandwiches, salads, breakfast items, pastries) and drinks (coffee, tea, smoothies, your standard cafe drinks).  I always get a pot of tea (only $2-3), and they serve it to you in a little teapot, complete with steeper and a cute little teacup.  Refills are $1.  

There are a variety of couches and artistically, colorfully decorated tables for you to sit at.  Each one is different.  Very cute.  

They play good music too - lots of stuff from the 90s, random reggae, and some recent stuff too.  The other night, towards the end of the night, they played the Final Countdown and some music from the Rocky movies, which got me totally pumped and into my writing session.

If you're looking to get some reading, writing, or studying done, this is a great place to do so.  It's easy to carve out your own little study bubble to be productive in, yet at the same time be charmed by the great ambiance outside your bubble - the music, the other people working, the quiet stories, the Christmas lights and decor.  

Only 4 stars for now because I haven't tried the food yet; I'll probably get around to that next time!  In the meantime, though, as a coffee shop, it works.  It definitely works.
author: Vivian C.

description:
A good stop if you want to sip a cup of coffee and/or down a glass of wine on a comfy couch, while enjoying a mute game of (insert sport here) in a mellow environment. The place is small.

The Good
- Nice variety of coffee
- Serves alcohol
- Good deli / pastry choices
- WiFi
- Sports on TV
- Clean restroom

The Bad
- Cash only
- Sometimes crowded tables
author: AandE D.

description: Very nice pour over coffee here. They spend the proper time for full extraction of the beans. My new go-to coffee shop in this part of town.
author: John H.

description:
nice cool cafe...but why do you charge for internet service?! that was the only downer for me.  
their coffee is okay, but they have alcohol and cool smoothies.
they have a big sandwich, salads, bfast menu too.  ive tried several of their sandwiches and they were yummy.

ill come more often and stay late if only they had free wifi. other than that, its a chill place to meet up with friends and just hang.
author: Linda T.

description: The Veggie sandwich was INCREDIBLE. Yummy bread, avocado, hummus and dressing. I didn't have to wait long for it either which was nice. The sole reason for the three stars is 1) the friendliness of the staff was nonexistent. Most of them seemed to not be in a good, high spirited mood. At the very least a hi, and a smile would be nice to see when speaking to someone and 2) there is NO free wifi. You have to pay 2$ for two hours and its not a strong connection FYI. When you yelp and search for free wifi, they come up but its not free... and it doesn't matter if you buy something ;)
author: Puneh A.

description:
SF like it used to be when I moved here in the early 90s. Can't say I have sampled much of their fare, but what I've had, I've liked. And it's all about the ambiance. Completely unpretentious, friendly, nice open windows to the street, comfy, lots of food and drink options.

Every time I go here I feel great.
author: Judith S.

description:
This review is for their house coffee!

I usually come here at night. The coffee here is on a pricier side, the small is quite small so should order a regular. 

The house coffee itself--wow, I like it. Usually coffee doesn't taste as good at night because coffee houses don't want to brew new batches. But at Blue Danube, the coffee smells good, and it's dark and rich even at night. 

The service was good. The barista was nice!
author: Mandy C.

description:
Big Fan, right here.  Even though it's a cafe, I won't be writing about that, I'm all about their sandwiches.  If you need an affordable lunch spot in the area, this is it. Don't think that they serve just ordinary, run of the mill sammy's.  No sir.  All of their sandwiches just have that one ingredient that set them apart from the norm.  Really great, and the salad served with it is just the right proportion.  I've tried both the turkey sandwich and the veggie.  The turkey is so SO good, I would go back again for it.  Next on my list is either their banana smoothie or any of their fresh juices.  The other day I saw that they were serving a cucumber, apple and mint juice, hi, i love you.  

Five stars for being a step above a normal cafe!
author: Casie M.

description:
I love Blue Danube, it's my neighbourhood coffee shop with great coffee, food, fresh juices and location. The only thing is the service is very slow, almost everytime. Not sure if the cashier was training today but he was slow... He seems distracted with all the coffee orders. I only order for a pick up. 

Suggestion: Have 1 person designate to take the order and ring it up, then have someone else make the drinks.

I'm giving it a 4 stars, still love this place.
author: Natalie F.

description:
Was it decent? Yeah. Was it worth the trip across the street to get cash from the ATM? Not really. Did my Mexican Hot Chocolate taste any better when I found out I had to pay for the Wi-Fi too? Not at all.

There was lots of (empty) comfy seating that looked appealing, and I liked the funky sign outside, but otherwise I don't see why this place stays in business, on this side of the first decade of the 2000s.
author: Omar Y.

description: I wanted to give a 3.5 because I enjoyed my California Wrap and the coffee was quite good. However, I took 1 star off for charging customers for wifi and limiting it to 2 hours, and 0.5 for being cash only. Other than that, I love the place.
author: Douglas M.

description:
Decent coffee, though my cousin recently got a latte that seemed like all milk and no coffee. 

Peruse the sketch book by the counter. Sometimes you'll see cool shit by a talented artist. Really.
author: Ken L.

description: Cutest cafe! I love their breakfast bagels
author: Erika P.

description:
First off, I'll say this place has an "interesting" decor, makes me think of a place for college students with alternative rock music playing in the background. Maybe it's because I first saw this place almost 20 years ago not long after my graduation.

Earlier this week, this was my stop for a cup of coffee after lunch to fight the afternoon food coma. Here, you order the coffee and they dispense it for you from a pot behind the counter. Pretty strong coffee. It's scary to think that many years have passed. :)

I saw on their menu board they serve certain mixed drinks like Bloody Mary (one of my favorites) for just over $5. It's definitely something for me to keep in mind.
author: H K.

description: I'm not a SF native. I'm in love. Not too many places in the SGV have coffee & alcohol & cafe eats & wifi &...yeah. You get the picture. They've got it all. So do your homework in the morning with excellent espresso, stay for a sandwich at lunch, then grab a beer in the afternoon before going to happy hour. Loved this place and this place alone almost made me move to SF, so yeah...it's good.
author: Amy R.

description:
The best atmosphere in Inner Clement and great products to boot.

I am a particular fan of the hot apple cider at night or a refreshing Italian soda on the few warmer days we have.

Always a favorite to go read, have a meeting, or just chill. Love love love it!
author: P L.

description:
This is a great place to meet a friend for a quick lunch or to linger over a cup of coffee and read a book (it's right near Green Apple Books if you're looking for something to read!).  

The decaf mochas aren't great, which is a make-or-break issue for me, since that's "my drink", and I've often had a hard time finding a place amongst the few cramped tables to sit.  But no place is perfect, right?

Overall, it's a nice, small coffeehouse, decorated in a visually interesting manner, and a great place to people-watch.  There aren't a lot of other cozy-feeling coffeehouses in San Francisco in my experience, so this is a nice alternative to a Starbucks or a Peets, and a great place to duck in and get out of the hustle-and-bustle of Clement Street!
author: Amy L.

description:
Love it!

College coffeehouses are dying.  Nobody wants the old couches or the mismatched furniture or the chalkboard handwritten menu anymore, but I do!  I like getting my coffee, mexican hot chocolate, latte served in an actual cup!  

It's a great place to sit and hang out with a friend from college and just catch up.  No rush.  No fuss.  No ventis.  Just coffee and nice people.

Love: Great selection of Mighty Leaf teas!
Not in love: Don't cave into the pretty cupcake... they're just okay.
author: Christine K.

description: My favorite coffee shop in the world.  Please come back soon, BD!
author: Jed X.

description: Get the Hot Apple Cider. They put a cinnamon stick in it. NICE!
author: Toome B.

description: Always good coffee and food options, and nice and quaint. But you want to charge me $2 for 2 hours of wi-fi AFTER I just spent $15 on food and drinks at 9pm on a Thursday night and you close at 10pm!?!?! Doesn't make sense business wise in this era in San Francisco.
author: Troy H.

description:
I've come here on several occasions while waiting for our table at Burma Superstar. Last night..with a group of 8, the wait was over two hours. I caved in and ordered quesadillas and a hummus plate to hold me over...maybe it was due to extreme hunger, but I thought the quesadilla rocked. 
I like the atmosphere of this little coffee house---coffee house that serves beer and wine that is..
I would give them an extra star for putting up with people regularly who behave in a obnoxious manner due to hunger pains waiting on their dinner.
author: Mimi T.

description: Blue Danube is a little refuge that's just a step away from the hustle and bustle of Clement. The coffee is decent but nothing special and the atmosphere is pleasant but crowded with narrow aisles.  I don't like the idea of paying for wifi at a coffee house though. It just doesn't seem right.
author: Mark S.

description:
Laidback atmosphere, large bay windows, big, comfy couches, stacks of papers and books, two computers to use for wi-fi, convenient location, decent prices and a chalkboard full of delicious sounding food items including many creative sandwiches. 
Minus a star because my chai soy latte was not very good...Had to come home and doctor it up in order to enjoy it. 

All in all, A-OK! I'll be sure to give them another shot soon, maybe with a sandwich and some drip coffee! Seems like a place where I could melt into the couch while reading a newspaper on a lazy day.
author: Leigh W.

description:
Cute coffee house. 

I shared the fig and prosciutto panini with my husband and the portion and taste made a good breakfast.

Coffee wasn't remarkable.
author: Sarang Y.

description:
Along a street of Asian shops and restaurants, this small coffee shop is definitely an unlikely find on Clement. This place is super comfy and cozy, filled with funky decor and art and awesome coffee-house music playing in the background.

I've had the Mocha Mint, Mexican Hot Chocolate, and the Bananarama smoothie. All deeeeelicious. (Mocha Mint is the same as "Peppermint Mocha" in case you're looking at the Specials and the Beverages Menu and are wondering. lmao)

Bananarama = bananas, cinnamon, honey, yogurt, soy. It's light on the banana, so the banana flavoring doesn't overwhelm the drink.

There's a power strip in the corner by the sofa and the windows, so feel free to plug in. But wifi is another ordeal..

I think my favorite thing about this coffee house is that it also serves 
alcohol. WHAT. Yes please and thank you. There's seating inside and outside, so you can take your drinks and people-watch outside, or you can sit inside and enjoy the ambiance.

I also enjoy the nice mellow coffee-house music. It's really a random collection. One time they even had Never Gonna Give You Up playing lool
author: Jonathan L.

description:
3.5

DRINK:
1.) Latte


SERVICE:
Normal. Workers are nice. Has wifi, buttttt it's NOT free. Pisses me off when I order a drink already and get settled in, only to find out the main reason I came to the cafe does not indeed give the free wifi. 


ATMOSPHERE:
Cute lil place. Mismatched, eclectic, eccentric feel of furniture / artwork. 1103
author: Angela L.

description:
Ever look into one of those books filled with patron-provided writing? Blue Danube has those. Once blank, they are readily available for your thoughts to fill their pages. And, man, diving into the psyches of coffeehouse minds is an experience in and of itself.

Y'all are crazy, serious.

I recently spent the whole day with a friend here, a testament to all that Blue Danube offers. With coffee, smoothies, a diverse food menu, and tasty alcoholic libations, it's not difficult to find your hours slipping away into pleasant conversation.

That said, there aren't many seats here and wireless costs an additional fee. That's pretty much a joke in this town, but then again I suppose it keeps the crowds at bay. Because, really, this is one of the coziest cafes in the city.

I drew a flower eating a moose.
author: Keane L.

description:
Always our go-to place when we're not craving anything particular, also a kickass neighborhood coffee shop. Really cozy and comfortable. You can sit on the couch and get lost in the many beautiful original paintings local artists have provided, catch up with out of town friends coming in for visit, or surf the web (they provide computers too) and just hang out. You can also sit outside when the weather permits...or even if it doesn't, they've got the tables under heaters.

The coffee drinks here are SO good! I don't know what it is; the Mochas (white ones especially) lattes, americanos...everything is sooo yummy! GET ONE. The food is slightly more than I would like to pay for what it is, but I understand keeping up with a competitive market and making SF rent. We usually get one breakfast plate (a GREAT brunch spot, not that I want to divulge this secret for all you folks overrating Eats and Q nearby.) The sandwiches have really yummy Ciabatta bread and the fresh salad always comes with a light, sweet and tangy vinaigrette. I've eyeballed the wraps, salads, smoothies (one tantalizingly  called 'funky monkey' including banana, peanut butter, and Ghirardelli chocolate) that I still need to try, but I can vouch for the French Toast. Incredible! Comes with cream cheese in the middle...'nuff said.

The only irk for me is that its cash only...but you can hit up the Chase atm across the street or make a quick hike to the BofA atm at 8th and Clement. Problem solved!

Always friendly folks here, always a nice and relaxing time.
author: nina B.

description:
Freshly squeezed OJ anyone?
Great way to start your morning along with a snug cozy atmosphere. Coffee is decent and there is a small selection of breakfast dishes. I like to come here when my car is being serviced at Toyota one block away.
author: Oren R.

description:
This was the first cup of coffee I had in SF, and my joy at finding a fresh, bold brew cannot be understated.  What's more, the ginger scone I had at  around 4 PM was as fresh and delicious as if it were 8 in the morning.  Unfortunately, the muffin my friend Steph and I shared a few days later was dry and unremarkable.  

The atmosphere is cozy and, does manage to evoke the Austro-Hungarian-Saxon feel that the name suggests, though I wouldn't quite call it Viennese.

Yet another wonderful Inner Richmond establishment!
author: Elaine M.

description: I got a iced almond latte and it was nice and strong enough. Atmosphere is nice, I like the wide open windows and the place was packed with laptop working people.
author: Karen T.

description:
Love this place!! The food is awesome! I alway think about the aioli sauce they use in one of the sandwiches. The drinks are really good too and they sell some of the best sangria I have ever had. Not sure if the staff is the same as the last I went but if they are they are freakin awesome & the owners are super nice!! I love that they have journals you can write in and that they have different local artist art on the walls. if anyone had a bad time i am in disbelief. and i enjoy their mexican hot chocolate more than current employers. also i literally go back EVERY time i am in the city and plan my time to do so. 

also you have to pay for the wi-fi but that's cool it's pretty well priced. they also have computers you can use too if you don't have a laptop.
author: Mimi L.

description: checked out this place based on the amazing Yelp reviews --I'm sure their drinks are top-notch but didn't get a chance to try them.  Small cafe w/ limited seating and wi-fi costs $2/hr --meh, not exactly what I was looking for.
author: Viv J.

description:
Give it a 3 because you have to pay for internet, $2 for 2 hrs, after which the connection automatically terminates. Don't mind paying $2, but for every 2 hrs is a bit of a pain. 
Other than that the atmosphere is calm, serene and the waitresses go out of their way to help! Decent crowd as well, comprising of students and adults. The music is soothing, and NOT LOUD (something Starbucks should learn from). Wide choice of food and drinks available.
author: Ethan H.

description: Cash only... but a cool spot to start your day!
author: Madhusudhan R.

description:
This place has amazing Mexican hot chocolate...really...amazing!

It's also the best place to wait "inside" for your table at Burma Super Star across the street.
author: Sofia H.

description:
After a sushi dinner, my friends took me here to get a cup of warm hot chocolate. I love the interior of this coffee place! Warm, inviting and a little quirky, there's even a comfy couch in the corner for readers and groups of friends. The Mexican hot chocolate I got was only mediocre (I could taste that it was from a mix). 

But the ambiance alone makes this place a four star venue for me. It's the quintessential SF coffee shop, definitely worth a stop if you're in the neighborhood or great for a relaxed first date.
author: Cindy C.

description:
4/5 write something

the drinks are great. i like the vibe, and it's busy, but never too full. kinda far tho, but burma is across the street so not too bad. nice place to unwind, meet up friends, have some hot chocolate instead of coffee--just cuz you can.

write in the journals. i think that is the true beauty. the space has a story, a presence.
author: Alvin D.

description:
As I walked into Blue Danube from this afternoon's cool over cast San Franciscan summer, the first word that came to my mind was "cozy."  That's exactly what this restaurant/cafe is.  With a rustic wooden interior, this place looks very much like a cafe you'd find in Vienna.  It reminded me very much of a miniature version of a Gasthaus in Wien called the Schloss "something" across the street from the Zentralfreidhoff (central cemetery) where Beethoven, Schubert, Brahms, and even the composer of the "Blue Danube Waltz", Johann Strauss Jr. are buried.

There are small tables, a wonderful couch and even a few seats with internet access for a nominal fee.  For dinner I had the Rosemary Focaccia Sandwich and a Blue Danube salad which is spinach, cranberries, slice apples and other interesting ingredients that blend well together.

The atmosphere is comfortable but the crowd seems a tad too eavesdroppy as if talking isn't the coolest thing to do.  That being said, it's still a comfortable world sheltered from the San Franciscan noise.

The Sangria was excellent, and for a healthy dessert capper, I enjoyed a very tasty smoothie called the "Bananarama" which is a mixture of yogurt, honey, cinamon, and bananas.  As it was made fresh, it was smoooooooooth and very good.  Most of the smoothies fit the overall musical vibe of the cafe's name by having musical references.  Not classical references like a Beethoven's 9th smoothie, but references to recent bands.  

Having a smoothie called a Banarama and given how cruelly cold it was in the city yesterday, having a drink named after the band who wrote "Cruel Summer" seems highly intuitive.
author: Tony U.

description:
I like it here...seating, food, great coffee drinks, etc.  And I like the Parisiene feel of the opening seats....

Go for the ambience, even if the price is a bit steep.  (Cash only policy.)

That's about it.
author: Fannie S.

description:
*** ONLY CASH PLACE.

Such a cute, cozy, comfortable, local coffee house. couches, awesome wall decor/paintings, a book shelf with some books to browse through- all make for a great ambiance.

Great variety of food menu, sandwiches, bagels and sweet snacks. Great Latte and chai!
Fresh juices are also available- different combos of pineapple, grapefruit, watermelon, carrots etc.!

They have a couple computers provided with internet access and the wisfi is available with $4 for a full day pass minimum. 

Love love love this coffee place :)
author: Vivacious M.

description: cup of coffee after brunch...cozy shop and liquid chalk board menu available...breakfast, salads, sandwiches, bagels and pastries....few patrons munching on early lunch...to the counter...small coffee order...cash only!..coffee with acidic note...potent blew wake-up...
author: Hen A.

description: Went here for breakfast while walking past, wanted to grab something small. There were not a lot of options for pastries and the cooked food was more than I was looking for. The muffin I chose was big and tasted pretty good, but they only had a choice between bran and carrot when I went. The coffee I had was decent.
author: Katie B.

description: I had the cappuccino and french toast and the french toast was amazing!! I would come here again just for that. The cappuccino was good. Sad there was no design.
author: Matt N.

description:
Cute cafe on Clement Street.  We love to sit outside when the sun is out - which is infrequently, unfortunately.

The staff is friendly and the coffee is strong.  That's all I really need in a cafe!
author: Carmel U.

description: This coffee tasted like dirty dish water!  After bragging about how great the SF coffee scene was to my uppity NYC-dwelling sister-in-law, this place made me look a fool!
author: Monica R.

description:
This is a very chill coffee place, it's very artsy inside so I liked that. 

I go here because I love their drink called depth charge. This is the only place that I know of that serves it. Depth charge is a cup of regular coffee with a shot of espresso. I love it. 

They also have a good variety of drinks, like all types of espresso/coffee drinks, juices and smoothies.In addition to their drinks they do serve food here and it's pretty good. 

I'd definitely recommend this place & the drink depth charge (:
author: Taylor C.

description:
A humble cafe on Clement with good service and quiet surrounding. I always come here for Mexican hot chocolate. They also have cupcakes from Sweet Things.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: Love love love this little coffee house. My fave is the French toast.  This place has charm and so much character. They have journals where you can write whatever you want in them or you can grab one and read what others have written.  They also display local artist's work.
author: Charmaine C.

description: I love this place. Great food and great environment. I just wish Wi-Fi was free. It's $2-$3 for two hours. I go other places just because I'm going to get free Wi-Fi somewhere else. But great food and smoothies.
author: Alyssa F.

description:
Great atmosphere, good for meeting up with friends and getting work done.

2 Things:

1) No free internet, unless you connect to the neighboring WiFi, but it's really slow!
2) They leave the large windows open all day, so it gets quite cold in the evenings.
author: Hannah J.

description:
Yes, I know one of the owners. However, I haven't seen her in over a decade and my curiosity was piqued. A coffeehouse off Clement should have some character, I figured. And this did. 

The neighborhood vibe was apparent when I sat down with my smoothie and people watched. You had high schoolers next to seniors, folks that knew my friend by name, and drop-ins our age looking to be satiated. The menu did not disappoint either. And I'm not just saying that because they had Blue Moon on tap *and* Guinness by the bottle, or even sangria available (which exceeded my expectations). 

Small plates to munch on (I sampled the seafood ceviche, you should too), casual brekkie fare, and a solid selection of lunch brought a smile to my face. Of course, all things coffee and (Mighty Leaf) tea were in the house as well. 

Open late, quirky/inviting chairs and couches, and an extensive menu. No hesitation to give it 5 stars.
author: Anne Marie P.

description: Blue Danube has been one of my favorites on Clement for a while, and they still have great food, but their service has been slipping the past few times I've been. People are still nice, but there have been a few issues, like overcharging (I overheard the cashier realize she charged me for 2 drinks instead of 1 but didn't acknowledge her mistake to me, or give me my money back) and changing prices without showing it on the menu. They're also now charging for internet , which I do understand - a lot of people stay all day and only order one thing. But for people like me who order throughout the day in exchange for using their space all day, it sucks. All of these are little things that aren't going to keep me from going to BD, but they just make me go elsewhere more often.
author: Cait E.

description:
Stopped by this place on the way back from the run for some much needed warming up.  

The parking on Clement was free because its Sunday but we were lucky to find a place right by the front.  

It's got a great front and they were just opening up.  I imagine that as it gets warmer later in the morning it must pack up with weekend newspaper readers, though we were pretty much the first ones there this morning.  

My partner in jogging got the mocha and I got the Mexican Hot Chocolate on the recommendation of the barista--it was pure chocolaty heaven.  Along with our bagels we were pretty much set.  
I wouldn't have minded staying longer but the BFF wanted to get back, otherwise I would probably still be there now.
author: Nikki K.

description: What! Pay for wifi are you insane? Why would I stay here and pay for wifi when there is another cafe down the street that offers free wifi. It would be nice for them to put up a sign, if you wAnt to connect to the Internet go to another cafe
author: Lawrence F.

description:
In my Green Apple review I joked that the one block radius around 6th and Clement is essentially the center of the universe, but I am actually beginning to believe it.  

No nexus would be complete without a great cafe, so here we have Blue Danube.  What better place to come and swoon over your latest finds at Green Apple while getting addled up on good coffee and eating delicious sandwiches and not-so-good pastries?

Last time I was at the Blue Danube I both began learning Chinese (learned the most that day-downhill since), AND made a list of all of the dreams that I had dreamt in the last month!

And WHO? said coffee is bad for you?

P.S. Minus one star for the computers. I hate cafes with computers bolted down to the tables. Not so keen on telecommuting cafes, either.
author: Joanna M.

description: It couldn't be farther from the elegance of a cafe along the Danube. A comfy spot if nothing else, used living room furniture and all. Coffee was lukewarm and so-so, the bagel was fair-to-midland, and WiFi wasn't free.
author: Michael G.

description:
A great little comfortable coffee shop on happening Clement Street (right across from Burma Superstar). What you might not know about his place is that in addition to coffee, tea and breakfast foods, they also serve beer and wine.

You can get a mimosa any time! My kinda spot. They have wines by the glass for around $6, and beers, too. Add a $6 brie plate to your white wine selection, and you've just upped the coffee house experience to a buzzed one with sophisticated flair. 

If you dislike going to bars alone, but often dig a solo after-work drink, this is not a bad option.
author: Brittney G.

description: Cute interior / decor. Their menu looked good but kitchen closes at 9pm so didn't get to try any. I'm basing this review mainly on: service, which was somewhat rude / poor. And the fact that you have to pay for wi-fi even if you buy something (maybe just not used to that nowadays). I've only tried the Mint Chocolate smoothie, which was all right, was lacking in mint flavor though. I wanted to like this place, but service just ruins it for me if it's rude (not just to me, it was to other customers after me as well).
author: Jennifer M.

description:
I really like this place. Extremely warm interior and a nice Chai Tea Latte made my experience here so pleasant. It was a nice stop on my walk through the Richmond. 

An attractive clientele (at least on the day I was there) gave me nice things to look at as my tastes were satisfied with my tea.
author: Rajiv S.

description:
Food and coffee are ok. Nothing special and a bit on the pricey side.

I am quite happy with the selection of tea ($2.25) served in a proper large cup and saucer. That's my usual order.

The thing that makes Blue Danube stand out is the atmosphere. It has that nice rustic feel that you get in a good European cafe. I like the outdoor seating and the fact that they open up the windows here when the weather is nice.

I like the mix of people. It's not just a bunch of social misfit hipsters or say the grouchy old men that you find at the Beanery at 9th and Irving. Obviously, women dig this place. Seems there are more of them than men. The nearby Green Apple bookstore is arguably the best in the City and that crowd appears to hang out here too. So, you actually have people that know how to hold a conversation and have something to say!

The slight price gouging keeps me from giving this place five stars but I can see that they have found the sweet spot where they are able to keep people coming so it's understandable.
author: John S.

description: Awesome place. Accomodated a 7 person contingent last minute. Gave us a great experience with excellent service. Food was delicious and I will definetly come back if I am in the Inner Richmond area. I'm sure upon my return, and additional great food, this place will be hittin the 5 star mark.
author: Jake H.

description:
Cozy place with a mini art gallery. 
I like to get coffee here once in a while
author: Alyssa K.

description:
Located in the Inner Richmond, this is a very small, mellow cafe...Staff is friendly.  Place is not the most impressive...but the kick-back feeling you get when you're there makes up for it.  Really good place to get some warm drinks on a cold SF night after filling up the belly on Clement Street.

My favorite drink there...the Mexican Hot Chocolate...easily the best hot chocolate I've EVER had (and I've had a lot)!
author: Justin L.

description:
Blue Danube was a featured SF review a couple weeks ago, and it caught my eye.  Even though it is clear across town from me, I hopped on Muni 2 to try this place this morning, and what a great breakfast I had this morning!  

I had the California wrap (lox, avocado, capers, eggs) and a small mocha for about $10.  I was ear-to-ear smiling eating at my window seat looking out to Clement Street - it was sooooo goooood.  The tortilla used for the wrap was thin enough to hold everything all together without overwhelming the fillings - the lox and capers were a perfect salty balance against the avocado and fluffy egg layer.  And the wrap was perfectly toasted.  Yum!  And the mocha rounded out my meal nicely.  

Service was very friendly and smiley - that is always appreciated!  5 stars, definitely!  I will be back.
author: Maile N.

description:
This was pretty much the regular breakfast stop for my roomate and I. Nice cozy atmosphere although it gets very busy during peak breakfast-ing hours in which you might have to stand around waiting for a table or sit outside in the cold. 

Not really the place to go to if you need to study, unless you come during a less crowded time. 

I usually ordered bagel with avacado, tomato and mustard...mmm delicious. The coffee is alright, my friend was appalled by it, seeing as how she used to work at peet's but I thought it was decent. Their smoothies are very good, and the banana one seems to be very popular.
Veggie sandwhiches are outstanding as well!
author: AL S.

description: Oh, you charge for wi-fi? Kbye.
author: Caroline J.

description: Nice little cafe, but gets fairly crowded.  I enjoyed the house coffee, nice and strong; and my wife got the cafe au lait which was also good. They have a fresh juice bar which I'm interested in trying the next time around.
author: Byron S.

description:
I've been here before for breakfast and coffee.  The coffee was alright but the greasy awesomeness of the breakfast bagel sandwiches is great.

Today, I only went there for earl grey tea.  It was freezing and raining today so it became a very popular hub for people to find some comfort.  I enjoyed myself immensely as I got myself acquainted with someone.  It was a nice enough environment to hang out and feel relaxed.

The ambiance by itself is worth the trip (minus the street parking) and the food is definitely worth trying.
author: Ashley I.

description:
Cute but busy coffee shop. 


It is right across the street from the Burma SuperStar restaurant.  It has some outdoor seating (two tables) and when the large windows open up, it makes for a airy cafe.  

The white mocha (small) $3.40 tasted just as good as the one from CHIT CHAT CAFE IN Pacifica.  

Small tables, one couch, and a dirty co-ed bathroom.  

A small narrow kitchen.  

They serve sandwiches and salads.

Negative star - Wifi is NOT free.
author: Jboogie L.

description: This is a super cute cafe with smoothies and juices, mimosas and microbrews, and decent coffee. I come to this cafe because it is only of the only places where I can study outside of the library. And they are open fairly late. My only COMPLAINT: What's with charging customers for internet use?? Who does that anymore? I just spent $8, why should I pay another $4 dollars for 1-day internet use? Free wifi is available everywhere. Come on, you guys.
author: Kira S.

description:
This is a great spot that reminds me of college cafes - comfy and artsy. There's no shame in ordering a coffee or two and sitting half the day working or reading. It's a great place to focus, relax, or sit with friends. The only downside is no free internet (so bring your cord and tether from your 3G phone!). 

Great escape into artsy/hipster cafe on an unassuming Clement street.
author: Jess G.

description: I come here for coffee when I am too lazy to walk the extra block to my usual coffee spot down the street. They serve Mr. Coffee coffee. Not bad, but not the best either. Service is good. Make sure you pay a visit to the atm across the street prior to entering to avoid waiting in a long line only to find out they are cash only. Enjoy your coffee while catching up on your fellow San Franciscans' love lives in their Blue Danube journal.
author: Sue L.

description:
No free wifi, but on a Sunday morning, that's just one more reason to rejoin the real world and enjoy the newspaper. And you'll enjoy it even more having some of their delicious eats. Whether you are rocking breakfast (steamed egg panini with a side of fruit), lunch (an incredible turkey, cranberry mustard, grilled onions on ciabbata sandwich with more fruit) or caffeine (great latte), it's all well worth a visit.

Grab a comfy chair, see what the Chronicle's got going on, and enjoy.
author: Jason B.

description: I take back what I said before. Been here a couple more times, and the service is pretty good for the most part. Drinks have never been bad either. I usually get things to go, but I think I can try to survive the old couches one of these days :)
author: Elaine H.

description:
No free wifi internet???

Finally! A coffeehaus that I don't endlessly procrastinate on the script by mindlessly browsing the  w.w.w.

YAY!!!

A good selection of eats and pastries, seems to attract a local crowd. MIght make this place my writing desk. I will put this in writing!
author: wayne s.

description: Good coffee. not overpriced. Bagel & Peanut butter tasted excellent. Cozy atmosphere, mixed crowd. Pleasant staff.
author: James P.

description: One of my favorite go-to spots on Clement street. Great coffee and food, and a nice atmosphere for reading and writing.
