author: Bridget B.

description:
I just love going to this place. One problem, everyone else loves it too, and sometimes it can get really hard to find a seat. Euro cafe feel.
It's totally cozy, and comfortable. 
Their menu is excellent.  The Blue Danube salad is yumm-o. The sesame dressing's the secret. As sandwiches go, Rosemary Chicken's my fave. It's served on focaccia and arugula, which gives it a bit of a bite, but it's the grilled onions that do it for me. If you're lucky, you can smell them cooking the onions....mymm mymm. 
I have yet to try their breakfast items, but I hear the greek yogurt is excellent. 
And if you ever feel like spilling your guts out, journals provided.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I happily stumbled across this coffee shop on Clement Street, far away from my regular domain of Mission coffee shops.

My friend noted that unlike Mission cafes, they actually have comfy couches you can sit on for hours to read, chat, or write in the Blue Danube journal (a public diary where patrons can share their innermost thoughts and musings.)

It's a real charming place with plenty of food, desserts, and drinks (coffee, smoothies, teas, and alcoholic) to choose from. Blue Danube is a comfy cafe where you can spend an entire day doing work or nothing at all.
author: Valerie L.

description:
OKay, so they may not have Blue Bottle Coffee...but they DO have French Toast with Fresh Berries, Almonds and CREAM CHEESE in the middle of each slice. Yeah, that's right...cream cheese. oh...and some powdered sugar on top...no biggie.

Hi, my name is Katy and I'm a fan of all things way fattening but delish. 
and the coffee is A-OK also. 

next time, i'm tasting the parfait. I saw a guy with it and I got minorly jealous of him.
author: Katy A.

description:
I've been lurking about the Inner Richmond frequently ever since I moved to San Francisco, and have never gone into this place for one reason or another. Usually being, I don't have any cash on me- but today, was a different story. After purchasing a cookie from the bakery down the block I decided it was a good time for a latte (any time is a good time for a latte though). 

So in I went, and I walked into a warm, cozy room filled with lots of seating options, filled with people and warm heat, and the aroma of delicious delicious soup and spices. This alone makes me want to stay here, forever. Mmm soup and spices. The latte was yum yum yum, with good quality espresso and the milk wasn't over steamed so yay!

Once a place makes Lauren all latte-happy, they never go bad in her book. 

And I'll be back!
author: Lauren S.

description: This place is one of my favorite coffee shops in the city. The rosemary chicken sandwich and mexican hot chocolate. pure amazingness
author: Jesse D.

description:
This is my first Yelp review and I chose to write it on Blue Danube because, after more than 4 years in SF, this is STILL my favorite spot to chill and grab a great sandwich. 

Pros: Great store design with lots of sunlight means these gorgeous sunny days aren't wasted just bc I want to be "indoors". Perfect for people watching with a steady flow of college students, causal neighbors, curious readers... and the occasional funky grandma/grandpa. 

BOMB food! I usually either get their Turkey Ciabatta or Rosemary Chicken Sandwich but I see that the Double Grilled Cheese Sandwich is also very popular. 

How's their coffee? Legit. 

Also love their random selection of music. There'll be days when I come in and it's trance playing. Other days it'll be Beatles, or hip hop, or Brittany, or Blue October. Pick of the draw but, with the rest of the perks of this place, the music is the last thing you'll notice. 

Cons: Eh, can't think of anything at the moment. That's why the 5 stars... as in "Woohoo! As good as it gets!"
author: Christy S.

description: The Blue Danube is the kind of coffee house that Joey & Chandler would hang out in with their 4 friends if, you know, they all lived in San Francisco.  Friendly staff (No Gunthers), excellent coffee, and that "lived-in-but-artsy" atmosphere that hugs you upon entry.  Though my coffee allegiances are hitched to the Blue Bottle express, knowing that The Blue Danube will "be there for me too" is always a comforting thought.
author: Michael D.

description:
kooky place with some kooky people. however, good coffee (not blue bottle though :() 
$5 min for credit card, but it is better than when they only took cash! 
Food is good, really recommend the mexican hot chocolate it warms your tummy on a cold SF day :)
author: Kevyn R.

description:
Really this should be 4.5 stars. I've only been for breakfast (too many times to count) or lunch (once or twice). Great atmosphere and friendly staff. Love their breakfasts - bagels with egg and bacon, or the most generous serving of granola and fruit. Also love their yoghurt and parfaits. Freshly squeezed juices and great drip coffee ticks all the right boxes for me.
A wonderful spot in an otherwise very Asian neighborhood :)
author: Izzy A.

description:
My boyfriend and i decided to go to Blue Danubue for some Hot chocolate. We came around 10pm and no one was there so we practically had the whole shop to ourselves. The shop feels very homey with a few couches and coffee tables around the store. They provide internet but for a fee. 

The Mexican hot chocolate was okay. I wish there was a little more chocolate because the milk and cinnamon was over powering the chocolate taste. The Mexican hot chocolate tasted like the regular coco packs you get from the store, just with a whole lot of cinnamon added for extra flavor.
author: Jessica T.

description: $8.50 for a bagel with lox with a three day old bagel?  Common... When I complained they made another bagel with an equally old bagel... Downtown prices with medicore food.  At least the place has nice ambiance.
author: josh d.

description:
Ah yes another coffeehouse for me to visit!  If coffee and coffeehouses were illegal, let me be an outlaw!  I suspect I'll be fitted with an IV that dispenses coffee through my system 24/7.

My friend and I crossed Clement Street to get to the Blue Danube.  We were looking for something to end the evening and to chit-chat for awhile.  So after dinner at Burma Superstar, to Blue Danube we go!  Plus it was the only coffeehouse that was close by and open.

Blue Danube was crowded (which is a good sign) and had this Bohemian flair.  The place is rather dark but also cozy.  Not really a big place: few tables, chairs, and a small kitchen.  Everything seems to be a close quarters as if people at one table can hear your conversation.

The coffee I had was the usual daily brew, which is pretty robust and flavorful.  I admit it's not enough to give a decent rating but as for the place itself, it was relaxing.  

Come for the ambience!
author: Vvn W.

description: Good coffee, friendly service, and an extensive menu in a cute space.
author: Rachel M.

description:
I work from home so spend a lot of time going to various coffee and tea shops to work.  I love the atmosphere here, even the "coziness" of people.  I'm one of those folks who is curious about people and life.  I don't mind striking up a conversation with someone sitting next to me or them doing the same with me.  The mix of people who come here are interesting to me - artsy, academic, business-minded, and simply people out and about.  I like the relaxed atmosphere.

What I was REALLY disappointed in is that I had read on yelp that they had wifi so long as you purchased something.  I got there to find out that it was $2 per 2-hours.  In this day in age, that seems so silly, even though I understand that limiting the ability to work for long hours means more customers.  I'd rather foster loyal customers who would return day after day.

Still, I'd return again since I end up in this area often

It would be 4 stars except for the wifi issue.
author: Melissa W.

description: I love this place but I really hope their stuff stop banning the coffee maker so loud. Sometime when I just tried to read a magazine, BANG! - just like someone punched your head... You then tried to go back to read... Another unpredictable length of time elapsed,BANG! It's so annoying ...
author: Din D.

description:
This place was a pleasant little discovery on a sunny San Francisco afternoon with Gracie poo.  Totally did not expect to find such a hip little cafe here amidst the Asian markets and tapioca drink peddlers, but we decided to stop in for some refreshments and there it was in all its hipster-ly glory.  They have these fresh made juices there and I got a pear peach ginger juice or something like that.  Really good.  Grace's grapefruit juice was not bad as well.  That's all we got so I can't really say much else about the food but the atmosphere is super relaxed and chill and there's a few comfy couches where I can just see myself lying on all day.  Too bad two hipster kids were there with the same exact idea.  I guess being hipster isn't all good.  

HIPSTER!
author: William S.

description: Great atmosphere, great coffee and great food options.  The perfect neighborhood stop for drinks and eats, owner and staff are welcoming and attentive...there is a reason they have been around for over a decade!
author: Collin W.

description: Talk about good coffee and some good snacks! I love this place! After going to Genki to get some good crepes, I love coming her for a nice white mocha. The atmosphere is really nice and inviting. Very "Friends" like :) Service is really fast and the coffee is always consistent. Try this place out. Plus there is plenty seating and Internet access.
author: Joseph G.

description: Adding one star for the super yummy smoothies! Do the Funky Monkey!
author: Queenie C.

description:
I had the Mint Mocha and it was Delicious! My gf also had a sandwich which came with a very very tasty salad, and I'm not a big salad person. We happened to come on the day the World Cup final was on so we sat in, enjoyed our coffee, and watched the last few moments of the game. The place was pretty packed with Spain fans! My friend lives just down the street and I will definitely come back here for coffee when I'm in the area again!

Aside from the coffee I appreciated the art hanging from local artist. i also appreciated that each table was unique in design, one apparently with a couple in a very intimate tango if you know what i mean...
author: Andrew I.

description:
When I first arrive to SF, I walked by the place and was like ehhhhh I'll go to starbucks for some coffee. 

But one morning I woke up I really wanted Coffee, and I didnt want to go all the way to Starbucks so I decided to come here since my friend lives around the corner, I ordered there House Coffee and it was very good, and the price for a large coffee was like 1.50 and they give you gum! 

Did'nt try anything else but if regular house coffee was good! I'm sure others are good there ;-)
author: Freddy S.

description:
This place is my second living room. I've been coming here a couple of times a week for the last 9 years. The coffee price has gone up a little in that time, but no worse than the rest of the city. There have been some other changes but the cafe has not lost its fundamental spirit. It's cozy and it's neighborly. It's a good place to wait for friends or meet with friends for a casual brunch.

I come here for the strong, dark roast house coffee, the greek yogurt with fruit, the large variety of tea, and the gluten-free sandwiches. 

I consider the fact that the wifi requires payment to be a quality of life enrichment to the rest of us patrons who don't want to walk into yet another cafe where instead of faces all you see are the backs of laptops. 

I'm keeping one star back because yes, the sandwiches are kind of overpriced, and the service is sometimes very slow.

Note to the owner if you're reading this: you need to do a better job advertising that you have gluten-free bread.
author: AK K.

description: I like the cozy and laid back ambiance and the coffee is good. I've come here before dinner at B Star and also after to have an espresso and split a delicious cupcake. They were playing long forgotten  90s rock music on one occasion (Are You Gonna Go My Way?- Lenny Kravitz & U2's Even Better Than the Real Thing, for example), which was an added bonus.
author: Corinne M.

description:
I live on a few blocks from here so it's one of my favorite places to hang out on a nice sunny SF day. I love sitting by the large open window with a book and some coffee and people watch. Their menu is pretty extensive, with reasonable prices, but most importantly...delicious! Sometimes I just stop by to grab one of their Hulk smoothies. Never would've thought spinach + fruits would be sooo amazing together! 

Other days I would just hang out there and browse through their public journals. Be sure to stop by and jot down some of your thoughts! I'll be reading! =)
author: Vivian D.

description:
Spent three hours explaining to my bff why I had to break up with this boy...

They let us sit there as I rant...tea was great and the pastries were decent...can't complain...love the coffee house vibee and located in my own backyard!
author: Julie H.

description: I went here on a Sunday, late morning, because I was craving a flavored latte so bad.  My friends and I were waiting for Burma superstar (across the street) to open for lunch, and I just had to get my coffee fix for the day.  The store was cozy and had a warm atmosphere.  The prices were decent.  It took them longer than the average time for the barista to make me a white chocolate mocha latte and I was the only person waiting in line, so that was the only downside.  However, the coffee (for the price) was worth the wait.  I couldn't get over how unique their lids for hot drinks were!  It had a red sliding cap to "lock in" the heat of the drink.  It's a good place to sit and read a newspaper or study if you're in the city.
author: Nancy D.

description: This place has the best grilled cheese sandwiches!  The tasty melted cheese is thick and even a bit chewy and the buttered bread is absolutely deslicous!  I like the blue danube a lot.  it has a laid back vibe and you can stay for five minutes or several hours.
author: Amy L.

description: I stopped by here early one Saturday morning and was thoroughly unimpressed.  their drip coffee was practically undrinkable, and over-priced to boot.  I decided to give them another shot and got a pastry a few weeks later, and it was bland and tough.  Be wary.
author: Andy J.

description:
Again, the Mexican Hot Chocolate proved to be worth it - even if it means getting stuck in the pouring rain for 25 minutes trying to hail a cab.

I will trek across the city any day to get me some of that yummy goodness!
author: Lauren C.

description:
Great little coffee house in the Richmond! Great ambiance, great coffee, yummy fresh squeezed juices!

My biggest pet peeve about this place is that the wifi isn't free. I have no problem continuing to make purchases for as long as I'm there bumming the wifi. However, the baristas are super friendly and the desserts are yummy so I will still come back.
author: Marissa P.

description: My go to coffee house to sit back and relax. My friend and I always come here to grab a cup of coffee and catch up. I could care less for their coffee (except for their mint mocha) since it isn't anything extraordinary. But I DO LOVE the atmosphere there. I love how the couches aren't dirty and grimy feeling and how the tables are well positioned so there's no awkward-ness between you and the person next to you, when you need to get in and out of your seat.
author: Jess s.

description: you've got to open again, blue danube. there is no place like you in the city - reasonably priced warm, eclectic, inviting ambiance, the BEST waffles anywhere (we drive down from petaluma so i can eat them!), and people actually sitting and talking with each other. who the heck cares if you charge $2 for WIFI. your wonderful cafe preserved a dying tradition of the authentic coffee house - a place to meet and share ideas and feel like a part of the community. please re-open. you are the heart of clement street, one of the last real neighborhoods in the city.
author: aunt b.

description:
Just got back from spending a couple hours at Blue Danube on a comfy couch reading a book and sipping a mocha. Such a pleasant afternoon! The coffee is very good and the atmosphere is funky, relaxing, and cozy (especially on a foggy day). It's a popular spot - comfortably crowded - but I've always been able to find a seat, surrounded by other people lunching quietly, working, or reading. Service is friendly and efficient. They have a pretty extensive food menu and a case full of baked goods to go with your coffee. 

Cash only. Wi-Fi is $4 for a 24 hour period.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Pretty good place for coffee and late night meet ups. Haven't tried the food just coffee.  The atmosphere is chill. However, tables are sticky. Not ideal for studying or sitting around too long.
author: Connie H.

description:
Since school started, I've spent a lot of time at The Blue Danube, studying. I think it actually makes a better cafe for socializing than for my purposes, but it's still my favorite place yet in the area. 

Generally, it gets crowded quickly, and for some reason it seems to fill up in waves. It's a pretty small place, so this means it can get a little stuffy fast. Because of this, they sometimes open the huge windows, which makes it have a nice, airy feel inside, until someone in the outdoor seating decides to light up. Suddenly, there's no non-smoking section.

The food here is always good. I've had smoothies, salads, bagels, and sandwiches and they were all fresh and delicious. Also, the people who work here are quite friendly, too, which I consider a big plus. Overall, it's a nice cafe. :)

P.S. It's CASH ONLY. Come prepared.
author: Kristine K.

description:
Everything about Blue Danube is wonderful (save for their minor lack of seating space and horrendous parking). 

With that said, it is still worthwhile to attempt getting a table to enjoy their simple, but very enjoyable menu. 

A few recommendations:

- French toast (it has cream cheese in the middle!)
- Funky Monkey smoothie
- Lattes
- Veggie Sandwich
author: claire s.

description:
I like this place, a lot.  Even though I work nearby I still don't eat here as often as I want to or remember to.  It's eclectic decor does nothing for me but I couldn't really care less about it.  The couches look dirty but I rarely hang out with my food anyways.

I love their sandwiches, all of them.  And I love their little side salads that come with the sandwich.  There's just enough food and sometimes I only eat half and push the other half onto my boss.  Their smoothies are also very good and creative.  My only gripe is the wait for food when they're busy.  They don't have enough people working back there but I guess they don't have much room to squeeze another individual anyways.

The outdoor seating is great on a sunny day too!
author: Rosalind S.

description: Great coffee house! Coffee was really good too - served in quirky mugs which somehow make the experience better. I had the avocado sandwich too which was quite yummy!
author: Rita S.

description:
I recently went  to Blue Danube Coffee House in the inner Richmond for a light breakfast.  I had a single espresso, a plain croissant and their granola.  The espresso had a nice foam on top and was surprisingly perfect to my taste which is not over bitter.  I've seen the mixed reviews on their coffee, but I certainly liked my espresso.

Their croissant was flaky and soft.  The granola was served in whole milk with fresh fruit on top.  The blueberries and blackberries were large and perfectly plump with the strawberries and sliced banana being sweet.   Ever notice that the smallest of things can make the difference in your day?  The granola made my morning.

I have decided to make this place a mainstay for a quick breakfast.  Tip:  for more table space, sit in the middle of the cafe.
author: Janet H.

description:
It's a great coffee place for locals. I've only been there for the tea, since their tea collection is extensive. If you sit and drink tea, they serve it to you in a personal tea pot with tea loose leaves (the best way to serve tea). It's a place to do some work, chill, or meet a friend or two. 

Great atmosphere and vibes. And it's near the Green Apple store, so after buying books from there, go to Blue Danube and catch up on some good ol' fashion reading.

One star off because they don't accept credit cards.

Please please accept credit card soon! I always have to make sure I have cash whenever I go in.
author: Carissa E.

description: My favorite coffee shop on Clement ... coffee is decent I love the fresh juice have and fresh smoothies ... they have huge salads and nice sandwiches ... comfy couches and nice seating ... perfect spot in my opinion ...
author: Anthony S.

description:
Mmmm......great coffee!!  After not enough sleep and a what felt like a very long morning of house hunting in sf, i needed a pick me up to recharge my batteries.  Blue Danube was a wonderful find.  Nice comfortable atmosphere, awesome music, and yummy coffee.  My cappuccino was perfect in its nice bowl-shaped mug that i love.  They also have yummy french toast.  I only had a small bite as i dont like to eat too much in the morning, but the lady obviously thought it was good because she scarfed down the whole thing in 2 minutes.  

I love relaxing in comfy coffee houses, whether with a nice book or just people watching or reading the paper.  And since my pushy mother is laying the heavy hand down on buying a house, once i get settled into my new place, im sure to frequent Blue Danube often.  Till then Blue Danube, your cool vibe will continue to entice me to stop in whenever im in the inner rich.
author: Juv C.

description: I need to take away a star, strictly because you leave smelling like food. Big. Pet. Peeve.
author: Gina G.

description:
What a cozy little coffee shop!

I haven't tried any of the food here, I just love coming here to people watch and drink loose leaf tea with my friends. I love that you get your own little tea pot with the loose leaf tea of your choice. The environment is always so calm and relaxed, you can't help but unwind once you take a seat here. Great place to meet a friend you haven't seen in a long time to catch up!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
A friend and I were looking for a coffee shop that was open until 10, and this one was the closest. I give them two thumbs UP for the best Mocha I've ever had. Seriously, their mocha beats Starbucks and even Peet's Coffee!!! :)

The downside however...
- The windows are open and the cigarette smoke enters the cafe
- They don't have free wifi (it's $4 for the entire day, which is not bad. However, if you come in at 9pm and you just need the wifi for a few minutes, it's really not worth it)
- They only take cash
- Small tables


Over all, the place is very welcoming and aesthetically pleasing. It's perfect to come, grab a bite or just to drink coffee. As for studying or working, probably not a good idea because the tables are pretty small.
author: Narina A.

description:
Love, love love this charming little cafe! 

It's small yes, with an amazing homey environment where you can sit and chat with people from all over the world. I think it's on a "must see" list for tourists somewhere and over the years I've had so many pleasant exchanges with people travelling through. 

I will say it's preferable to like people if you go here since it's close quarters. 

The food here is really really good..a full coffee and tea bar, soup and sandwiches, fresh juices, breakfst and great desserts. The cheesecake I had a few weeks ago was delicious, and the latte too. For a little place they offer a great deal of variety.

There are a couple of couches with side tables and coffee tables, about 10 tables and a few tables on the sidewalk for those rare warm Richmond days. 

This cafe has been in existence for at least 20 years so you know they are doing something right!
author: Sharon J.

description: Food was great, I had the French toast. Paid for the internet but it was incredibly slow so I got no work done. Ambiance was cozy and hipster, found an outlet for my laptop in the corner. Not too many outlets.
author: Sanaa K.

description: I've been going to Blue Danube since I was six and have loved it ever since. This is a wonderful little neighborhood cafe where you can grab your morning coffee, enjoy a sandwich for lunch, or have a beer on tap and sit outside in the sun on a weekend afternoon. The B.A.L.T. sandwich is one of my favorites.  Blue Danube is small and full of mismatched furniture and art, but somehow it works and has stayed in business all this time. Make sure to bring cash as this is one of the cash only places so familiar on Clement Street.
author: Rebecca D.

description: Am I the only one that thinks this place is overrated? No offense to the cute coffeemaker and worker, but Blue Danube needs a little work. First, it's super crowded and the seating is so awkward. Everyone is kind of too close to one another and there's barely any room to even look comfortable. Second, you have to pay for Wi-Fi? I mean come on... the coffee is already a bit too much to start off with. When asked about the Wi-Fi, one of the workers in the back rudely told me "You know you have to pay for it right...?" No, I didn't and that's why I asked? Personally, I didn't have such a great experience with my Iced Peppermint Mocha either. It was watered down - not enough coffee and too much syrup. This place won't be at the top of my mind when I am in dire need of an iced coffee, but I guess it works for a lot of others. Blue Danube just didn't cut it.
author: Linda T.

description: This place is cool! I feel like I got the real "San Francisco experience" here. The atmosphere of the interior of the cafe is pretty laid-back, its really cozy, and cute! I got the green tea, which is pretty boring, but it was good anyway!
author: Kirsten K.

description:
I could spend an entire day here,

sipping on a large mug of Mexican Hot Chocolate, 

catching up on all that reading [Green Apple is RIGHT THERE!] I never get done,

enjoying conversation with an old friend,

sneaking a glance in the mirror at some gal on her laptop surfing Facebook [this is what you look at while paying for wireless?],

watching the line at Burma Superstar grow across the street,

making funny faces at a baby,

smiling on the inside and out. 

I wish it wasn't all the way across town.

PS - Mimosas and pear cider, among other alcoholic beverages, are available. There's food, too.

PPS - STUDYING here should be great too.
author: Tinna H.

description: Any coffee shop that doesn't bat an eye when you order a side order of sandwich meat is worth 5 stars. Really, though, the Danube has been serving up comfy breakfast and elevated sandwiches for years and still keep up with the times and their customers' desires. Plus, art shows, painted tables, and couches! It couldn't get better if I were to eat a bagel sandwich in Stevie Nick's Paris apartment circa 1982.
author: Joan A.

description:
You might go to Blue Danube and be like, "Five stars? Really? megan w., are you high? (again?)" 

But yes. Five stars. And I'll tell you why. 

Blue Danube is the coffee shop that most independent coffee shops are trying to emulate. You all know the coffee shop I'm talking about; chalkboard menu, standard espresso drinks, dried-out pastries, mediocre food, salvage furniture and musty carpet, probably near a college campus. There are tons of these. And Blue Danube isn't, at first sight, terribly different. In fact, you may even peer in a few times and write it off as an impostor, before you actually patronize.

But you should go in. Blue Danube is full of sparkly details that really set it apart from the horde of shitty cafes. 

Firstly, they have beer and wine. Judge not lest ye be judged in return, okay? A beer and wine license makes any cafe better, and you know it. Also, they have sangria. Which makes pretty much everything better.

Secondly, they have a sizeable menu of decent foods, including tasty sandwiches and classy little amuse bouche plates of apples and brie. 

Thirdly, they sell individual Oreos. Out of a jar. So you're like, "Hmm. Mediocre madeleine, or trusty Oreo? Trusty Oreo. Definitely" (Which, yes, I realize will kill you at age 30, but they don't have Newman-O's and there's a limit to how picky even I can be. Yes, there is.)

Sangria, Oreos, and seating in an open window? Yes, please.
author: Megan W.

description:
It's got ambiance, it's got quirk, it's got erotic sketch art on the outside tables.
The espresso drinks are strong but not caustic (unless you order a depth charge), and they feature Mighty Leaf Teas (decent long leaf stuff).
Haven't gotten anything to eat here, but I've come to lounge on their outside benches a few times now, just CHILLIN', and have seen some tastily topped bagels being eaten by other patrons - cheese and avo slices? Mmm. 
*And cute guys studying thick law books hang here, or getting morning hangover bloody marys do add to the charm ;-)*
author: CINDY K.

description:
Recently on one of those grand 2 hour waits for Burma Superstar, we decided to trot into Blue Danube to have some drinks and snackies.  Starving and a little tipsy from our earlier drinks on empty stomachs, we stood indecisively in the doorway, peering in, wondering if we were too sauced or too yuppified to cross the threshold of this sweet, low-key joint.  A few of the guys working there smiled welcomingly and gestured us inside, kindly saying, "come in, come in."  And then, somebody said the magic word: sangria.  And then, I saw the other magic word: cupcakes.  (Oh, and the Oreos in the cookie jar are hilarious and fantastic).

Plied with a pitcher of sangria, some yummy appetizers of hummus and quesadillas, plus my cupcake, things were looking up.  I am a salt and chocolate girl, but for some reason, I like my cupcakes ivory and super-sweet, and my vanilla cupcake didn't disappoint...I practically licked the plate.  Sangria wasn't the best ever, but, really?  Sangria?  At a coffeehouse?  With cupcakes and nice people?  They could have served me antifreeze with orange slices and I still would have been happy.

All they need to do is throw in a jar of lychees and I'll never leave.
author: Tanya N.

description:
Q: Does Blue Danube really need another review? 
A: I don't care. I liked it so much that I'm writing one anyway.

My only complaint is that a place that feels this quaint should never be full. Sure, it's good for business & all, but I wish this place was my secret. They've definitely benefited from their proximity to Burma Superstar (it's right across the street, & there's always a line out front).

I just sort of happened upon the Blue Danube while I was out on my bike on Sunday. An out of town friend was in the city & had about an hour to kill, so we met up in the Richmond & stumbled upon this little gem. My Cafe Au Lait was gigantic & delicious, & kept me warm on the cold ride back to the Western Addition at dusk.

Not recommended for stunt men: The front windows open all the way up, so if you were planning on arranging a highly dramatic "tackling a perp through a plate glass window" scene, Blue Danube ain't the place for you.
author: Pete J.

description:
This was a nice comfy coffee spot. I had a wheat scone with orange which was fresh and very tasty. Along with the scone I had a cappuccino which was just the right temperature. 

There were also a lot of small conversation areas. Judging by the scone, I think it is safe to assume that  other items from the kitchen, would be really good and I look forward to trying more food here. 

My friend drank a cocoa and she seemed pleased with the large glass of hot chocolate that she had. ...and she is a (self proclaimed) cocoa expert. 

I would recommend this place to anybody what wants a nice quiet place to talk or read.
author: Eric G.

description:
This is the perfect place to go while waiting for your table at Burma Superstar to open up.  You're right across the street so you can run back and forth to see if your table is finally ready.  After their minimum 45 minute wait you get a lot of exercise.  If you get really desperate, you can even have a light lunch while you're waiting.  Surprisingly, there are a lot of food options in this tiny coffeehouse. 

Not to say that this place isn't good in and of itself.  Their Mexican hot chocolate was deliciously spicy with an adorable foam heart oozing over the edge of my mug.  Thick and creamy, it made me pleasantly warm and sleepy while I lounged on the sofa, to watch the crowd outside Burma Superstar ebb and flow.
author: Shelley H.

description:
I actually love this place coz it's cozy and not so noisy, in contrast to a larger place like Canvas Gallery.  I like the wide selection of good eats on top of the standard offerings of coffee drinks and smoothies.  They could use some scrumptious flourless chocolate cake (CG has this)---which goes great with a lot of their Mighty Leaf teas.  Their "depth charge" coffee is really good for late-night studying...the caffeine high totally kept me going till the next day.  (then again, I OD'd on the espresso/coffee, which is not adviseable if you're trying to get some sleep).
I also like this place because my first crush of 2006 works here, but homey's got a gf.  *sad face*

The Double Grilled Cheese and Roasted Veggie sandwiches are mouthwatering!  (though I haven't tried any of the 'white or brown' meats)
speaking of sleep.  I need to do that now instead of Yelping.
author: Grace M.

description:
It's more like 4.5 stars.  The coffee and food is up to par and the staff can be very welcoming, but the place can get pretty cramped.  It's not necessarily a bad thing--usually, a testament as to how good a place it is--but it can get annoying when all you want to do is find somewhere to take root.  The panel windows and outdoor seating make for good people watching, though.  

It's a mellow atmosphere, so chill out for awhile.  Sit outside.  Order a beer, wine, whatever it is your lil liver desires.  If you hang around long enough, chances are, you'll meet some real cool folks.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
I like their coffee and I'm pretty picky with my coffees.  

I like how you can wait here for your seats at Burma Superstar.

I also like the old gentleman who sat in the middle of the room and drew portraits of the people across from him.  

I also like how I can write by the window for hours, as I try to avoid the evil-eyeing from people who couldn't find seats because I was writing by the window for hours.
author: Andrew P.

description: Good lunch and breakfast food. My one complaint is that their "apple brie cheese plate" is a sliced apple with traces of Brie; slightly disappointing if you're expecting a cheese plate. Maybe they should rename the plate or up the Brie? My personal vote is for the latter.
author: Anna J.

description:
A little gem of a place.

Cozy up in a comfy couch with one of the Danube's many journals, and scribble in a poem, a cartoon, random thoughts, or read the like from the customers before you. It's a great way to pass the time!

Yummy breakfast bagels and cozy, relaxed atmosphere make this a morning favorite in my book.
author: Sophie D.

description:
My review is based not on their coffee, but their hot chocolate.  This is SwissMiss gone bad...grainy and like sandpaper with milk. 

Its a tiny little place so it looks packed with just 10 people in it.  I like it, but I wouldn't go back... if that makes any sense...
author: Mac S.

description: Good coffee. Go somewhere else for food. I got their beef sandwich, and a beer. Ended up spending almost a 20 there, not a very satisfying sandwich. Poorly done, beef was just a regular from package kind and bread was a bit stale. I would just go get food somewhere else. So many options close by.
author: Try E.

description: Really great food selection, amazing smoothies, and a super friendly staff. The interior is very pleasant and homey. I wish there were more tables! I love coming here. And they have computers that you can use, if you happen to not have a laptop! Such a cute place.
author: Carrie G.

description:
Ahhh, my old love. I used to walk from the Laurel Heights area, and then I moved to the turquoise apartments behind the Toy Boat on 5th and Clement. Needless to say I was a regular. This is the best cafe for studying I've ever frequented. I don't even mind that Jim thought my name was Sara and made a point of calling me Sara every time I stopped in (it's Kathryn). At least he remembered the same name. And at the Blue Danube I get to take on my alter-ego--Sexy Sara.

Their mochas are deliciously rich and ALL their food is awesome. Big salads, perfect sandwichs, yummy sweets. They even have the most simple, but best, pre-made paninis that they'll grill for you or are good as is, if you're in a hurry.

Say hi to Jim for me next time you go. Tell him Sara sent you.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
I eat here three times a week.

Isn't that something?  I really better back off.  Don't want to kill it, ya know?

Ice coffee $2.  Granola w/ Berries $4.50.  Wait scratch that.  Bagel Melt $4.00.  Add bacon $1.75.

Wait how much did I just spend on coffee and a bagel?

O.K.  Start over.  Sorry.  Gimme the Grilled Cheese (love that aioli) $6.25.  The side salad is totally worth eating, nice vinaigrette.  Wait you have Tomato Soup today?  Alright alright.  Half Sandwich Half Soup, final answer.

I'm going to read this silly book!  Blue Danube Diary Volume #23!  Ooo Ooo Oo!!  Last time I read all the way up to #15 and this must be the newest addition.  Like. So. Totally. Excited.  Silly observations, awesome artwork, shitty scribbles all in the same book!

Just outside the front door there are at least 4 free readables, common ground, the onion etc.  I like to grab them all.

Do I hear Blonde Redhead?  I like this album.  Maybe I'll get breakfast here tomorrow too.
author: Justin P.

description:
Another classic spot for chill atmosphere.  I don't drink coffee, but they have a tasty turkey sandwich, which comes with a complimenting salad.  I don't know what it is about that turkey sandwich, but it's good all the time.  

The staff is friendly, and they have internet w/ computers, but you have to pay.  Good place to get a drink and chill.
author: Kalani K.

description:
So I think the only thing I haven't done here is sleep, it is that inviting and comfortable.  Now if they didn't serve awesome coffee and tea (including a nice vietnamese drip) here, you would totally see a drool stain that looks like Gorby's head tattoo on the pillow of one of the couches.

So before I go off on my typical tangent, this place is a great spot to meet friends, grab a bite to eat (especially breakfast, yummy freedom toast).  At night, it's a great place to grab a beer and wait one hour for your table at Burma Superstar.

The other thing I like about this place is it's uniqueness in the sense that the tables have all been painted by local artists (kinda partial to the naked couple table...).  One of  the owners, Jimmy, also caters to local artists by allowing them to hang their artwork all over the cafe to sell.  Haven't bought anything, but I like looking at it.

My other weird sorta thing I like--and I'm so not a wacko or anything--is they have a journal that patrons write in, draw in, converse with each other in.  All super interesting stuff, even the stuff that isn't interesting is somehow interesting.  I get off, in a hyped up on caffiene sorta way, on reading people's inner most thoughts and trying to guess who wrote it.  There are also some really good artists at this coffee shop which is evident in the pages of these journals.  There are over 20 of them so come on down, grab a coffee and an oreo cookie and write about how the smell of bacon and onions cooking makes you want to eat beef again.
author: Kanoa B.

description:
I'll always come back for the pastries, the coffee or the half-liter of sangria you can down while you're, hypothetically, waiting an hour or more for your table at Burma SuperStar. They have individual Oreos for sale. They have actual food-food, best for brunch. I know!

It has a great set-up for lounging, chatting or working, and it has quality goods, somehow without the usual trappings: superhipness or fancy people on smartphones. Bonus points for being near my humble 'hood.
author: Tara R.
Bruce R.

description: a cozy place for study hall but if you're a coffee addict, i would not have high expectations here
author: Jen C.

description:
This review is NOT biased in anyway by the alluring Russian speaking Asian woman who flashed me a smile across the room, looking smart and sexy with her gold wire rim glasses.  Or the stunning blonde who flashed me a smile when she sat at the table next to me.  Or the fact that these smiles were launched despite the presence of their male companions. 

No. I like this cafe. Despite the fact that:  the wifi is not free; that it's cash only in the cafe; that it's very tiny with limited seating. But somehow, somehow this place has an intimate, welcoming vibe.  It's a great place to settle in with your Green Apple purchase for a read or a cozy conversation if you can snag a couch. 

Oh, yeah. The food was good, the tea selection more than adequate, and I could actually order a stiffer drink than coffee or tea if I wanted. All just toppings to the overall vibe cake.
author: Padawan T.

description:
It all began on Sunday July 30th, 2006. 

A long drive from Los Angeles to San Francisco the day before...my first ever visit to the 540 club & realization of its/my love for Fernet & I was hungover. I woke up, rubbed my eyes & realized a new chapter in my life was about to begin. 

NO Job.
NO Place to Live.
NO People I could call my friends.

It was the first of 10 days before all that started changing...And I was 'living' above the Blue Danube. Couch surfing at my brother's 4th & Clement pad, the 'nube quickly became my cozy little hotspot.

I searched for jobs, apartments & people watched from their outside seating...becoming part of the charming urban landscape they call Clement St. I saw bright eyed faces that were also new to the city, apartment searching & ready for everything it has to offer...and we became friends. Even ran into a woman I called my love for awhile.

Since then I've found a place two blocks away (a job too), and still visit the Blue Danube on occasion. They have tons of great food, choices of tea, music & cool vibes from the patrons. 

They do charge $5 for Internet which sucks, and thus the reason why they do not get 5 stars.

You'll still find me outside, watching passersby & reminiscing of my first days in Fog City.
author: matt m.

description:
I finally decided on a rating- 3.4.  it's nice to be able to go to a local independent coffee shop instead of the cookie cutter starbucks or peets.  However, I thought their food prices were quite steep for how much food I received.  Also, they have a 1/2 sandwich and 1/2 salad special.  Since the full sandwich comes with a mixed greens salad, I took this to mean that I can get a 1/2 order of a sandwich with 1/2 order of one of their special fancy salads.  Not so.  I was informed I can only get the mixed green salad.  I get that anyway with the full sandwich, and it costs almost as much as the full sandwich, so I said no way - just give me the full sandwich.  It wasn't overly large, I might add.  

The one I ordered was pretty good.  It was called the Caprese Sandwich: mozzarella, basil, tomato, greens, and balsamic.  The mixed greens salad is actually very nice too.  I'm going to have to go back to try out the coffee.  On Clement Street where you can get a sandwich for $2.50, it's going to be hard for me to pay $8+ for this sandwich again though.

Oh, and I got bit by a spider while waiting for my sandwich :(
author: Angie C.

description:
By far my favorite place to get coffee and either hang out or do work. Since I moved out of the neighborhood, visits are quite rare. They have a great selection of salads and sandwiches along with smoothies and the usual cafe favorites. The art work is always changing and diverse. Go there at night, its very lively and has a nice atmosphere to it.  The only thing I would say I don't like is how small it is, even though I bet it makes the cozy feeling greater. I have to consider what time of the day it is before I venture out there, so I can make sure to get a seat.

1/8/08:
I must say I get very nostalgic whenever I come here now. Since moving to the east bay, I have found myself in a rut for some good coffee. I was staying at a friends house who lives near the establishment  and decided to pick up a mocha on the way to work. I must say, I have yet to experience anywhere else that makes mochas this good--smooth, perfect balance of bitter to espresso. perfection.

I need to stay at that friends place more often--or move back to SF.
author: Ruchita P.

description:
This place has a great atmosphere; nice layout, just perfectly cramped (and full of quiet low-key people like you), and even has a huge window for ultimate ventilation and sprint/summer breeze experience while you sip on your sub-par espresso or beet juice. 

The 5 bucks for wireless is worth it for me *if* I can find a spot to sit.

Reminds me of my college days.
author: Jae K.

description:
Dear Blue Danube,

Two things (aside from your freeway-close location to me) keep me coming back to you: your pear-a-dise juice blend, and your bagels & lox.  You add tomatoes to yours, a fresh take on the traditional style which I enjoy very much.  All of your breakfast open-faced bagel sandwiches that I've tried are delicious, including the scrambled egg and cheese one.  Your fancy-shsmancy french toast is sweet and rich, and at lunchtime your sandwiches and salads are quite satisfying.  I am especially a fan of both your tuna salad and sandwich.  You're even open late enough for me to enjoy this delightful cafe fare for dinner.

In my personal opinion, your coffee leaves something to be desired, but it's pretty good in espresso-drink form.  So if I must have caffeine with my delicious breakfast bagel or decadent french toast, I get it in latte form.

Thank you, Blue Danube, for providing a much-needed European-style cafe right here on Clement St.

Cheers,
Erin
author: Erin M.

description:
An enthusiastic five stars for Blue Danube & the people who run it--
  It can be hard to find a seat there because so many people flock to this spot to hang out there all day. I've been known to do it myself on occasion. Ok, there's been a big number of those occasions. They are just a block away from my favorite bookstore in the city, and I like to score a corner sofa seat, sip a frothy latte in a big round mug & enjoy the music, the people,& read my book in the laid-back living room which is what all we danubers make it. Home.
author: jane y.

description: I had the Blue Danube salad- spinach, pear, blue cheese, and some kind of sesame dressing.  It was a bit different than the usual pear, blue cheese, pecan salad because of that dressing and it was really doing it for me.  The salad made me feel good- it was very nourishing.  I also had a perfect cappucino.  My BF had a bagel with cream cheese and lox which looked fresh and abundant.  He also had a chai which he liked.  Great menu, great atmosphere and the guy behind the counter was wonderfully cheerful.  Our food was fresh, fresh, fresh.  I am moving to this neighborhood this month and I am excited to become a regular.
author: Erika W.

description:
I met a friend at the Blue Danube last Sunday. Even though I often visit Clement Street, I had never been here before. The cafe is quaint, with a couple tables outside and about a dozen inside. The menu has the typical coffee offerings, a large variety of smoothies, and a surprising number of sandwiches. I had the rosemary chicken, which was very tasty. It's served with a side salad.

This seems like a place with a lot of regulars, who settle in with reading or schoolwork over a cup of coffee. It's a nice neighborhood place, but no one seems to mind if you're just popping in after browsing at Green Apple down the street.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I greatly enjoy this place. When I go in, I feel super artsy and hip as I order my white mocha and a croissant. I can't wait to just chill there, read a book, and drink a beer or mimosa (they serve alcohol!) Although I feel as if some of the food/drinks in this place can be a little pricier than one would expect, I suppose it is redeemed by the cool tables and chairs that furnish this establishment.

I mean, on one of the tables I sat at, there was a naked man and woman. Sure it was some kind of art thing, but any place that I can behold nudity as a placemat to my breakfast pastry before 10 in the morning definitely rates high on my list. 

I took one star off for the hit and miss employees. Sometimes I get someone who's really nice, and other times I wonder why ornery seems to be their word of the day.
author: Bel P.

description:
ahhhhh the memories.  This was a regular hang out for me and my college buds back in the day.  Great coffee and teas and some not so shabby eats.  Lots of comfy couches and chairs to just kick back and read, relax and scope out the hotties from USF, UCSF and the other local institutions of higher learning in the area.

Came back just to pick up some coffee on the way to a meeting with a co-worker and discovered they now have free wi-fi and several computers that I am assuming people can rent for Internet access.  I'm glad to see our fair city is starting to catch up with our European, Asian and Latin American counterparts who have been offering Internet access for years!

the memories!
author: A P.

description:
i love this place...   it's got such a cozy atmosphere to it...  the food is always good...   the sandwiches on the menu are all really friggin' good! the coffee could be a little stronger, but that's just my preference. 
the rosemary chicken sandwich is my personal favorite, and the roast beef sandwich made me realize that i actually do like roast beef...    very good service too.
author: anthony g.

description:
My Blue D.!  Oh, what would I do without you???  

Most of the staff is very friendly (Sergio is the best!) and the owners are awesome, really good people!  There is a great selection of salads and sandwiches.  Breakfast at the Blue D. is also fabulous.  They have delicious organic teas and make a great latte.  Ok yes, you do end up paying $3 for a cup of tea but I'd rather hang here on any day than in any other inner/outer richmond coffee place.    

Seating is a bit tight but that makes it more cozy.  Weekend mornings are quite crowded but you should have no problem finding a seat in the evenings.  

Speaking as a true coffeeshop whore with great taste, congratulations to the Blue D. as it has clearly won my heart.
author: Riri S.

description:
I live in Santa Clara and work in Palo Alto, which is all basically Starbucks Land, so when I go to SF on the weekends I always hit up Blue Danube to accomplish various writing pursuits.  

It's hip, the servers are really friendly, and the food is really good.  It's your typical sandwich/desserts/coffee/tea place.  But, I'm just going to lay it out here, I love a good tunafish sandwich. If a tunafish sandwich is on the menu, I'm going to order it.  As a tunafish connoisseur, then, I'm going to tell you that they make the best tuna sandwiches I've ever had.  I don't know how the hell they make tuna so damn good, but they do. Thank you, Blue Danube, that's all I'll be eating for lunch on Saturdays. 5 stars.  

Also, after 6 hours, or after some ridiculous time span like that, of writing and studying evil math for the evil GREs, who wouldn't like to sit down with a pitcher of Sangria to share with your equally-busy but ready to consume alcohol friend?  Good times.
author: Stefanie S.

description:
Thus far, my favorite coffee shop in the city.

Good coffee and a great coffee shop menu - their ingredients are fresh and they make the best breakfast sandwiches around.  The only downside is that this place is almost always packed - but I guess that's what you'd expect when a coffee shop is this good.

I've been meaning to try their smoothies too - but haven't gotten around to it yet.
author: Lauren B.

description:
For an independent, artsy Coffee house and Pub, it is definitely one of the top places to get your coffee in these local streets. Laptop friendly with also 3 pay-for-internet desktop computers available. 

Great for a relaxing, slow, hot and I mean REALLY HOT coffee and/or espresso drink. The steamed milk was burning hot. We sat there for about 10 minutes before we could drink our coffee/tea drinks because the added steamed milk was so hot.

Not for people in rush.

Very small place. They have a couch and easy chair, plus maybe 8 more 2 person tables around, but I guess it's just not my style for a place to chill. 

It's so crowded even with 2 or 3 people in line, but hey I would go for the coffee -- espresso and drip are very smooth and strong. Earthy, Artsy ambiance.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
I have to give this place four stars.  The food was good, and even though the place is small -- it probably seats at most 25 people inside and a few more outside -- they were extremely nice to us when we pulled together four tables right in the middle of the place so that eight of us could have lunch together today.  They just politely  asked us to leave a walkway and left it at that.

On to the food, there's a good mix of bagels and sandwiches on other breads (wheat toast, ciabatta, etc.), and there are plenty of vegetarian options.  I had a veggie sandwich with avocado, sprouts, tomato, and cheddar on toast, with a side salad.  The salad had a little too much vinaigrette, but otherwise I enjoyed the meal.  

The drink selection includes coffee, smoothies, bottled beer (the SF usuals: Fat Tire, Guinness, etc.), and probably other options that I didn't notice.  I had a beer, but wished I'd gone for a smoothie; they looked pretty good.
author: Andy G.

description:
This is a really nice local coffee house. I work not too far and it's a perfect place to meet a friend for a quick catch-up. It's cozy and the service is always warm and friendly. 

The coffee drinks are good though I won't recommend the Chai. No offense, but it tastes pretty unpleasant. They also serve wine and beers. More power to ya! The food are pretty good too. I like the croissant-wich and the wraps.
author: Perry S.

description:
Why doesn't this place have free wireless, damnit?! If it did, then I'd put it in a holy trinity of San Francisco coffeehouses with Rockin' Java and Coffee to the People. I swear. 

Great food (the hummus plate is SO good... what do they put on those cucumbers? magical pepper yumminess?!), great soy chai, vegan cookies, comfy and cozy with outdoor seating, too, for that rare sunny Inner Richmond day...

FREE WIRELESS, PLEASE! That's all I ask...
author: Lisa T.

description:
Such a cute place. My boyfriend and I had some time to kill so we decided to walk into this cute cafe. I don't even want to call it a cafe -- it's way better because it serves bloody mary's, sangria, beers! Their sangria was yummy. And I usually don't like hot apple ciders but their's is very crisp and perfect for a cold, SF "summer" day.

Don't get the pastries  in the afternoon, we both had the cupcakes (1 chocolate for my sweet tooth! and 1 vanilla for my white boyfriend) and they didn't taste very good -- so I'm sure they were sitting there the entire day.

The salads are super fresh and their sandwich/salad selection is pretty awesome. Cute neighborhood cafe -- perfect place to spend the day...coffee in the morning, drinks in the afternoon/evening and plenty of snacks in between. I also love the Danube theme -- they have a corner bookcase filled with literature about Danube.
author: Vanessa W.

description: Food and drinks are tasty!  Everything Is freshly made. Seems like people hang out there regularly. It can be a very nice place to people watch. There is even a girl that sits in the same spot everyday and has 4 different guys visiting her each hour. I wonder if she lives there or goes there to get attention?
author: Wine L.

description:
Well I happened to chance by in the morning the other day. It was fantastic. I enjoyed all the random things, that I haven't had in so long. I miss Richmond District, Blue Danube, and all the crazy restaurants that are at your fingertips!

Also, being opened late really helps.
author: Michael C.

description:
It's quickly becoming a weekend tradition... I meet a friend here for 'morning' (sometime around noon) coffee since it's about half way between our houses, we get a little something to eat and drink and then walk down to Golden Gate Park. The coffee is good, there is a good selection of teas, and they serve mimosas! This past weekend I had the rosemary chicken sandwich and it was absolutely delicious. I've always found the service here to be friendly and attentive as well - and I've never had a problem getting a table outside where the dog can pretend he's little and crawl underneath my feet so he looks just pathetic enough to get away with begging from other tables - while hopefully not knocking my table over when he stands up. 

But quite possibly my favorite thing about this place is the fact that every time I've been here, we've been lucky enough to be sitting around some cool people. You know when you're sitting really close to the table next to you and it's always that little 'do we talk?' 'do we pretend like we can't hear anything they're saying' kind of dilemma? Well, I've never had that here - it's always the perfect blend of friendly chatting and leaving each other the fuck alone.
author: Suge K.

description:
This is where you go if you are looking for a coffee shop that is NOT the mainstream Starbucks or Peet's. Their drinks are great, but I go for the food. In a little coffee shop, it surprises me to find freshly made sandwiches and salads on the menu. ( I recommend the spinach) More of a cozy neighborhood cafe where you don't just go for the coffee.  

The tuna sandwich is great, which I heard was inspired from Europe?? the side salads that come with the sandwiches are just as tasty and if there is a long line, it's worth the wait.  I personally like their veggie sandwiches; I'm not too big on meat, so its a nice change.  Aside from coffee and food, they have a delectable selection of deserts that tug at your sleeves when you are ordering and offer sangria and drinks as well.  I believe that they also offer music once and week ( I think...Tues nights??) and display local artists on their walls. 

Blue Danube is definitely the great little coffee shop that will keep you coming back.
author: Vivian C.

description:
blue danube is a nice place to grab a bite to eat (pastries and such) sit and read, do wifi (free, i think). nice people here. friendly patrons, very small,  compact place.

the bad? the coffee, they use mr. expresso, too harsh for my taste.
a cup l (1.90). added half/half, sweeteners and it's almost good. still could taste a little harshness.
author: Victor G.

description: Unpretentious, cozy and great prices. Had a large drip coffee and a great almond croissant for less than 5 bucks.
author: Jess G.

description: great service, love the basil tomato bisque, always get the rosemary chicken sandie, and the strawberry blast.  Sometimes order take a little too long.  A  great place to eat and read a book.
author: Lu G.

description:
Top 6 reasons this place rules...
1.  Super good coffee
2. They make fresh juice
3. People that work/and own it are wicked nice
4.  It is cozy
5.  They are open pretty late
6. You can sit outside with your coffee and do some quality people watching
author: erin f.

description:
Hella good cupcakes! 

Everytime I want to come in here and read..it's PACKED! I hate that! I would give this place 5 stars if there were more seats available.
author: Cris L.

description: Great! This place had me hooked right when I walked in.  Love how it is so far from feeling like a Starbucks or Pete's.  It is that place that you imagine people open up their minds and discuss the most intellectual of topics.  I am really speechless on how much I love this cafe.  The white mocha is pretty damn good also.
author: Mr. tyson R.

description:
I used to go here and crochet, listen to the live jazz combo, and sip on a misto while I waited for my laundry at the laundromat across the street. Those were the only times I enjoyed doing my laundry.

Whenever I had friends in town, I'd take them to Danube for the atmosphere, the french toast, and the community journals.
author: elaine m.

description:
The wifi is no longer free; Blue Danube is now a paid 'zrnet' wireless location priced at $5 per day. That's annoying, though it does mean I feel no obligation to regularly re-order a snack or beverage while slurping up their connection all afternoon.

The greek yogurt was made with good ingredients, though it seemed a bit small --- it's served in a wine glass --- for the $4 price.
author: Rick C.

description:
I LOVE this place. I used to come here every Sunday morning when my lovely Girlfriend lived in the Richmond just a few blocks away, but she had to move and I haven't been back since. But I really do have to start coming back it is so worth it. 

Not only do I love the neighborhood, but the food here is good, the smoothies are good, and the atmosphere is just right for a laid back Sunday morning. Provided you can get a seat. Which at times can prove quite difficult, but to me for some reason, it is still worth it to wait around to find a seat and enjoy my breakfast there. Maybe its the bagel sandwich that I love so much. The one with the Black Forrest ham, added bacon, cheddar cheese and tomatoes. Or maybe its the beautiful french toast with all the fresh fruit. Or maybe... well, you get the picture. Clean, simple good food. Not pretentious. 
I miss you Blue Danube. and I can't wait till we meet again.
author: Lawrence A.

description:
I like this place a lot- mostly because it's very comfy-cozy and chill.  The staff is friendly, and the coffee is great.  I've never tried the food (and probably never will), though.

It's also the only place I've ever known that keeps "house journals" where customers can anonymously harness their creativity, and write or draw whatever they want for the world to read/see.  I think that's pretty damn cool, honestly- what a concept!
author: M S.

description: This is a great place to study or work.  It's not too loud or insanely quiet; it's just perfect.  Plus, they have good food, coffee, and a variety of other drinks, e.g., smoothies, if you don't like coffee.
author: M. N.

description:
This place is cozy and fun. They serve great food like salad and sandwiches and have a wide variety of smoothies and juices and also Coca-Cola in original glass bottles! woo! 
Don't forget dessert! Lots of cute little cakes to choose from which will definitely leave you very happy. And if you like tea, they also have a huge variety of them to choose from.

There is also quite a lot of room inside. I've done my homework and studied for things quite often here and found it to be a very comforting environment. 

I suggest the Cobb Salad or the Rosemary Chicken Sandwich. To die for. :)
author: Bella S.

description:
Despite that they DON'T take credit cards, I like this little house. It's got great fresh, fast coffee, and some good close outside seating. It's oft overcrowded, but ne'er to worry, as people stream in and empty out in matters of clustered minutes. The condiment stirrer table is located in an off-handish sort of weird place, but I can deal. 

It's got a good feel so I like it here well enough. And fresh juice and breakfasts look desirable but I have only had the coffee. Someday I may provide an update!
author: Adrienne S.

description:
This has been my favorite local coffee house for the past four years.  When I was a grad student, this was the first place I'd go to study and procrastinate.  Now it's a haven I visit where I can grade papers or read or write in my journal while crying silently to myself or, most importantly, indulge in their Cobb Salad and Mexican Hot Chocolate.  The food is always fresh and healthy.  Their french toast topped with bright berries once gave my morning the start it needed.  It was a visual and tasty delight.  

The owners are super friendly and low key.  They're easy to approach and chat with.  They were nice from day one and have been consistently kind and personable.

The only reason why I don't give five stars is because it is often crowded there on weekends.  It's cool though, to see the regulars.  Like the guy who sits alone and sketches people.  The small space is definitely a plus in terms of intimacy, but I don't like to go there when it's too crowded with yappy people.
author: Mijin L.

description:
Love this place.  I've always been walking around this area and never noticed it, the outdoor sign is hard to recognize.  The prices are worth it especially the ambiance.  This place is a very chill, artsy-fartsy eclectic hole in the wall type of place.  Seems a little crowded but the outdoor seating is great when it's sunny out.  Try their smoothies and their pastries, hey try everything, I've been pleased with everything so far.  

They usually have local artists once a week or so.  Every type of artist: music, painters, clothing designers, everything!!  And the art work is usually for sale, vendors come in to sell sometimes too. 

Surprise, surprise: they serve alcohol in the evening.  Perfect place when you're waiting for a crowded restaurant to die down, which is pretty common in Clement.
author: Jamie Q.

description:
Update:  Last time I went in here, I asked for a Sangria, and they didn't have any, so I choose a mimoza, which was really good.  I was staying out on the sun, reading a book, enjoying the mimoza, and then the late, and checking out the cute girl on my side.  Life couldn't get any better   :)  

I still can't give them 5 stars, as their furniture is pretty crappy.

-----

As an European, I shouldn't even dignify to enter this place.  Looks like most of those coffee shops, with old tables, unfomfortable chairs, semi dirty that hippies and granola eating types love, or cash-less students.

But they make the Best Iced Latte EVER in the US!!  (i think european frape's are still better).   Plus they even have beers on tap  (never seen this in the east coast).  I like sitting outside (if it is sunny), and playing my Nintendo DS. while enjoying that good coffee of theirs.

They also offer wireless internet, for 5$/hr, but you can just can steal some internet from those unprotected wireless routers around the area. So, why pay?   They also have computers (if you have no computer), for you to use at a reasonable fee.

The staff is generally friendly, with plenty of piearcings and tattos, but not too many of them.  Ah, and coffee is cheap.
author: Ardit B.

description:
I love the vibe here. As well as vibe, they also have great food and drinks, both hot and cold.

My favorite item that I get may sound simple, the cheddar and tomato on a bagel. It is served hot and it just melts in my mouth.

The atmosphere is a little earthy, but in a good way. They have journals to write in for public view. You can read other thoughts as well. If you write your own piece, you are leaving a piece of yourself, which I think is cool.

I would certainly stop by this place to read or just enjoy a drink. It is open late, so you can get a late-night dessert.

They only take cash, so bring some dollars with you. I have found myself without cash or very little on more than one occasion and it is not fun making difficult choices, bagel or soy hot chocolate?
author: Christopher W.

description: I stopped here randomly for a quick grab and go breakfast.  I ordered a brownie with a hand-squeezed apple juice (yes, apples), which was very different and interesting.  The apple juice really felt like drinking apples and not just concentrate like you get from most drinks such as Motts.  It was very unique and had an interesting taste to it, although it was quite pricey for this hand squeezed juice ($4.25).  The brownie itself was alright--it was dense and had a lot of chocolate flavor in it which is pretty typical of the brownies I typically like.  Overall, this is an interesting coffee house and I would probably return to try out their coffee next time.
author: Lawrence E.

description: Great place to grab a coffee in Inner Richmond. Tasty, well made drinks in a comfortable atmosphere!
author: Emily C.

description:
EDIT:

THIS PLACE IS CRAP. 

So I work about 4 blocks away from Blue Danube on Clement, and you know what? I can drive down to Coffee Bean and Tea Leaf on Fillmore from my house (in the Inner Richmond), find parking, wait in line, order, get my drink, and be at work, all before I can get some coffee at Blue Danube. Seriously. I'm not lying.

By the time I got my drink, which was a soy mint mocha, it was so disgusting I threw it away after a sip. It was horrible, like bathroom cleaner, old milk, and mouthwash. What a waste of 4 dollars and my precious time.

This place is disgusting.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
This has become one of my favorite coffee shops in San Francisco. I love to go in, order lunch along with a nice, large hot tea, and read for an hour or two. After a while, you start seeing regulars, and that makes me happy. They have a nice lunch menu, and their food is great. Huge salads, delicious sandwiches, sweet stuff, and even a few fruit offerings. I haven't tried their smoothies, but they look great too.

My removal of one star is for a couple of reasons...the first being their small breakfast offerings. I think that portion of the menu may be growing, though, so kudos there. Also, their internet rental fee is a bit high, and some of their tables are a bit small and in uncomfortable locations (like right next to the line where people order). But, overall, this is a great spot.
author: Kathleen P.

description:
'The Blue,' as I affectionally call it, is my favorite coffee shop, full stop! The only downside is that it is a little expensive, but the food never disappoints and the atmosphere is inviting. 

Make sure to try the breakfast wraps, the sangria, and the french toast. In terms of smoothies, try the bananarama (or whatever they call the one with bananas and chocolate), it is to die for! 

Also, write in the journal... they keep the old ones stores on the bookshelf in the back right corner. Flipping through them is always entertaining.

The Blue is a must!
author: Bay M.

description:
Good coffee, good service, nice little {semi-annoyingly on the weekends] cramped space, excellent juice. It's nice to find a independent coffeehouse where the staff has not been infiltrated by pretentious hipster spies. 

At least it was like that last time I was there. One point is taken off for the semi-high prices. I still have to go back there and try everything meatless on the menu, item by item. My roommate vouches for the Greek Yogurt.
author: Jordan S.

description: I love this place and would come here a lot more often and spend a lot more money here if they took credit or debit cards.
author: Patrick T.

description:
How do you earn 5 stars despite serving wayyy sub-par coffee?

Have: the overall best vibe of any coffee shop in the city (shut up-- i've been to all the good ones), eclectic yet tasteful music, an entire staff of genuinely sweet people, good-looking but not snobby patrons, and have 27 volumes of guest journals featuring interesting sketches and funny/pathetic entries.
author: John J.

description: Very nice, cozy place. Small but comfortable, with delicious drinks and a very friendly feel.
author: Bret W.

description: Stopped in really quick to grab a bite and coffee on my way to work. I had to try one of their fresh juices too! The Pear-a-dise juice was fricking amazing! , the coffee was good, and I wished I could have stayed longer to enjoy the cuddly atmosphere. They even have 'puters there for 'puterless people to use the interwebs! It's cash only, but there's a Chase atm directly across the street!
author: Lindsay J.

description:
cozy. nice variety of teas (lychee anyone?)
haven't tried any pastries or kitchen food, probably will one day.
i'm hardly ever in this area seeing as how Clement St is the battle of the Chinese soccer moms. 

This is what i'm usually yelling as I pound my steering wheel while driving on Clement: Uhh, turn off your fucking blinker! Where are you going!??! STOP at the stop signs Ohmyfuckingpookgaihomgachandenglaygafai NO FUCKING WAY you're double parked! STOP MOVING ohmygod you're still moving. You're going to fucking hit me aren't you!? Mmmhaaai ah mah!?!? JUN HAI AH!??! omggg say bot po..lay deem ja che ah!?!?  GET OUT OF MY WAY!! I'M HUNGRY!! 

....sorry i made so much noise trying to get the door open on monday. it was pouring rain. i was wet.  the handle wasn't turning. 

the cool kitschy hipster kids glared at me. =(
author: Susy C.

description:
This is a good neighborhood coffee spot.  Only thing that would make it better is if the wi-fi was free.  It isn't, but if you have a ZRNet account, you can get online.  I pay $10 a month for the service -- I can drop in and log on any time.

Okay, okay, free wi-fi isn't the only think this place needs.  But its slightly ramshackle atmosphere is part of its charm.  There's a carpet you'd never put in your own living room .... chairs and tables that have seen better days ... and eclectic art on the walls.

The menu?  Breakfast, brunch, sandwiches, coffee, a few beers and wines, smoothies and juice.  And your usual assortment of Inner Richmond characters.

(Bonus:  Make this your waiting room while your reservation simmers at Burma Superstar right across the street.)
author: Sanjeev B.

description: I love your coffee, chai, hot cocoa, and smoothies. You are the reason I get excited when the sun comes out. Sunny days spent sipping on your drinks while studying or chatting outside can't be beat. You epitomize the coffeehouse my neighborhood lacks. I only wish you weren't so popular since half the time I have to take my drink to-go since there are no seats left. But I guess that's a good problem for you to have.
author: Victoria N.

description:
Come and go, come in slow, oh Danube, two Purple Rains Yo..make conversation, drop the dough. come and go, walk out slow.

This place has some  awesome seating...real cafe feel with a wide span of fresh prepared food's to eat, the kitchen closes at 9pm but the place is open late. This morning when I went there for my morning smoothie I saw this cop car catching all those freaking speeders on Clement..bad folk, bad folk for speeding on Clement..
author: John L.

description:
DON'T COME HERE IF YOU ARE:
-hungry
-in a rush
-with more than 2 people
-trying to work

COME HERE IF YOU:
-like to sit and people watch
-sip mimosas
-love ham and cheese croissants 
-have cash
author: Rina C.

description: $2 internet. Really? Plus it didn't even work. Cash only. I do like the menu, ambiance and juicebar however.
author: Renata B.

description: This place gets a 4 because it's an awesome place to chill before getting into Burma Superstar...as others have commented. They have Mighty Leaf tea which is one of my favorites - and give an option to serve as loose leaves with a small tea pot or with a bag. Very nice! Their apple cider is tasty and their coffee/espresso drink prices are decent...just am yet to try their coffee. The place is small and doesn't feel very clean - but hey, it's a nice, warm haven before getting your burmese food on!
author: Lisa H.

description:
I wanted to like this place since the atmosphere is super cool and funky and the people were nice.  But the food was less than mediocre and the prices were crazy!  $21 for two lattes, a wrap and a bagel!  How is this possible?  

My bf's bagel with egg was greasy and I got sick off of my salmon wrap.  

Such a bummer.
author: Melissa W.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. It's quirky and charming and attracts an interesting crowd that varies depending on the time of day. I tend to settle in here with my laptop for hours when I have a big project I need to finish. There are power outlets near most of the tables, and Wi-Fi is $4 a day. 

The food looks good but I can't eat most of it (because it's all full of wheat); it's mostly salads and sandwiches. Drinks run the gamut from lattes to smoothies to delicious, delicious sangria, and they've got beer and cider on tap. I love the variety. 

The location is great. I can focus on my work when I need to or just gaze out the big windows (which are open on nice days) for some fascinating people-watching. I wish I'd found this place years ago, because it's quickly become my favorite coffee shop.

Also, it cracks me up that they sell Oreos for 25 cents apiece.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Current update, as prior review was based on experience 4 years ago. 
What has changed? 
Nothing.

 Still cute.
 Coffee is still bad.

At least it's consistent.
author: Max R.

description:
Good at the Danube:
coffee's decent
refills: $1
breakfast croissant
nice spot to sit & peoplewatch
salad options
blt options
beer options
central location in my hood!

occasional drawbacks: 
frightening electronic or boy band music choices of staff (not always, okay, occasional, but troublesome)
nowhere to sit sunday morning
this one guy who sits and draws people (do you know who I mean?!)

Thats it really. I like it here. I don't hang here at night, never tried. But its pleasant at all other hours. Staff are friendly.
author: b a p.

description:
Love this place. My boyfriend & I have made it, "our place"...

The Good Things:
The food
The California Wrap (if u wanna get specific)
The Sweet Things Black & White cupcakes
The coffee
The ever changing art on the walls
The ambiance
The quiet
The beer & wine
The fact that it's open late
Great place to go if Burma Superstar is too packed

The Not-So-Good Things:
Orders can take a little too long sometimes
Internet access isn't free
Sometimes too crowded on the weekends

So.... 

Mostly good things.
author: Samantha R.

description: Honestly I won't be back, inside was nice, menu is pretty good, but there are better coffee houses if you need power and internet, they want money for wifi access, its very limited at 480kbs, and a 2 hour limit, I found coffee houses with free wifi and 5.5 mbps so like 10.5x faster download speed, for FREE.
author: Frank G.

description:
I'll be frank, Frank. I found the hipster vibe of this place so offputting that I didn't frequent it for months even though I knew it existed. I continue to find it odd how Clement has a few random "white" hangouts. No, seriously. I love Clement. I like all the people and the shops and the variety of food. Still, I find it disconcerting how there are a few places where the majority of people there are white-- it doesn't really fit with the neighborhood.
