I sort of like feeling as though I'm amongst the international throng and here you can't help but be aware that it tends to be a whiter crowd (I say this as someone who is white by the way). 

Anyway, I started coming here because it reminds me of a cozy coffeehouse that I worked at during college. It is cool, but also cozy. Also, the food here is shockingly good. I find the prices odd in that food is fairly inexpensive, but coffee/drinks seem a little pricey.

For the laptop geeks: plugs lurk about in the corners here and they have nice seating for studying or what have you. I *think* their internet is a pay service, but you may be able to 'borrow' from open wifi in the area.
author: Katy W.

description:
Maybe it's just me -- but, everytime I get a coffee from Blue Danube it tastes burnt.  Even fresh made espresso drinks (and, I know the difference between espresso taste and burnt coffee taste before anyone says a DAMN thing, thank you...)  Yucky...

And, it is always crowded - which may mean it's popular and all - but, it is really annoying when I'm with people who INSIST on going to the Danube... 

Meh, not impressed at all...
I'm a girl who likes her coffee - three cups a day (at LEAST, if you want me to function) - I will be quite honest: I don't like it from the Blue Danube.

Sorry - I WANT to like Blue Danube - because I'm all for the small indie coffee shop kicking the ass of the stupid 'effing chains... however... just not that great.
author: Kate R.

description:
This ain't no disco, this ain't no party, this ain't no Danube around.....  
Back in the day this place was run by the meanest witch on the planet. She ran her business with the temperament of a Marine Corp drill sargent, Lou Gossett style. Her mannerisms were like that of the Incredible Hulk. Though she never turned green, she roared if you didn't follow her rules. The most common offenses against the state of Ms. Lou Ferrigno were to violate the "no outside food" rule, and when very busy, adhere to her overtures to your unplanned departure. In short: SHE CWAZY!

Metro was feeling a bit in need of the Teutonic coffee experience that the name of this Clement St. joint conjures. Hadn't been back in a while and heard that ownership had changed. Feeling a little skittish. Would there be caped crusaders in lederhosen serving up espressos? Maybe you'd have some remixed techno UM-PAPA music all Kreftwerked up? I was expecting some serious change after my last experiences at the Danube. I'm happy to report that dark clouds have parted revealing a bright sunny day. Birds have started singing again. Former dejected customers are returning, myself included. The Danube is a good place to chill and drink coffee while reading the Sunday paper, or to meet friends for some convo. Once in a while I get a PTSD Danube flashback and look over my shoulder to make sure El Loco isn't about to bight my ass. But to quote Bill Clinton, "Change is good."

Only 3 duckets until I can recover from the old days of "Psycho Owner, que'st que c'est."
author: Johnny C.

description: I recently moved back to San Francisco from SoCal, and in my absence all I've been hearing about is Blue Bottle this and that.  Before I had a chance to try Blue Bottle Coffee, I moseyed (sp?) on over to the closest cafe in my new 'hood -- Blue Danube.  I must say, whether it's house coffee or the French brew, it always satisfies.  And after trying Blue Bottle at Velo Rouge, I actually prefer the brew at Blue Danube better.  I also find that it's easier to find a place to sit, and the food comes faster.  Only downside is the wi-fi's not free.  You take what you can get, right?
author: Audrey E.

description:
Great way to wake up to on a Saturday morning-ish. 

Specifically, waking up to a BLAT...Bacon, Lettuce, Avocado and Tomato. They make a stellar one here.

Also offers a comfy couch and a great collection of politically ironic used books to enjoy. And coffee too.

The ultimate in a relaxing, friendly, neighborhood coffee shop experience.
author: Kelly R.

description:
A mostly nice setup.  A few couches, but mostly small tables for one or two people.  A nice variety of drinks - wine, coffee, tea, cider, etc.  The food is pretty good - a variety of things, but the salads stick out a bit more than the rest.  And the presentation of it all adds a bit of class.

One thing I'm not a fan of is the row of 3 or 4 computers.  Or maybe it's 2 or 3  Either way, they don't seem like they get a whole lot of use and take up some needed space.

They close at 10pm, I believe.  Kind of a drag for late night hanging out.
author: masa s.

description:
I'll admit, I've only had coffee here SO FAR, but I'll be back.

This place is inviting, cozy, and very laid back.  There aren't many tables, but that doesn't mean people are rushing you along your way.  You're welcome to sit and hang out for a while.  There are even a few tables outside to enjoy that random 65 degree day in January.  The people watching on Clement is great too =)

The service is friendly and helpful if you can't decide what you want.  And by the way...the mochas are great!

My bf got a smoothie with chocolate, banana and mint and it was surprisingly good as well.  i can't wait to go back and try the sandwiches and cakes everyone else has mentioned.
author: Candace C.

description:
This place provides a nice spot for sitting and chatting with friends... I am a tea drinker.. so it is important to have other alternatives... or mocha... coffee for the non coffee drinker... I am pleased... 

Staff friendly... clean... yummy baked goods... mocha good too... yum yum!

Something I enjoy very much... their tables.. I find them pleasing :) I have spent many hours there chatting the afternoon away... I should revisit soon. :)

A
author: Amelia M.

description:
Small, cozy place, great for people watching and the coffee is ok.
Open until 10pm on Sundays.

It's when you start comparing places like this one to Starbucks and Peet's you start realizing how important it is to support the independent, small coffee joints.

So fight the good fight...go to your local, non-over-franchised coffee shop and get a cup or two.
author: Rich S.

description: Just stopped by for a bit to grab coffee on a cold, rainy night. Seating is pretty limited but the couches are comfy if you can grab one. Coffee was pretty standard as far as I'm concerned. But I did have the blueberry pie or cobbler or whatever it was and it was pretty good!
author: Brad Y.

description:
Dear Blue Danube,

I became a die hard fan in college (Go Dons!) and though I've since moved out of the neighborhood, I have to take the chance that you read these reviews to say that there is a commercial space for rent across the street from my house on Sacramento and Scott. Please please move here or open up a sister cafe. PLEASE???

Sincerely,

Die Hard Fan Who Can Only Justify Driving to Have Tea So Often.
author: Ginny Z.

description:
The Blue Danube has many functions. It is a wonderful place to come on a nice saturday or sunday morning and kill time having their yummy french toast and a fruit cup. Or you could shop on clement street first and then stop by for lunch and have their great grilled cheese or turkey sandwich. 

Another of its fine functions is to serve as a great place to sit and drink coffee, tea, beer, sangria, etc., while you wait to be seated at Burma Superstar. This place has saved me many times from freezing to death while I stared through Burma's window and watched people eating slowly at MY table!! lol.

Another very interesting function this place serves as is an outlet for your artistic or literary talents. They have all these little books laying around (like 30 volumes?) that you can just pick up and start writing or drawing in. It truly is a fantastic idea. And for those who aren't inclined to draw or write it is even more fun to read through those books and absorb the craziness of san francisco. I have laughed out loud a million times reading people's crazy adventures or funny pictures. It's like picking up someone's diary and getting a peek at their innermost thoughts and feelings......without the fear of getting caught.

My recommendation would be to come on a sunny saturday or sunday morning when they open their huge windows that look out onto clement street, order the french toast, pick up one of the volumes and enjoy your morning. It doesn't get better than that.
author: Josh J.

description:
These kinds of cozy, chatty, kinda funky, neighborly cafes are totally endangered. Blue Danube is one of the few places left in the city where I feel comfortable just hanging out, reading and writing. It's practically nostalgic.

I usually get a little pot of tea, which is served on a fancy platter. They also have one of the best Cobb salads I've ever enjoyed. It's HUGE. Their smoothies are filling and delicious, but if you just want an Oreo, they got that, too.

I love the fancy tables, the friendly staff, and the silly sign on the bathroom wall.

Hooray for Blue Danube!
author: Jaina D.

description: My friends and I settled in and ordered some beverages while on the list for a table at a nearby restaurant.  The atmosphere was nice, you can definitely tell that this is a local hangout.  The menu was impressive, extensive including alcoholic beverages such as mimosas, sangria, among others and smoothies.  But the cafe lost stars for a dirty restroom and by far the worst chai tea latte I have ever had.
author: Jennifer L.

description: This place has certainly be out here in the inner richmond for a while. I used to pass by it all the time but have honestly only actually tried it 1-2 times. I had their hot chocolate here which was pretty good. Just the fact that it's a none chain coffee shop earns it some stars.
author: Petra S.

description: Cute little coffee shop w/ large open windows, twinkling christmas lights, and good coffee =) Great place to chill w/ friends or bring a date after dinner.
author: Becka T.

description: This is the kind of place that makes me think that San Francisco trumps Chicago by a slight margin when it comes to regular, everyday cafe food. Their turkey, croissant sandwhich was very delicious, and their lattes are great.
author: Irvin A.

description: OH, OK I had the fresh juiced juice, Yum. Then I had the locks bagel but of course I have to substitute the bagel for their GLUTEN FREE bread .... HELLO THANK YOU. LOVE YOU. After lunch I had their jasmine tea, it was great, however the cup they give you is not large enough so your tea continued to steep (bleh). My complaint, is it's freezing in there! I would stay longer but I would have needed a blanket.
author: Star Z.

description:
When you want BOTH a great cup of Joe AND a good bite to much on, you should probably look no further than Blue Danube (but what do I know, I'm a "tourist").  This place offers what Starbucks does not-- a feeling of individuality mixed with.. well, real food!  

Unfortunately, there's no Blue Danube in NYC.  But, it remains one of my fondest stops in SF.
author: Amy Y.

description: This is a really cool place to just relax and hang out.  I'm all about places with character and this coffee shop is definitely not lacking of it.  I love the half lit chandeliers with missing parts, and the comfy sofas with miss matched pillows.  The whole vibe of the place is nice.  I can't say much about their drinks or food though.  I had the lychee tea and it was pretty good.  I like how they serve it with the teapot and your own little cup.  Looking over their menu though everything looked pretty good.  I'll be back to give their food a try!
author: Cecille B.

description:
Nobody mentioned the sangria.   Cheap sangria while you wait for your table at Burma Star.  And Fat Tire on tap.  

Actually, I found this little coffee house quite enjoyable.  I couldn't for the life of me figure out why a herd of people were standing outside the door of Burma Star staring longingly at people stuffing their faces when there was plenty of seating just across the way at Blue Danube.  A 1.5 hour wait is nothin' once you get a little sauced up.
author: sarah k.

description:
I didn't have the coffee here, so I can't comment on that. But It's a great place to have something to drink while waiting to be seated at Burma Superstar. 

Though it was small, I love the environment. Sofas, vintage-y chandeliers, and they're not trying too hard to be an "art gallery". Eclectic, warm & colorful, but still clean. Soft lighting. No flies buzzing around. 

But what TOTALLY won me over is that they played Calexico's Black Light. I'll be back.
author: N B.

description:
5 stars for the Mexican hot chocolate. No one should live without trying it. A huuuge chocolate bar melted into hot milk with nutmeg, cinnamon, marshmallows, and whipped cream. It tastes like fall and is just simply wonderful.
3 stars for the service. They aren't very friendly. Also, some of the desserts are not too fresh. I still need to come here for an actual meal... 
But it is a very cozy, cool place to stop by and hang out with a drink.   
OH! And don't forget, they only take cash.
author: Andria M.

description: Small coffee is less than 2 bucks and pretty good. The ambiance is a small to medium size chill coffee house with several outside tables. I like the rustic decorations that make it feel right at home in San Francisco.
author: R J.

description:
four stars. confident.

-Oreos.  and loose leaf tea to go with it.  One star.
-A Vegie sammich dat tastes fresh, and hearty (you can actually get full off of it.
-Clean bathroom.
-Jivey ambience...a big o fat overweight star.

Those are my four stars.  the items are interchangable with other great foods and aspects of this Richmond-characterized locale.
author: Jay M.

description:
A perfect place to stop by after dinner. My friends and I had coffee and shared a slice of cheesecake along with some talk time. My vanilla latte was perfect. The right amount of vanilla syrup mixed with espresso and steamed milk. The cheesecake was so-so. I guess it had been sitting in the fridge for too long, it was a bit hard. 

The atmosphere was nice. A nice group of people came and went. And there were computers for paying internet users. A good place to stop by to end the evening.
author: Nana R.

description:
Oooh, who would have thunk it. So this was the first place I ever met my BF to be. I was there to meet him and his friend (my friend) who was doing some web page business stuff with both of us. I think they were only there for it's proximity to alcohol. But the coffee was good if I remember correctly.

I'd only come back out of sentiments sake, and even that is pretty unlikely. I'm sure if I were walking by and really wanted tea or something I would stop in, but other than that, I don't hang out in this part of town very often, and it would take one helluva coffee shop to drag me out here.
author: Allyson S.

description: Blue Danube is the perfect evening coffee shop for the Green Apple lover. It's a good launching point for plans ranging from book browsing at Green Apple to beer quaffing at a local establishment.  Yes, they do serve alcohol, but my favorite feature is the participatory diary (several volumes long now). Blue Danube uses ZRNet. The usual parking warnings about Clement Street apply!
author: Marcus M.

description: average food and drinks but for some reason it takes 20 minutes to make a sandwich? They've messed up on my to go orders both times I have gone in and took about 20 minutes each time.
author: Clara A.

description:
The Danube!!  Where would I be without my morning Chocolate Mint Smoothie (No Oreo Cookies, yo) on the way to the gym???  Halfway down hungry street, that's where.  And it's a dark, lonely path I don't suggest taking.

This is like a café with a full-service menu.  Breakfast, lunch, beer, wine, etc. etc.  The food here is pretty much exactly what I want when I'm recomitted to healthy cuisine every now and then.  Their salads and sandwiches are great.  Mozzarella cheese, tomatoes, mixed greens, chicken breast, foccaccia bread... that kinda thing.  Their smoothies are definitely my favorite part of the menu, but the breakfast ensemble's great if you're walking down Clement in the morning and want something warm and great to start your day without having to jump into the full-on "restaurant" experience.

I will note that my hot chocolate (the measure by which I rate my esteem for all cafés) was pretty bland-ish and failed to leave me wanting more.  Fortunately, I splashed it in the face of some guy walking by, then went back in to order myself a Chocolate Mint Smoothie.  Let's hear a cheer for assaulting strangers!!
author: Philippe N.

description: This place is so cute and cozy! I love coming here for a cup of coffee and a good book to read for a couple hours. The place has a warm feeling with the decor and friendly staff. I have yet to try the food, but I'm sure it is just as great as their coffee drinks =)
author: Lisa B.

description:
I love coming here!!! They play great background music, and when its a nice day they open the big windows in front!! I HIGHLY recommend ALL of their smoothies, they are blended just perfectly! The grilled cheese with aioli is also quite amazing. 

The only reason I didn't give them a full 5 stars is because they don't have free wi-fi!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I had an anchor steam and a tasty (but not amazing) sandwich.  It certainly passes. It also has free internet. That is great!

It is very different from other places on Clement street.  One could do a cultural study on why Asians don't frequent this place like they do all the nearby Dim Sum establishments.

I may try it again when I'm in the area.
author: Aaron W.

description:
Ok...so my sister and I used to walk up and down Clement street ALL the time and we'd always see Blue Danube and it looked so chill and  relaxing. So we tried it and loved it! I love the food, the coffee, the juices...just about everything!

My ONLY gripe...is the customer service. That is a BIG deal to me...so I just felt that the cashiers or whoever happens to be helping at the counter could have a better attitude. 

Other than that...I love the atmosphere...I would definitely go there whenever I'm in the area!
author: L. F.

description:
This has been my favorite coffee joint from my highschool days, and it hasn't lost its original charm since.  The coffee and specialty drinks are always perfectly made.  The food, be it the wraps, crepes, or panini sandwiches, are always fresh and delicious.  The comfortable, inviting decor makes it a great place to people watch, or just to chill on the sofa and read a book.  Speaking of books, make sure to add an entry into the blue danube journal to mark your visit.  

Only reason why I'm not adding  the fifth star is for the lack of free wi-fi.   Other than that, this place is perfect.
author: Jenny H.

description:
with free wifi, this place would get 5 stars.

pros:
-this place is where "cool" people hang out
-the tomato basil soup was awesome. the sandwich was delish as well.
-they were playing zero 7's first album, simple things.


cons:
-no free wifi, 
-limited seating, esp if the weather sucks
-not super fast on the food making, but you can't blame the 2 people working there.
noteable:
there was strange clothing hanging on the wall for sale, $300 bucks for a random jacket-shirt thingy.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Mmm...four words: Proscuito, Brie & Spinach Paninni! 

Working around the area unveils lots of cuisines to choose from...being sick of asian foods, I decided to try something from Blue Danube. Looking for a cheap lunch, I found their Pannini on the menu for just $3. They have 3 different types...but I opted to customize and create my own...which they accommodated wonderfully. It comes on a grilled demi baguette and is sooo delicious! The staff is really nice and makes you want to come back and chit-chat with them. They also have lots of breakfast/lunch items like french toast, salads and sandwiches....I love how they've got a french flair too. I can't wait to go back for more!
author: Jessica h.

description:
This is one of my favorite coffee places, but I hardly ever go as the public transportation between my place and here is crappy and slow...and trying to park around here can take nearly as long as taking the bus.

Regardless, they have ridiculously good Mexican hot chocolate, funky furniture, and where else can you write in the cafe's own journal?  Its always fascinating to see what patrons past have written and drawn.  While many people hang out here waiting for the overrated Burma Superstar (yes, it's good, but it's not salvation on a plate, folks), I prefer to just stay here.

If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd be a regular for sure.
author: Jen D.

description: It boggles my mind that a coffee shop wouldn't offer free wireless internet. It was inconvenient to have to sign up for their pay-for-internet service. The baristas were nice, the coffee was fine but I really recommend they offer free wireless.
author: Sarah K.

description: twas was a cold and foggy night, in the streets of san francisco. it's summer in san francisco, so you know what that means. time for hot chocolate! so i was in the mood for some mexican hot chocolate and friends and i wanted a cool place to chill and chat as well.  it's actually hard to find a cafe that's open late on the weekends. We actually didn't know where to go and after driving around, we found this place.  it's was pretty full but we were able to grab the sofa still. they have food here as well. like cupcakes and other pastries.  they had my mexican hot chocolate and i have to say it was good! we got the cupcakes too and that was pretty good as well.  it's pretty chill here, they even have a little journal book for the customers to write stuff in it. it's a great place to chat and chill with your friends and it's even more fun reading what other ppl write in the journal. this is gonna be my fav. cafe to hang out in.. if only parking was easy...
author: Belinda C.

description: OMG - amazing selection of bakery goods!  Great atmosphere and service.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I can't stand this place.

The carpet reeks of bad things.  The food is absolutely horrible.

It's dirty, the guests are often loud, it's tiny and you are packed in like a sardine, the seats are super uncomfortable...and overall, the place deserves a big hose down.

Avoid!!!

However, not to seem like a total negative jerk, I'm going to add a little note my girlfriend wrote while observing people there.  Here goes:

"At the Blue Danube tonight, December 19th, 2006. 

An adult exhibit of female gazing and the desire for intimacy, was at it's best. It was apparent, however, that at the late hour of 9:37pm, with the cafe closing in just 23 minutes, the gazing, which was being confused for drilling- though perhaps it was her attempt to drill into his core and find the truth of his existence- would not be softening in time for the bridge to be crossed and a comfort, on the part of both, to be achieved. 

At least, not before closing time.
 
Too much psycho,emoto-analytico drilling for this homo-sapien to handoe!"
 
-A witness"
author: Matt O.

description:
Went here to wait for a seat at Burma Superstar, and I inevitably found my newest favorite coffee house.

They give you a lot of quality coffee for your buck, but that's only part of it. The ambiance is just stellar. Makes you just want to bring your favorite mag while sipping that cup of joe.

Maybe I'll go back next weekend just to hang out.
author: Chaz C.

description:
My favorite neighborhood coffee shop.  BD has great sandwiches (I'm not a vegetarian -- but both veggie sandwiches are my favorite)...the coffee is great....the staff are really friendly...and there is always good music playing.  It is a great place to meet a friend for a drink or do some studying...the two things holding BD back are that it feels kinda tight and crowded at times...and there is no free wireless :( (though this does keep me from being distracted while studying...)

Try it!
k, thanks
author: M J.

description: Love the Mexican Hot Chocolate, and love that it's located few blocks away from my work place. Always come here before work to do some reading and have a cup of hot chocolate. The decor is very unique and one-of-a-kind. The only thing I could complain about this place is it gets really crowded sometime. Had the salads, they are really good too.
author: Marlis T.

description: come here all the time cause it's so near, but also because it is great.  I'm not a big coffee drinker, but their other options (mexican hot chocolate, mixed juices and smoothies) are great.  Nice, comfy area to hang out.  When it's nice outside they open the windows and have a good seating area outdoors.  Just a great place to be.  Almost subtracted a star because they are cash only, but thought better of it.
author: Phil J.

description:
aka "The place you go to wait for your table at Burma Superstar," Blue Danube is a comfy and tasty treat. Moderately priced wines, beers and sangria complement the Mighty Leaf tea and Mr. Espresso coffee selection. 

They've also got a full menu of salads and sandwiches but warning, their basics are a bit on the pricey side - eg breakfast bagel $5.95+
author: hunter w.

description:
Atmosphere: 4.5
Food/Drink: 4
service: 3

Cool, indie feel. But paying for internet? Eh, not so cool. I'd rather drink my coffee and watch the guy with the faux-hawk look up his fantasy football stats totally trying to make eye contact with any girl who has eyes. Nice relaxed feel though.

i drink americanos. It's espresso + hot water. pretty hard to f that up.

I have persoanlly been overcharged for a couple americanos. First you write it off, then you realize a trend. But it's not consistent so you're not sure what to think...!
author: Miss C.

description:
One of the craziest things happened to me in this cafe.  

I go there often, but will never forget this one time:

Early one Saturday morning a while back, a girlfriend and I are groggily waiting in line (those of you who have been here know that it is tight quarters and the register is right at the end of the hallway to the restroom).  Well, I guess I was in the way of an older (crazy) woman returning from the restroom, I realized this when she shoulder checked me.  Remember, it is early, I am sleepy, that is why I am in line for coffee!  I said "jeez," kind of joking, and the lady takes about five steps, where she is smack in the middle of the place and turns around and screams, "WELL, NEXT TIME YOU SHOULDN'T STAND IN THE WAY, STUPID BITCH!"  Then she left, and I was standing there dumbfounded.  I wish I could have said something.  It was just nuts, and the place was packed.  

I still love the blue danube anyway.  Crazy people or no crazy people, I like to go and have a pot of tea and their greek yogurt and do other people's unfinished crosswords.
author: Stacey d.

description:
I've been once and totally loved the sandwich I got. Also loved the selection although I didn't order more. I should have.

I don't drink any variation of coffee or alchol so I can't really judge that. But from what I had... yuummmmm delicious.

Smelled a little weird and when I went in it was a pretty nice day, so the big windows and door were open, had a couple of flies inside which I actually hate. Oh well.

Would totally recommend and go again
author: Sydney T.

description:
5 Stars! For a coffee house/cafe this is a damn good place. I am sold. Perfect for me as this is something that I can go to often as its in my hood. One of the many reasons why I love San Francisco. : ) 
So, I had the Bananarama Smoothie as suggested on here and the Breakfast Bagel. Both are something that I would get again and again. Did not expect this place to be as good as it was, since it being a coffee house. Besides the food and drinks the atmosphere is cozy and makes you feel like you can hang out (of course I came in when it wasn't crowded Sun. @ 11am approx.). Another cool thing is they have Journals that people have written in and its nice to check out and add your own mark on Blue Danube history. This is perfect for someone living in the Inner Richmond or wanting to try something new.
author: Ben L.

description:
I like this place.  Some times the atmosphere is just right and you could really sit a spell. When it's not very busy, personable people behind the counter (you can tell they chose the music), and customers are all chill reading, cross-wording or chit-chatting.  It's great.
Rarely, though it does occur, at other times one must endure standing in line for a quite a while to order, followed by sounds of crying babies as their mothers eat salad ignoring them while you not so patiently wait for your lunch or breakfast which you then ordered "to go" because there's no where to sit at all and it ends up taking twenty minutes.  

DO NOT GO HERE JUST FOR COFFEE.  It's really not that good.  Seriously, it's "Mr. Espresso", check it out.
on the flip, the TEA SELECTION IS PRETTY AWESOME.
and do go here if you want exceptional café food.  salads, sandwiches, breakfast stuff.  I like the roasted veggie w/ feta sandwich.  All the sammies come w/ mixed greens salad and might cost between six and eight bucks. The breakfast bagel is so good that I would give five stars just based on that, but a solid four for everything else.
author: Natalie B.

description:
Always a great place for good coffee day or night if you are in the area.   Grap your newspaper, order a tasty sangwich and enjoy. Feels like a college cafe.  

PS-I saw Reinhold Neibhur there having coffee reading the paper.  So weird.
author: Jon K.

description:
lived down the street for a while and have always been a fan of this spot. usually i take my coffee and leave which leaves little room for annoyances but from what i have gathered the place can get a bit crowded. consider it a very cozy place. the confines arent huge but they for sure make the best with what they've got. comfortable seating both indoors and outdoors and even when its packed its usually still pretty quiet. 

they serve all sorts of coffee's and snacks as well as mimosas and bloody mary's all day, they even have a small beer selection too. the staff have always been very friendly and it is no suprise that this place has been running 18 years strong. this is the best coffee house on clement (in my own humble opinion)
author: Andrew D.

description: Watch for the fee-charged WiFi.  It is offered by "HR-net" and will post a "seciurity check" screen on every URL you will try, when you use a Kindle Fire eBook like mine. I don't know if it happens on a Mac or PC, but if you have a Nook or a Kindle, beware.  You will pay for degraded service.  Better walk 4 blocks to a Peet's coffee and tea, where you also pay, or better yet, Starbucks where WiFi is free.
author: John K.

description: the vietnamese iced coffee was a mug of sugary deliciousness, a perfect accompaniment to a breakfast bagel and a good book.
author: Amelia B.

description: Great place to meet a small group or friend for coffee. They recently added Vietnamese coffee to their list of drinks (awesome). They also have mimosas, sangria and baked goods. If you have a motorcycle or bus it's simple, car parking can be a PITA.
author: Corvus C.

description: Went two days ago to do some work. Ordered a coffee and a bagel. The bagel was pathetic, but the coffee was good. The food being served around me looked good. Saw a few sexy sandwiches distributed. The atmosphere was pretty chill and the staff was incredibly nice. Thought I got some good work done, but it turned out to be shit. I blame the bagel. Though, I blame most my problems on bagels.
author: Aaron Z.

description: Got the mexican hot coco and cookie dipped with chocolate and white chocolate while waiting for the crappy restaurant across the strip (Burma Superstar). They were both good!! And not too pricey.
author: Em F.

description: perfect coffee place to stumble to after incurring food coma at Burma Superstar. Oh yeah, nice outdoor seating and coffee too!
author: Jan Michael K.

description:
Went there on a Sunday morning to have some breakfast and read the paper.

I really like the openess of the place when the weather is warm.

The food and coffee were pretty good.

What I really didn't like was how dirty the place was and how unfriendly the guy who helped me was.  I felt like he totally didn't want to be there and I was putting him out by ordering something.  Then I saw some other customers who were being helped by a really nice guy....maybe I'll go back and try to get him to help me instead.
author: Luci B.

description: *Update* they are not owned by burma superstar, That was a big wrong presumption on my part. Still amazing, great salads, fun atmosphere.
author: Amanda T.

description: Ive been going here for years and it never fails to satisfy. The iced passion fruit unsweetened tea is my usual suspect. I have not tried the food but I hear its great and they have a large menu. There is outdoor seating and indoor comfy couches. Also be sure to try the bananarama smoothie. It is excellent!! It has soymilk, bananas, honey , and cinnamon. So good!
author: M K.

description:
I used to come here all the time to "concentrate" and "study".  I did get a lot done...it just took me a bit longer because I was often distracted by the interesting artwork hanging on the walls and cute babies cooing at me, sitting at the next table over.  It was also a relaxing and chill spot with great music and nice people, which created a great place to sit and people watch.  
I think over the years, it got super popular and I can see why.  Nowadays, I don't have anything to study, but I still love coming here.  I don't necessarily love the coffee but their food is wonderful.  For a cafe, it does take a bit long to get your order, but it's worth the wait.  Oh yeah.  Bring cash.
A favorite Sunday brunch is dish is the french toast with cream cheese and fresh fruit.  Add a side of bacon and I'm in Sunday heaven!  Another favorite is the BLAT sandwich for lunch...it's perfectly toasted with a lightly dressed side salad.   Also try their smoothies!  Refreshing and absolutely tasty!    I love bringing friends here and surprising them with the great food.  Definitely a gem in the Richmond district...
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I. Love. The. Blue. Danube. 

Sigh... I wish I was there right now writing this review. Though it's a little small, it definitely falls into the cozy category. And what better way to meet new people than in a cozy warm atmosphere? It's got indoor seating and a couple tables outside - and the windows open to make the window seats feel like you're outside anyway. 

Coffee? Good. Beer? Good. Food? Haven't had it but it looks/smells delish. 

I think I'll be going every Sunday before my skeeball games at Buckshot. If only I lived closer.
author: Susan P.

description:
I found Blue Danube by accident and was surprised by their menu. The menu included salads, bagels, sandwiches, coffee drinks, smoothies, AND alcoholic beverages (sangria, mimosa, screwdriver, bloody mary, and greyhound). 

I ordered a latte and 1/2 sandwich/salad combo (Turkey sandwich with mixed greens). Wow. For only $6.95, I received a lot of food. The 'half' sandwich was a generous portion. The salad was a HEAPING pile of greens. No complaints though, because I LOVE veggies. The food tasted fresh, healthy, and delicious. I really enjoyed the turkey sandwich, because it wasn't low-quality turkey cold-cut. They gave me turkey meat with texture with the taste of turkey. yay. The latte wasn't bad; it was merely okay. The flavor and aroma wasn't that strong and it had a weird water-downed taste. I'm not sure how else to explain it.... 

Would I come back again?

Most def.
author: S. H.

description:
Pretty good coffee, but food takes a loooooooong time.

Cash only, which can be a kick in the balls at times.
author: Andrew T.

description:
awesome vibe and i like the photography on the walls. 

i thought i was going to fall in love with the french toast that everybody says is so amazing. everything was fine with it except for the creamcheese. i thought that the richness would make it an exceptional french toast but i actually ended up scraping it off.
author: Regina C.

description: Quaint and lovely place. Wonderful sandwiches and wraps and sangria to die for!
author: Shoshana S.

description: We had our rehearsal dinner here and the owners are wonderful--helpful in every regard. One of the highlights for our out of town guests who got to see & taste one of the Inner Richmond's gems.
author: J M.

description:
I've only been in for coffee or a drink before dinner, and I have to say the Sangria is the best I've had in a long time. Good selection of teas and sweets, too. I've overheard that the sandwiches are great but I can't comment on that -- review is based on drinks only!

One small downside is that it can get a little crowded around dinner time with folks waiting for tables across the street at Burma Superstar.
author: J C.

description:
Can be a touch pricey, but or ambiance, the incredible random writing/art journals from the last however many years and the delicious food, this place is worth the time (several times per week).

Also the owner is an awesome, awesome dude.
author: Jack H.

description: I won't be going back. Saturday morning, place is packed. Order coffee and ham/swiss/egg croissant and a pre-made quiche . The fellow working behind the counter sneers when I try to pay with a card (sign says cash only, my mistake, I pay with cash instead). Get coffee about 5 minutes after order, my girl thinks her mocha (ordered extra hot) is cold. People who ordered after us get served before we do, we get our food after about 15 minutes. My quiche is lukewarm, having either been sitting or not heated long enough. Why the wait, why the bratty service, why the cold drinks and food? Good news is that with the all the competition, this place will be gone soon enough...
author: Colin J.

description: Cute & quaint little coffee house where you can sit & relax. They offer a full menu of food from sandwiches to desserts to cheese plates! A varietal crowd from those catching up w/friends to those needing to study. We ordered a mocha & chai latte - both very good! I wanted something to nibble on before dinner and tried to chocolate chunk cookie - a little too sweet for my taste but I'm a big fan of the crunch. Barista was very nice and helpful :)
author: Cheryl P.

description:
Had some time to kill before Yoga so I wanted something to eat that wouldn't weigh me down.  

A cup of the Chicken Noodle Soup and some yummy Vanilla Black tea hit the spot, and for under $7!  

Nice and homey atmosphere though smoke comes in from the smokers on the patio due to the large open windows.
author: Jennifer H.

description: It was pretty quiet on a weekday morning before 8am.  The decor was cozy and charming but if it were crowded, I could see it being pretty cramped.  The coffee was good and it was a comfortable spot to perk up and have a too brief conversation before heading to work.   Quiet and comfortable are good sometimes.
author: Seong P.

description: Funky, clunky, slightly junky, Blue Danube is a nearly ideal study cafe. The palpable tininess of the space keeps your fellow patrons from getting screechy, and the fact that the cafe has no free Wi-Fi means that us poor internet-addicted souls can actually get some work done. The coffee, while nothing special, accomplishes its purpose. The few times I've sampled their food, it's been good enough to keep me from having to go eat pho across the street, which has been conducive to powering through more chapters.  The main draws are the cozy vibe, the sane patrons, and the absence of distractions. It is the anti-Starbucks.
author: Clay S.

description: I stumbled upon this place while waiting for Burma SuperStar to open. I thought it was just a basic coffee shop, but to my pleasant surprise they had an incredible selection of drinks and food. Very cute vibe. I was a little disappointed in my sangria so I am docking a star but it seems like a solid cafe option and the perfect place to sit while keeping an eye on the line at Burma SuperStar. If I lived closer, this place would be in my regular weekend rotation!
author: Priya N.

description: ...this palce is not a franchise...it's more like visting an old friend. Staff is very friendly and decore is that of a classic, old fashion coffe shop.
author: Amy F.

description: The first coffeehouse where I felt at home after moving to San Francisco.  It is small, but cozy and inviting.  The owners are friendly and doing a great job of running the place.  The hand-painted tables are intriguing.  The food is basic, but good.  My favorite is the ham and cheese croissant sandwich.  The coffee is good -- they use Mr. Espresso coffee out of Oakland.  For evening visits they also have beer and wine.  It remains my favorite Richmond district cafe.
author: Bob H.

description:
one star for the extensive food & drink menus - definitely give their mint mocha a try

plus one star for the big, wonderful windows in front that they open up on warm days

plus one star for the comfy couches and hand-painted tables

plus two stars for the blue danube journals!  they provide hours of entertainment, reading the inane or not-so-inane ramblings of strangers, leaving inane ramblings of your own.  the best is if you go there with a friend and you play the two-sentence game - you formulate a ridiculous story two sentences each at a time.  when i first moved to san francisco i used to come to the blue danube with my then-boyfriend who lived in the neighborhood.  so now i can look up the lame crap i wrote in journal #2 (they're on journal #20 now) 4.5 years ago and have a good laugh at my expense while sipping a fine cup of tea...
author: genevieve g.

description: Yet another cozy neighborhood coffee shop with couches and internet access; however, this one has a remarkable apricot bar, which in my book, gives it an extra star.  Clement Street is actually one of the little-known gems of San Francisco.  Not too popular yet, but there are so many good restaurants, bars and shops down here.
author: Rick H.

description: I love going to the Blue Danube on a Saturday morning and sitting at one of their tables that are outside and enjoying a cup of their awesome coffee.  I'm very picky with my coffee, and I like to drink it black (I know crazy, but I use to work at a coffee shop that will remain nameless and we had to do tastings all the time).  I like the fact that they have huge windows that they leave open, so even if you sit inside you get a nice breeze and don't feel like you are in a stuffy room.  It is always crowded, so if you like to people watch, this is great place.  Also they serve beer!  Now that just makes this coffee shop even better.
author: Sarah M.

description: Definitely love this coffee shop! My favorite to be exact!!! It's small, warm and cozy...and their coffee is the best!!!
author: Juli S.

description: Quaint and unassuming. My most favorite coffee house in the city. The owner is a doll and the food is yummy. If you get there early enough you might get a seat on one of the comfy sofas.
author: jodi v.

description: Oh-so-good sandwiches, fresh juices, free wireless and notebooks lying around to write random stuff in.  A great place to spend the day alone or with friends, probably why there are never any free tables.
author: Lindsey W.

description: When I was in college I went to Blue Danube Coffee House to study. I would haul my laptop and assorted books and head there to have a snack. The aroma of coffee and the noise of low level conversations was a welcome change of atmosphere from the dead-quiet of a library or the distraction filled space of my home. The folks at Blue Danube make good food which can sustain you through a long study session. It's a comfortable neighborhood cafe with a casual feel of your own living room.
author: Jessica D.

description: Great atmosphere!  Nice first tea/coffee date place if it's crowded and happening... otherwise you feel like you're in a fishbowl.  *glub glub*
author: Rashmi N.

description: Great atmosphere, good food, and decent prices. I only wish they took credit cards.
author: Daneen A.

description:
YUM.

I recently discovered this place.

I think this little place is adorable. The journal thing is genius--I love sitting on a cozy couch, flipping through one of the Danube's journals--notebooks you can write and draw in. I come in here from time to time and enjoy a coffee and flip through the journals, reading people's poems, comic strips, etc.

Definately check out their bagels with melted cheese. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

The Blue Danube was definately an unexpected surprise. There isn't much surrounding it, but going here simply for the Blue Danube is reason enough to go.
author: Nicole R.

description: Banana-rama smoothie...get outta here!!! And the Hulk smoothie, yum! Haven't been in a few months since i moved out of the richmond, but have been dreaming of one of their smoothies for a while now. This place makes some seriously good concoctions. Juices are great, smoothies are amazing, and coffee is excellent.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: I like it.  Espresso was good, not great, but certainly worthy of serving.  Place is a bit small but really well done.  Great home-made, welcoming vibe to the whole place.  Just what you want in an SF coffeehouse.
author: John D.

description: This cute coffee house is not only a really attractive place to stop and read a book but has healthy alternatives, like juices, teas and smoothies. They also have some fragrant delish coffee and some great looking desserts. We went last night to see Tranny Bear and Trout play (kind of a performance art band) and art show. My husband and I really enjoyed looking at and discussing the art, which had both Asian and Media influences. I would say the pieces on display were vibrant and playful. If you have a chance stop by and check them out. The band was great, it was a very interactive performance and the crowd loved it. Something about a band in costume and singing full throttle guarantees a good time. Reminded me of the good old college days and Luna's in Sacto. Anyway it's a great place and I would totally go there again and the owner is awesome to provide this venue to local artists and the hungry public.
author: Tiffany T.

description: Blue Danube is what independent coffeeshops in San Francisco are all about: quality and character. I love the painted tables inscribed with poetry, the chandeliers, the big ornate mirror, and the decorative branches arching across the center of the shop. One point off because while the coffee is good, it's not great. Best to visit on cool days because the interior of the store fills with smoke from the outdoor seating whenever the windows are open.
author: Karin T.

description: I love this cafe! I just came back form eating there today & I'm trying to figure out why I don't eat there more often. I'm not really a big coffee person but I have had their peppermint mocha & their Vietnamese coffee & they are good. But what I really come here for are their sandwiches. I crave their Rosemary chicken sandwich on foccaia with grilled onions, my mouth is watering jus thinking about it...mmmmm. & the side salad they give on the side is sooo good. Super simple and uber tasty. I wonder what kind of vinagrette they use, I have to find out. The decor is very eclectic & cozy. I like looking at all the different wall hangings as I eat my yummy sandwich. They also have live music some nights, I need to remember to stop by & check that out.
author: Maritess N.

description:
i spent a lot of time here whilst studying for the LSAT. i do quite enjoy the ambiance and occasionally enjoy the music. i like that they serve beer and wine, although i have yet to partake of this offering, and the food i tried was pretty tasty. the staff are also extremely friendly and welcoming, especially to someone who would sit there for 4 hours buying nothing but a pot of tea. 

a few qualms: the tables are too small. it was difficult to maneuver my 25 test prep books and notebook and an iPod and a pot of tea and how anyone manages to work on a laptop on one of those tiny things is beyond me. second, their prices are really a little steep and this is the richmond so we know that rent is not an excuse. none of their food is under $5 and coffee is $2! this place i went to in the mission had the same stuff for half the price. $7.95 for a salad at a little coffee shop in the rich is just too much to me. perhaps the frequency with which i visited this place has something to do with my being bitter about the prices...

anyways, still a cute place to hang out and read and study and wait in from the fog for a glass of wine while in line for burma superstar.
author: Rachael S.

description: this place rocks!  The atmosphere is great and the people who work there are real nice.  They have a great selection of drinks, from beer to smoothies, and there sandwhiches are off the hook.  definately check this place out for some morning coffee and a breakfast croissant.
author: Paul Michael A.

description:
everytime Ive gotten cappuccinos here are pretty decent, plus they dont look at me like im a crazy nut when i get 3hsots in a small cup. 
baaah no biggie. plus i enjoy watching people letting go (feet-up, blankets, really who cares) and relax in a non-snobby coffee house, one of the fewest. for that they get an extra star.

BEANS: L'appert's coffee / Mr. espresso
author: ninja M.

description: Everything I've had there is delicious. My friend got me hooked on their Bananarama shakes, so props to him. I also dig the toasted rice tea and the outdoor seating. Blue Danube is essential to the neighborhood. Richmond District represent!
author: Vanessa N.

description:
May I please have an attitude smoothie with a side order of sarcasm and a cup of indier-than-thou-ness, please? $400? Great.

That's what you get when you go to this place. Twice, now, the hipsters behind the counter have taken out their issues out on my out-of-town guests. First, one friend asked what kind of fruit juices they had, and the short-haired brunette smirked as she rolled her eyes, "Honey, there's a whole LIST behind you." Why didn't she say, "You can check out the menu behind you and I recommend the watermelon-strawberry"? Why is that so hard?

The second incident was this weekend when my sister-in-law stood at what she thought was the beginning of the line, because they have a long counter and no sign as to where to stand. Turns out she was standing in the area where you can wait for your food after ordering; we weren't there so we couldn't tell her, but I can totally see how it is confusing. The food preparer behind the counter asked if she'd been helped and like any normal person, she said, no, but can I have X and Y? The blonde behind the register then turned to her and said, condescendingly, "This OTHER customer was before YOU. Next time, the line is over HERE." Not, "Sorry, would you mind waiting until after I help this customer? The line is actually over here." See? Not hard. Well, the customer is always right and so my sister-in-law walked out while they were making her order to give her money to some people with manners.

I don't care that what I have ordered there has been fine. If those people are too cool for my friends and family, then they're too cool for me and my cash. And oh yeah, they don't take credit card.
author: Deb T.

description: Damn near the best cup of chai in town. I love to go to Clement to hit up my Wamu account and buy lots of housewares on the cheap while sipping my hot cup of deliciousness. The service is chill (read: aloof) and they have  decent breakfast foods.
author: Colleen B.

description: Great place to start the day with a fresh squeezed juice! I particularly like making my own combos: sometimes grapefruit, apple, & celery or carrot, apple & ginger. Lox bagel is great here as well. The bohemian philanthroscopic environment was quite welcoming too.
author: Brittany T.

description: Nice, mellow coffee house in the Richmond. A friend and I were in the neighborhood and stopped in to take a break. The fresh juice combinations were good, the coffee was better than any strabucks and the prices very reasonable. They had computer areas, sofa's to lounge on, and a really casual and neighborhood vibe. If I'm ever out in that area again, I would definately stop by.
author: Jason D.

description: This is one of my favorite places to hang out and read a book, write letters or grade my student's papers.  It has a great homey ambiance and friendly folks behind the counter.  On a warm evening (which are rare) it is a nice place to sit and have a beer or some of their tasty sangria.
author: shawn l.

description: LOVE this place...my b.f and I have date night here on Fridays or Saturdays night....stop at Green Apple books, get a coffee or tea...we bring backgammon (dorks!) and just hang...mellow place, not too loud...and I like their cool community journal...it is kept at the front...anyone and everyone writes in it... super cute. :)
author: Bing B.

description: My wife and I were at Blue Danube two weeks ago and we thoroughly enjoyed our visit. It was a wet, rainy, Sunday afternoon in the city - perfect coffee drinking weather. The café is small, some might say too small, but it makes up for its lack of space with good old fashioned bohemian ambiance. There were lots of people there: students, artists, suits, etc. It's nice to see a diverse crowd at a coffeehouse - I think it adds a little character to the establishment. They have a fine coffee/ tea menu and a pretty extensive food menu for a coffeehouse. The Mexican hot chocolate that I had was delicious and my wife certainly enjoyed her Chai tea. We also tried their Brie and apple plate and it was very tasty; The veggie sandwich that we tried was also very good. Over all, I would recommend Blue Danube - good atmosphere, good coffee, good food, friendly staff. I would have given it 5 stars if it weren't for the fact that you have to pay to use the internet. Come on guys, put in free Wi-Fi and free up those two spaces for more customers.  Oh, and in regards to parking - don't forget, you are in San Francisco.
author: Salvador C.

description: Oh my god, the coffee here is terrible. Ordered an iced coffee today that tasted like piss, and I really hope that it was just bad coffee. I come here every once in a while after a Green Apple run. They have a bathroom (often with a line) and some outdoor seating--both good things. Also, I think the vibe is pretty relaxed and the lighting is good. Wish the coffee was better. Cash only.
author: Anna F.

description: I love Blue Danube, it is both quaint and comfortable.  I absolutely love the veggie sandwich and I am not even a vergetarian.  Their Chai latte could improve, but other than that this place is great,
author: Rachel R.

description: My local cozy coffee joint.  This is a great spot on a lovely day to just while away some time, next to the open windows and do some people watching.  They make decent meals too - probably one of the only spots on the street where you can get a salad for lunch.  And they make a fantastic grilled cheese sandwich with tomatoes.  Get that with a glass of red wine, and you're set!  The fruit smoothies are quite tasty as well.  They occasionally have a guy in to play guitar at nights, and it really adds up to some nice, warm and cozy ambiance.
author: Nadine T.

description: This is my ultimate weekend coffee and eggs fix.  First of all, the vibe is one of the kindest in the city: the people will actually have a real conversation.  There is a lot of in and out traffic, so the feel is dynamic.  The staff is friendly.  The late is superb.  Go for the California Wrap (salmon, eggs, creme cheese, capers in a flour tortilla) or the Breakfast Bagel (decadent with bacon, eggs, and cheddar).  The smoothies are also creative (try the Funky Monkey with peanut butter).
author: Paul M.

description: Fair variety (and quality) of food and beverages. The atmosphere is great, but I probably wouldn't recommend it as a quiet coffee house (unless you're there close to closing) - it's definitely more of a "hang out" place from what I've seen. The paid Wi-Fi is kind of a bummer, and I'd probably be here much more often if they offered free access. It's also a pretty tiny place, and even though they've done what they can to maximize seating room, it's best for smaller groups, couples, and individuals. Still, a cozy stop, especially for Inner Richmond. Fantastic cupcakes. Be warned, it's cash only!
author: Sam S.

description: This place is always crowded with people.  It's really hard to find a seat because the cafe is not big in size and usually people just hang out all day at this place!  It's got a funky, slightly bohemian vibe and the couch section usually has some good gossip going on!  The food is fresh and I love their Mexican hot chocolate!  Try to sit at the couch section if you've got a group of friends, otherwise it's hard to find a spot.
author: Daria i.

description: I love this coffee house! I wish some of the tables were bigger, but I came here to study and get my beverage on, and it was pretty nice. I liked their choice of music, the bathroom was clean, sometimes it gets noisy in there, but overall, i liked it. I haven't tried any actual food there, but the coffee is good. I also tried connecting to their wi-fi on my phone, but it said I have to watch an advertisement every 15 minutes. Eh, I just stuck with my Tmobile Edge access then.
author: Wendy L.

description: Best latte I've had in a while.  Great little vibe in this place too, and friendly service!
author: Erica G.

description: Simple good breakfast-- great Chai Tea and decent French toast with berries and almonds! Gets busy around 10-ish am on weekends. Hippie style deco matches its relaxed, earthy tone clothed patrons.
author: T L.

description: If I am in the area and fancy and cup of coffee and Peets is no where to be seen I'd come here. I remembered coming here for breakfast or brunch.  The food comes fast which is good and it's yummy so it's even better.  It's a small place and always crowded but we usually get our seats if we want to.  The turnover is high.  One thing, people around me are constantly checking each other out so I don't really feel comfortable in that sense.... The cappuccino is huge and I love it :)
author: Bella A.

description:
this is definitely the coffee shop that all other coffee shops aspire to be.  the food here is unique and excellent.  the french toast and the morning egg wraps are incredible.  they juice fresh vegetable and fruit juices - try the carrot/apple or the pineapple/grapefruit.  they blend fresh smoothies - try the hulk.  although an unappetizing green, it's mostly mango and banana so it's very tastey. the coffee is stellar.  the teas can come in tea bags or the premium teas come loose-leaf in their own pot. 

they also have a wine and beer license so you can have a beer or a glass of wine if you're looking for a nightcap.  the furniture is comfortable and funky.  the ambiance is pretty friendly.  parking of course, is horrendous.  but there's nothing better than a weekend afternoon at blue danube.  the staff is mostly super-friendly and cool.  except of course for that one red-head that seems to have a grudge against life.  but what would a coffeeshop be without one nihilist, disgruntled staff member? :)

bonus: there's a few outdoor tables so if it's good weather than you can get a tan while scanning through the newspaper.  there really isn't much else you can ask from a coffee shop.
author: dan h.

description: I just had a fall kind of experience at this little cozy coffee shop.  Ordered a hot apple cider with pumpkin bread to go with the September cool temp, foggy type of night in the city.  The drink was great and the pastry was decent.  I have no complaints!  The location is ideal and attracts people who love coffee houses.  Oh and may I add the staff are friendly!!
author: Kristina A.

description: This seems like the place to be on Sunday afternoons because everytime i come here its always super packed. But the setup of the place is nice. It has these big windows that open up to get some of that nice sf city air. They have these little books that go waaay back where people write poems, drawings, thoughts on their mind or whatever else you can imagine. It really is pretty interesting. It is a coffee shop but strangely enough ive never had their coffee. However their food menu is really good. I highly recommend the tuna sandwich. Im not quite sure what they do to it but that is the best tuna sandwich ive ever had. The shakes and smoothies are also really good. But yes, this place truly does feel like an independant coffee shop, they even have music and spoken word on some nights. Anytime im near ocean beach i always make a point to come here and the little crepe place next door.
author: Mark L.

description: the juices are tasty, the coffee and food is good enough to come back for, if you are having a leisurely break, and don't plan to get some work done while having coffee. Charging $1/hour for internet, really?? Then you connect to their internet provider, and find out that you could have bought an entire day for $4..., and get served some advertising on top of the money you just paid. not cool. and a bit pretentious too.
author: Adelie P.

description: Met a fellow craigslister here for some board games.  I was surprised and amazed at how many journals they got going there. I started one at a cafe in So. Cal and it was eventually stolen. Here they've got 15 volumes or something crazy like that.  Plus they had Telemundo going on silent, then some latin rock/pop in the background. They serve alcohol and caffeine, not sure which one you might need for meeting a new board gamer.
author: Anna O.

description: I'm surprised I haven't yet written a review for this place, considering it's been my main haunt for about a year now.  I have yet to find a sandwich in the city as delicious as the Blue Danube's rosemary chicken.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it.  The service has always been good here and the food is always delicious.  The atmosphere is perfect for a cafe and the journals left out for customers to write in provide hours of entertainment.  Even as I'm writing this review, I feel a little like I shouldn't publish it, because the Blue Danube is crowded enough and I want to keep it to myself...
author: ashley w.

description:
Wait, there's other coffee houses in this city?  Well there might as well not be.  Or, if there are, you might as well not go.  This is the place to be.  Great, quality food in a nice chill atmosphere.  My recommendations for breakfast are the french toast, or granola for the healthier option.  For lunch/dinner all of the sandwiches are excellent.  The BLAT (Bacon, lettuce, avocado, tomato) and the roast beef are my favorites.  For snack the hummus is excellent and the bananarama beats any smoothie at jamba juice.  
Enjoy...
author: darren o.

description: I live four blocks away, so I'm always here. I love Blue Danube immensely. Coffee + an Oreo = love. (Also, pear cider? Way yum.) My two main complaints are, one, I hate the Burma Superstar people who come wandering in at night to stand blinking at the menu and messing up the general vibe, and two, on weekends it's far, far too crowded. I guess that's just because everyone else likes this place too. I can't fault them that, I guess.
author: M J.

description: Only ever been here waiting for the good ol' Burma Superstar. They have cheap beer. Yeah, that's all I got. They have cheap beer.
author: Michael E.

description:
Before I moved to San Francisco, I lived in Atlanta..... the heart of the South, where coffee means Starbucks and neighborhood means "a bunch of houses that look exactly alike with a grocery store and bank nearby (but still not close enough to walk)".   
When I was back in Atlanta dreaming of moving here to SF, the Danube is the type of place I pictured myself hanging out in on sunny mornings, sipping a latte or chai, working on my laptop.  
The reality now that I'm here?  The Danube is pretty comfy & warm, with a handwritten chalk board menu, and your typical coffee house fare... it isn't exactly the haven I had imagined, but it's still pretty great.  The down side is that you can find these places around every corner, the generic mismatched furniture, crammed seating, chalkboard menu, almost stale pastries, and so-so coffee.  
What makes this place better than any of the others?  Nothing really, but it's really close to my house, and I can count on it.  It's a true neighborhood joint, and I appreciate that.  
1 star off for the $5 internet....that, and they always run out of cards to give you, so sometimes there is no internet at all.  Boo!

All in all, a comfy neighborhood coffee house that's great when you need a quick bite to eat or a change of venue if you work at home.  I guess I just wish it was everything I was dreaming of when I lived back in Atlanta... but hey - at least it isn't Starbucks, and we don't live in track housing!!!!!
author: Stacy S.

description: The Breakfast Croissant is good but $3.75 for a 12oz OJ that sucks.  They are slow and don't accept credit card plus everyone that works there has this daze on their faces like they just shot up some black tar H bombs.
author: Steven S.

description:
I absoutely hate to do this. For two years I used to go to the Blue Danube at least twice a day. I met up with friends and we became regulars. It was nice getting coffee from someone that didn't have to write your name on a paper cup. There are no college memories that don't have some remembrance of the Blue Danube. If my friends were on Clement they'd actually expect to see me there, and if someone was looking for me they'd sometimes stop by the danube as the first place to look.

Why I don't go anymore? They hired new people. One of which when I had asked her if she could turn on the heat lamp outside told me to "put on a jacket" if I was cold. I laughed thinking she was joking- she wasn't. Again and again the vibe from the workers weren't like old times and the regulars were becoming not so regular and eventually I was the newbie.
author: Samantha F.

description: oh how i love the blue danube! i'll be honest, i used to think of it as a good study place, but it's a little too busy and noisy for studying.  I might just be the type to get distracted very easily, but i usually spend more time people-watching then studying.  plus, the tiny tables that barely fit a textbook are sometimes the only tables you can snag when it gets really busy.  They do have good coffee and the few times i got food, i was pretty satisfied. it's definitely got a good vibe, the art there is always fun to look at, and very good people watching.
author: Margit H.

description: I totally heart Blue Danube!  I used to live in the neighborhood and It still feels so comfy to me on the rare occasion Im in the area and get to stop by. I'm not a coffee drinker, so I can't comment on the delicate intricacies of blends and aromas...lol. I can say that what makes a coffee house is the people who work there and set the mood... There are no friendlier folks than at the Danube, and Jimmy, the owner is always a treat for the eyes too with the best smile around. :) They have a nice variety of snacks, salads, and I love the egg wraps and smoothies.
author: Sylvie S.

description: When you can find a seat, Blue Danube is a great place to have a bite and read a paper. If only it were a little bigger!
author: Nathalie L.

description:
One of last months Weekly Yelps mentioned the Blue Danube and how delicious their Mexican Hot Chocolate was...... right when I read that issue I knew I had to try it. 

My grandparents live on Clement and we were visiting last weekend so it was the perfect time to check it out. Funny thing was that I mentioned the place to my Mom and she said that when she was younger that was the cool hangout stop where friends would gather and chat. When we visited it was just that. The cafe is cute, over stuffed with tables, chairs, and a couch. The night I went it was freezing outside and stepping inside was a welcoming warmth which made me want my hot chocolate right away. I ordered at the counter it was $3.25 and then sat down to wait. When i was finally served, holy by golly wow, the thing was huge, about the size of half my head. The cup though big was a perfect hug mug. The first sips were the best with the mixture of foaminess and melted marshmallow that accented the cinnamon and nutmeg in the chocolate. Lipsmackin good and perfect for a winters day. This is no chocolate pouch with water, the drink is made of real chocolate melted by steamed milk with dashes of spice that really makes the drink special. 

My bf is a big fan of Mexhotchoc and I can't wait to take him here!
author: Nicole L.

description: It so nice  to find a real "old fashion" coffie shop. Lots of art on the walls, friendly staff and a nice menu...oh. oh....and the owners and staff are really great. This is not a franchise....thank you Blue Danube.
author: carol c.

description: I've had the same rosemary chicken sandwich on 4 visits already.  However, I've tried 2 different smoothies...this place is so good for lunch!
author: Jeff H.

description: I guess it's fair to say Danube's your typical coffee joint serving breakfast, salads, and sandwiches.  I ordered the cobb salad, which was surprisingly good and filling, while JM ordered the B.L.A.T sandwich.  There's really nothing special about this place, I will wander somewhere else next time I'm taking a stroll down Clement.
author: Scott G.

description: Ditto Rachel M's review (too lazy to repeat the points).  Would also add that paid wi-fi is a bit of an anachronism these days -- kind of a cheap move by the owners.  Overall, a very cool hangout.
author: Ari M.

description: this place has the best cobb salad ever. seriously.  i used to live right around the corner and it was my go to meal.  i loved it so much i never once ordered anything else.  oh how i miss thee, cobb salad.mmmm.
author: Shelley B.

description: Local color and local flavor. My favorite place to hang out doing my favorite activity on my days off: sitting with my hubby, sipping coffee, eating a panini with a  side salad and vegan cookie chaser, while doing a crossword and people watching. This place could be a institution. The food is good and prices are reasonable and the owners are pretty cool. I've brought friends here, most remember the food and cool music and the cozy atmosphere. The Blue Danube is one of my standbys and probably will always be.
author: cora j.

description: The drinks and food are fine. The setting is cozy - a nice change from Mission coffee shops, where they're either trendy and cold or not that great at coffee and still don't have a great setting.
author: Heewa B.

description: I was craving French Toast and Blue Danube definitely came through for me.  The menu lists "carmelized apples, almonds, mixed berries" written under the French Toast so being the Blue DaNEWB (I know, awful, right) that I was, I expected the cashier to ask me which topping I wanted, but lo and behold the French Toast actually comes with all of that goodness on top!  The secret ingredient is definitely the cream cheese in between the French Toast slices.  So good.  My friend's breakfast wrap looked really good as well, but she assured me the French Toast was better.
author: Krystle S.

description: Hands down my favorite coffee shop in the Richmond district!  It's fun and quirky with a pretty extensive food menu.  Must try the breakfast wraps, caprese sandwich, the hummus plate (comes with warm pita triangles, and sliced tomatoes and cucumbers) and the black and white cupcake.  I love the mochas, green teas (often served in a small tea pot and small tea cup) and lattes.  It's a cozy spot and the staff is awesome!
author: Marie B.

description: Love this coffee house for the causal and warm atmosphere. A great place to take an afternoon off or to study for final exams.
author: Jamie K.

description: Good coffee, Nice people.  BUT their kitchen is extremely slow.  It took over a half hour to get a simple sandwich.  People ahead of me planned to have lunch there but their food took so long they had to get it to go.
author: Otto G.

description: My favorite place to go for my lunch break.  Their sandwiches and soups are super yummy, and the people that work there are all really nice.  It's cash only, so don't forget your dollars!
author: Carrie A.

description:
Chill neighborhood cafe with yummy food, too!
I used to live by here and have been back a lot since my friend moved here. Independently owned (I like to support the little guys), it has a pleasant, homey, chill-out vibe. 

They have scrumptious sandwiches and all kinds of smoothies. My favorite is the French toast, with caramelized apple pieces -- I could eat it all day!  It's a cute little place to settle in with my book and grab munchies.
author: Cheeky C.

description:
blue danube is *exactly* why i love my neighborhood.  under-explored, underrated, and not pretentious.  they serve good coffee and have a super simple but tasty menu.  

went there with the hubs recently and got a mozzarella, hard boiled egg and tomato sandwich.  mmm good enough to go back for.

for all you yerba mate swilling, financial times reading, foodie fronters - this is NOT the place for you.  and i'm reeeal glad about that.
author: Christina K.

description: I ended up in this coffee house as an overflow for the Burma Super Star waiting room but wow, am I glad I did.  What a great coffee house all around, it's an all star.  The selection of food is fabulous, I was in the mood for a smoothie and they sure delivered.  The great food here definitely makes this place outstanding.  It's got a great coffee house vibe that's very homey and I noticed they even have live music at times...I would love to catch that sometime.
author: Debbie Y.

description:
everyone must come here while waiting for a table at burma superstar, since it is right across the street.  i know i did in an effort to stave off hunger.  they have a wide variety of sandwiches, salads, breakfast items and other small plates.  they also have beers on tap and a really good bloody mary.  i had a bloody mary here tonight while waiting for a table at burma, and once i finished, my table across the street was ready.  this is a great setup!

cash only!
author: Helen T.

description: One of my favorite coffee shops in the City:  small, cozy, laid-back, and a little funky.  Service is friendly and the food is decent.
author: Sophrosyne Y.

description: Great place to hang out if you live in the neighborhood, very chill staff and clean independent coffeehouse. Another reason to live in California as oppossed to Starbucks ridden NY...ack!
author: Maritess Z.

description: This is a cozy unassuming place to have a good cup of coffee and a ginger biscuit.  Maybe one of their baked egg dishes sometimes.
author: Debbie T.

description: I'm addicted to their ChocoMint Smoothies. Great place to get a bagel sandwhich in the morning too! Super cool staff. Love it.
author: Tiny H.

description: Nice little place to hang out in the hood. Really small, long lines. What makes this place unique is the huge french windows. The windows are open in the summer months on warmer days.
author: William H.

description: So basically I go here at least 4 to 5 times a week. It remains, still, simply the best. Love the coffee. And, I've recently discovered the deliciousness of their brown sugar currant scones (once again, ilovebutter), and bran muffins. I seriously don't know what I am going to do when I move out of this neighborhood.
author: Laura D.

description: Hip coffee houses are a bit rare and hard to find in dim sum dominated Inner Richmond, so Blue Danube doesn't have much competition.  That said, it would certainly hold its own in down town Santa Cruz or the Mission.  I especially love the decor and the cheesy, suggestive drawing on one of the tables.  But what really keeps me coming back is the beer.  A decent beer can be had for under four bucks, and sans the usual beer-drinking crowd.  This is the place I love to go when some quiet reading/beer drinking is in order, accompanied by a big side dish of people-watching.
author: Carmen D.

description: Great coffee and friendly service--if a tiny bit slow.  It's a perfect neighborhood coffee shop and the food isn't half bad either.  I go at least 2x a week and am always completely satisfied, especially with their coffee.  I mostly drink their drip but I've had a latte or two and they are just as good.
author: Jennifer L.

description: I had the Mexican hot chocolate the other night and it was soooo freakin good.   I haven't Yelped for a while, but that little bit of divinity, plus the ambience of the cafe, made me hop back on Yelp so that I can give this place props.   I especially love this place during the summer time, when they open up the window and you can just chill and people watch.  From the great menu, little art exhibits, to the decor, and the cool staff, this is a great little cafe to spend your nights reading a book or just chatting with a friend.  The only gripe is that sometimes it's hard to get a table.  Enjoy your cup of coffee here after you stuff your face at one of the inexpensive restaurants nearby.   Oh, you also have to try the French Toast with powdered sugar, toasted almosts and fresh berries....
author: Quinn W.

description: I went here with a very hungry friend.  I got the BLAT (Bacon, Lettuce, Avocado, Tomato) without mayo and it was delicious.  It came with a salad, that was light but a good extra item.  One great thing about this place is that it was packed but our sandwiches were made in a timely fashion.  Great atmosphere and wonderful food.  I only wish I lived closer.
author: Lizzy G.

description: nice little spot with comfy living room atmosphere. wi-fi, table seats and couches.  The sangrias not bad, definitely try the mexican hot chocolate and the small snack sized sandwiches (brie and pouched pear), sweet place to sit and read while sipping on something warm or enjoying a caffeine fix with friends.
author: Wei W.

description: A nice coffee shop with friendly service and good drinks. Definitely go here to sit down for a while and study or read. Nice little sidewalk area to sit in case the inside is full, and it often is. I recommend the mexican hot chocolate or a fresh smoothie.
author: Jasmine O.

description: Came here to hopefully recover from my feast at Burma Superstar.  Yes, the latte here did provide me somewhat relief.  The latte here is honestly not mind-blowing amazing, but it's also not bad.  This place gives me the comfy homey feeling, as if there's a grandma in the back cooking chicken soup or something.  With this kind of vibe, it would be a perfect place for a writer to let their creative juices flowwwwww.
author: Sheryl S.
