description: Blue Danube is everything I want in a local independant coffee shop.  Too bad it's not in my neighborhood, or even in the same city, for that matter. Ahh well.  I can still enjoy their cookies and coffee and cozy ambiance when I make my periodic trips to SF.
author: Anna G.

description: This place looks a little intimidating when it's filled with laptop-toting twenty-somethings like myself but it actually is great for anyone and everyone. Some good selections of drinks including might leaf teas and great (read: not too sweet) hot chocolate.
author: R K.

description: sucks its always filled with pretentious liberal lap-top warriors. neat cookies and tasty coffee thogh.
author: aidan m.

description: The Danube was a big high school haunt of mine for some reason, maybe because it's utterly hip and artsy and has blank journals that anyone can read or write in.  In recent years some high school friends and I met up there, but the magic was gone.  I still like to go there from time to time, but sometimes I'm scared off by the hoards of pretty people.
author: Emma K.

description: This is my favorite coffee joint in SF.  It has a cool ambiance and great selection of breakfast and lunch.  I used to work down the block from here, so it would be great to come here in the morning and get a cup of coffee.  They have homemade soups and the best one is their Chicken and Rice, which is a bit spicy and comes with garbanzo beans and corn.  My favorite panini is the salami and provolone.  I am not a big fan of salami or mustard, but this panini is awesome and the best one I've tasted in SF.  It also comes with a side salad as well.  It's a great place minus the parking around the area.
author: Carli F.

description: Love the Blue Danube.  Great coffee's, smoothies and teas.  PLUS a nice place to kick back and have a glass of wine or a beer.  They have live music (which I've yet to go hear, shame on me) and great service.  If you happen to be waiting for a table at Burma Superstar (directly across the street), its a great place to wait, get a hummus platter or a beer.  The chicken or turkey sandwiches are good too.
author: Andrea R.

description:
I took a train and a bus to get here and an hour is a long time to spend on transportation when you have hours of homework to do. I have a theory that you're better off studying comfortably over struggling to focus and mentally trying to drag yourself over your material, so I hoped that this place would be comfortable and worth the trek. All I knew about it I looked up on Yelp because I've never been to this neighborhood before. 
It went well; I got a seat right by the large open window and it was a warm night. I got a (decent) hot chocolate and I pulled out my binder, my two French books, my French verb book and my French dictionary - along with some worksheets and pencils. So I took up the whole table, I was in the depths of translating this stupid story called "Generation Kangaroo" which I'm going to be tested on next week when.. this horny couple posts right next to me outside. Oh nights when they have the windows open, you become oh-so-aware of  whoever sits outside because they're right against you practically - too bad it doesn't work the other way (?) cause this couple did not consider me at all. I had all my schoolwork out and I'm pretty obviously trying to focus on my work rather than their non-talent of loud lipsmacking kisses and annoying yuppy-couple-banter. I could not clear my throat, cough and fake-sneeze enough. It was a classic "No, you move! I'm not going anywhere" moment.  So just keep in mind that if you go here, you might run into that "fun" swinger couple that wants to give you a little show. Just sit in the window - or don't, if it's open and you feel like concentrating. On a side note, there were couches and other little tables inside plus the staff was nice.
author: Sylvia P.

description: I found myself on Clement Street yesterday in need of nourishment.  Before I left my favorite clothing store I asked them for a recommendation.  They sent me down the street two blocks to the Blue Danube which turned out to be a great recommendation.  If I lived in the neighborhood this would be the kind of place I would frequent.  Intimate, laid back with wifi - just how I like it!  The Double Grilled Cheese was stupendous but one star off for the scalding temperature of my Chai Tea.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
there's an old man who walks in with a large sketchbook, sits down and draws caricatures of other people sitting in the cafe. i watch him draw away, and he's pretty good. he's not really invading anyone's privacy, and i've seen him offer his sketch to his muse. i don't think it gets him laid.

one day, i would like for him to draw a picture of me. it will be of me staring at him as he draws a picture of me. it would be a staring contest i would have with a caricature of myself, and i will not blink first. this, i guarantee. my caricature can eat it.

i think that would rock.
author: Steve T.

description: A cozy little coffee cafe that offers not just an awesome cup of coffee but beer, fresh fruit smoothies, and a good selection of panini and wraps. Bohemian vibe complete with christmas light and featured art on the walls. Very mellow patrons. Good place to study if you can grab a table. Even better place to catch up with your girlfriends.
author: Marie V.

description: Hands down, my favorite coffee shop in the city.  I will even go out of my way (~ 20-25 min drive) to visit this spot if I just want a cozy place to read or catch up with friends.  The environment is unpretentious, surrounded by cool art, and just oozes a lovely neighborhood hangout atmosphere.  Oh, and their mint mochas are yummy!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Came here once for a sandwich with a friend.  Price was average but with pretty good quality.  Then I saw on the coffee menu called Depth Charge.  I was thinking that thing sounds dangerous, so I asked them what that is.  The barister told me it is regular coffee with a shot of expresso.  Lived around here for couple years already but never heard of it; so naive of me right?  Since it was around 5pm, I decided against it at that time.  I decided to come back next time and tried it.  Gee, I was wired for a good 5-6 hours.  I absolutely love it; I came back for it couple more times after that.  This never grows out.  I tried it with starbucks couple times also; blue danube still makes it better.  Also, it is cheaper than starbucks too!
It is however definitely not a good place to study.  It is pretty cramp and loud music is playing all the time.  Would recommend it for good chat place though!
author: K L.

description: I use to live right around the corner from this coffee shop and would always get my caffeine kick early in the morning, sometimes mid-day. The service has always been really nice, and the house coffee is amazing! The best house almost...they have a lot of seating, though close but still cozy, couches and chairs/tables. Nice big windows so a lot of natural light, even on a gloomy day. There was even live music one time I was there during the week (not sure which day), and that's always a nice little charm to find in the neighborhood. Definitely a moms and pops feel at this place and a good place to just chill and catch up with friends, read a book, or do some work.
author: Linda N.

description:
I first fell in love with this coffee shop when I walked in. It's small, and if you got any hips on you, you're going to have to hold your breath at times to squeeze past some tables. Which will remind you that holding your breath will not reduce the size of your hips...but that's neither here nor there. Either way, it's so so cozy that I felt myself relax as I walked in.

The first time I came, it was a Sunday and it was 9 pm. The kitchen was closed so I ordered a loose leaf tea that came in an adorable tea pot and a little cup, and some delicious blueberry pie.

I also came here during lunch time and their sandwiches and salads are quality. The lunch can be pretty quick too, so it's definitely doable during the work week.

There's outside seating, Wi-fi and a huge menu. It's also cash only, so be prepared.

The only downside is that I can definitely foresee it being packed with no seats availablle, but until that happens to me, it gets all my stars...and my love.
author: Masha B.

description: Blue Danube used to be something of a parasite business, with Burma Superstar calling over to let customers know that their table was available.  For some reason, I'm told they've stopped doing this.  You can still leave a cell with the Superstar, though.
author: J R.

description: Check this place out even if you don't need to wait for Burma Superstar:  They have beer and wine and sangria, decent enough coffee, a cozy atmosphere, and entertaining cafe journals.
author: Bailey S.

description: My aunt lives in this area and I used to spend weekends at her place during the summer and come here to read and hang out.  I've never had any of their food before but their coffee is pretty good.  It's usually pretty crowded weekend mornings but I usually manage to find a table for my laptop.  Free internet is always a nice plus :)
author: Joanne L.

description:
I really really really want to like this place. It has some great elements! Outdoor tables, cozy inside, and it's literally less than a block from my house. 

But I can't like to myself. And I definitely can't lie to you.

Today I wandered into the Blue Danube on my way to Eva's Hawaiian Cafe. The thought of Hawaiian BBQ seemed a little bit heavy but I haven't tried it since it has opened and for a Sunday afternoon, why not? But first, I needed coffee. SO I decided to give the Blue Danube another try (who says I'm a total hater? see: Buckshot review). The last few times I've tried coffee from there, it was pretty terrible. The espresso tasted burnt and overpowered any minty-ness I had desired. And it was weak, which is even worse. Don't mess with a lady's caffeine intake. Anyway, so I intended to try my latest caffeinated obsession: soy latte (I know, I missed the whole Starbucks era). As I stood in line waiting for my turn, I noticed the sandwich board. Apparently I had forgotten they served light lunchtime fare and it all of a sudden seemed like such a better choice than the fried chicken katsu I had been thinking about all morning. The line was getting shorter and the first sandwich I saw was a B.L.A.T. on multi-grain. Hella yeah. 

There was some shit going on at the counter and the cashier seemed flustered. No big thing, it's Sunday. I ordered my stuff to go and turned around to wait for my goods. 

Not one place to move. No room by the counter. Everyone looking at you impatiently for blocking the counter. But where am I supposed to go?! Feeling awkward, I finally saw an empty patch of couch next to a middle aged gentleman. I found out why it was empty, homie was having some deodorant challenged issues. But hey, I lived in Santa Cruz for 5 years so ain't no thang.

The soy latte came up; not bad. Not great, kind water-y. Kind of weak / no taste. 1 point for using vanilla soy though.

The sandwich finally came up. A man brought it out in a to go box. I was excited. BLAT! Just the name is enough to get excited over.  Bacon! Lettuce! Tomato! Avocado! I practically skipped my way home.

I love mayo as much as the next overweight American. I dip my fries in it. A sandwich is never complete without it. And both sides of the burger bun get it's own helping.  Yet, there is such thing as overload. When I opened the box, the first thing I saw was mayo, mayo, MAYO! Like it was attacking the sandwich. The whole thing felt somewhat soggy from the pure amount of mayo slapped on there. Did I mention it takes me about 2 minutes to walk home from the Danube?

The next thing I noticed was how thin the poor thing was. Upon further investigaton and peeling of the bread, there seemed to be some soggy pieces of romaine and wait, what was that? Ohhhh, those tiny reddish brown things were bacon? The tiniest pieces of bacon on the planet I think. And hold up, where's the avocado?! WHERE IS THE AVOCADO? Missing :( $7.25  for that experience! Perhaps if I hadn't felt the pressure to get out of the way of this place, I would've checked before I left. Sigh.

The whole experience bummed me out. How fantastic would it be to have an awesome sandwich place down the street? Seems like I won't find out any time soon :( I suppose it's a decent place to go if you can actually find a place to sit and don't order anything besides a black cup of coffee. So much potential Danube, let's try to live up to it.
author: Salina Z.

description: This place was good, good cofee and a nice filling eggycheesy bagel.  A little on the pricier end for a Richmond coffee shop, thank goodness for Javaholics.
author: Jenn F.

description: A friend recommended we come here for the sangria while we waited for our table at Burma SuperStar across the street. Definitely some tasty, strong sangria, but not necessarily the best I've ever had.  It was one of those warm nights so we sat along the open windows, perfect for people watching. Overall, cute little place to hang out and pass the time during our 1 hour plus wait for our table. FYI - Its cash only so be sure to bring some.
author: Carolyn K.

description: I love this place.  I used to spend a lot of time here with a friend who lived in the neighborhood.  I made a return trip there this week after many months and remembered how great it is.  The atmosphere is pleasant.  The people who work here are really nice.  And of course the coffee is good.  I also had a really delicious cinnamon bun on my most recent visit.    I am taking away one star though for serving their lattes in bowls.  That drives me nutty!  I am way too clumsy to drink out of a bowl without being afraid of spilling it all over myself.
author: Squirrel L.

description: Great place to hang out and watch the hustle bustle of Clement St. Good coffee, good food, funky atmosphere, and they make a mean smoothie. Great neighborhood haunt.
author: Kate Y.

description: Love this Cafe... the whole place rocks. It might be a little pricey but it is worth it. The coffee is a thousand times better than starbucks. They have everything from breakfast to desserts they even have smoothies. I really enjoy this cafe, I think it is my new fave... it's a great place to study, or to sit down and chat with friends or you can even grab something and go. They have two computers and outlets where you can plug in your computer. Great GREAT PLACE!
author: Ashley M.

description: This place is always packed, but it's because everyone loves it! Great atmosphere and yummy food. Everything on the menu looks really good and the coffee is good to. Free Wi-Fi, always a plus.
author: Sonya S.

description:
on atmosphere alone, i have to drop the four stars. it reminds me a lot of Simple Pleasures, but with less comfort, although the open window seating is wonderful.

theyre slow'ish. their sandwiches are entertaining and pretty good. i dont think they serve a caramel latte with real caramel, which is such a downer, but here's what they do have...

a series of little journals stowed away in the cafe that are available to anyone who wishes to write something down, draw a sketch, make a joke - its the most entertaining read, and greatly creative. i want to head over now just to read an entry again that had to do with chuck norris and extra arms.
author: Darrell L.

description: Laid back coffee/sandwich shop in the Richmond.  Always a mellow atmosphere, and the huge open windows are nice on a sunny day.  Go there for lunch, sandwiches served with small salad are very good.   Or for a beer while you wait to get into Burma Superstar.
author: Andrew R.

description: This coffee-shop really sets itself apart from so many wanna-be independent cafes. Would you like cheese with that wine? And by wine, I mean this shop actually sells booze AND cheese platters. (Check!) On top of that, they make a mean smoothie. (Double check!) The whip cream  on this review is the journals/books one can entertain themselves with. It's so hip, you'll cry.
author: Liz L.

description: I love this place partly because it's a pleasant counterweight to Burma Superstar, it's neighbor on Clement St. While you wait for a table at Burma, stop by this arty cafe for a great and generously portioned cappuccino and a monster-size biscotti. Each table at the Danube looks like it was painted by a different artist. The strength of this cafe's personality will make your coffee taste that much better.
author: Andrew K.

description: really good tea and a nice place to people watch while waiting for a seat at BurmaSuperstar or a hair appt!
author: Emm C.

description: This is an excellent place to sit down with a good book and space out while sipping excellent coffee, or enjoying a light meal. If cozy (OK - you could call it "cramped") quarters with unique decor is your deal, you'll enjoy The Blue Danube.
author: Alex C.

description: Currently my favorite SF coffeehouse.  The Depth Charge (house coffee with a shot of espresso) is surprisingly smooth and tasty, and has enough caffeine to keep you up for hours.  The french toast was yummy, decent sandwiches, the atmosphere pleasant, and the music good.  The only complaint I have is the parking in the area.  If you wanna work for 2+ hours, you have to park several blocks away.
author: Francis L.

description:
great cafe food, nice coffee, cute tables to study at or chat... GOOD SALADS, vietnamese coffee, baked goods. 

check it out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Erika Y.

description: It's a cute little place to stop in and read your Green Apple books if you just can't wait. I like the big, real mug instead of the paper ones. The interior needs help, but the food was tasty (I had the hummus plate) and the service was friendly.
author: Rachel B.

description: This is a really nice coffee house. It even made a good study environment on a Friday night. Extra points for them letting me decide on the water level in my Americano.  The music was just loud enough to hear without being distracting, although it did get a little tiring to hear over and over and over again within a 2 1/2 hour time span. It was a pretty sweet old-school mix though so I can't complain too much about it.
author: Naomi C.

description:
This place is becoming my favorite cafe in the city. It's bijou enough to be cozy, but there are still comfy low couches to be found. The coffee is very good, though not fantastic, but that's not what this place is about. What keeps me coming back is the atmosphere - it's balanced. Not as self-consciously hip as Ritual, and not as over-40 bridge-and-tunnel as Trieste. And, as someone else said, it's definitely not Starbucks. It's quiet, but most of the regulars are open and social. The baristas are friendly and the menu is surprisingly good. There are juices and smoothies to be had, as well as wine, and the food is excellent. If nothing else, try the Greek yogurt, I usually get two. 

One other plus is that it's open later than most other cafes I've seen around here - 10 on weekdays and 11 on weekends, which is perfect for a procrastinating student like myself.
author: david p.

description:
This review is purely based on the coffee as I had read most people who rated this place high were due to the food items: 

I was dining at Burma Superstar across the street and decided to finish off with some coffee.  They had a good selection of drinks to order and I noticed that they had holiday flavors.  So I ordered the hazelnut spiced mocha with non fat milk and my fiance ordered a white chocolate mocha with soy milk.  The prices were good; I believe it was $3.50 for large coffees.  The coffee, however, was somewhat of a let down.  Probably because I saw the Yelp sticker outside the window and because I normally prefer mom and pop coffee shops over chain ones.  My coffee was overly sweet and the hazelnut wasn't really highlighted - it tasted more like hot cocoa with a hint of cayenne pepper.  My fiance's white mocha didn't taste anything like white mocha.  It tasted like strong brewed coffee with a hint of flavored syrup.  The baked items I didn't try but they looked pretty dry and it was only 1pm... It was pretty crowded and smelled like a thrift store - i dont know if it was the store or some of the people who happened to be there that day.
author: Allison J.

description: I always come here for business meetings with my boss. Don't forget to bring your cash because they don't accept any cards. Their sandwiches and salads are absolutely amazing! The fresh juices available are sooo good.
author: Jasleen K.

description: Cute coffee  shop in the inner richmond.  Good for some hummus or a bagel while you are waitng to be seated at Burma Superstar.  They have cute coffee shop journals as well.
author: Joanna S.

description: I used to live around the corner and went here everyday, totally loved this place.  Went back this week on my way to Green Apple books and whoa, has that place really changed for the worse.  Could hardly walk into the place with all the chairs/tables packed in there like sardines.  I know people need a place to sit, but that is a little much.  Having said that, the coffee and snack I got were great, but the atmosphere is just totally shot .. such a travesty.
author: Darren Z.

description: On a recent beautifully warm Sunday morning, a couple of friends and I were walking down Clement in search of a light brunch. The mellow crowd at Blue Danube,  and the open outdoor tables drew us in to check out the menu. Wraps, fresh fruit with granola, smoothies, and a nice espresso menu make this cafe great for a healthy brunch alternative. The food is great, and the atmosphere chill -- the espresso and smoothies make for a refreshing pick-me-up on a pleasant Sunday morning.
author: Megan E.

description: Great coffee and food, however, this is not my favorite place to study for a few reasons: tables are tiny and hard to come by.  If you do get a table, they are really close together, making it hard to spread out with the laptop, books, pens... Also, they charge $5 to use the wi-fi for the day.  If you are looking for a place to hang out with friends and grab brunch, this is a great  option.  I recommend the Greek wrap: eggs, spinach, pesto, sun dried tomatoes and feta in a hot tortilla- delicious.  Also, the large coffee comes in a really wide mug, which gets cold very quickly.  Order coffee to-go!
author: Jessica M.

description: This place is suuuper cozy and open late, which is great. My chai was only okay. It was a little watery but I guess that's what you get if you order a non-fat chai latte. They had a delicious chocolate coconut biscotti. The couches are really comfy and the staff is nice. I would definitely hang out here again.
author: O K.

description:
my ex and i have this running debate after i spent the night chez him..

where do we go for coffee ( we obviously are better off wasting our time arguing over the destination than just biting it and making that shit at home)

i'm for blue danube. 
He's all for the ice cream/coffee/ old timer place that he only hated when he thought the kids serving him were giving him attitude
Honestly, i feel that standing on carpet makes my coffee warmer.


I feel more cozy, more welcomed for a longer time, at the blue danube. 

Sure, sometimes service sucks, but i feel comfortable waiting for my order to manifest at the blue danube. Not like i need to buy an action figure in the unplanned 5 minutes of waiting for the java to arrive.

oh well

so apparantly if you are an old school SF(ian) then you head over to the toy boat. 
I am not.

I like carpet. I like discretion. I like to not have to ask the staff if i can go behind the counter to use the loo.



thanks
author: Domini A.

description:
I've been patronizing this coffee house for over twelve years, and have seen it change hands at least three or four times.  The current owners appear to have gotten the establishment's vibe and flavor down, for indeed simultaneously the most lively and mellow java joint in the Clement Street commercial corridor.  The other notable coffee houses in the neighborhood like Java Joint and Cafe de Flore don't really compare in terms of having an inviting attitude  and an interesting, colorful clientele.  
It's cosy enough to encourage friendly conversation with fellow coffee goers and also for people watching.  It's also a place for laptop junkies and readers as well as writers.  I've seen people sketching in their black books, and I've seen people killing time awaiting their table at Burma Star, something that wasn't really done back in the day, liquor license notwithstanding.  I sketch in my own black book, so I find this a great place to draw people.  I also like sketching the environment itself, which is busy due to the space's size but contains curious objects, like the large mirror with an ornate frame, and the tree decoration with holiday lights hung from it's leafless branches.  
And it's all so compact, even cramped, but that's what contributes to the place's appeal.  It always gives the illusion of crowdedness, so that when you take your seat inside, you feel  a part of this close knit caffeinated Blue Danube community.  It's like a living room vibe.  You want to stay and watch live reality and hear layered conversation, and that's to me always enjoyable, and as been for over twelve years now.  
The coffee's good, the food and desserts are delicious, the beer's on tap and will give you a buzz if you drink enough of it.  One thing I do miss about one of the past incarnations is Wednesday night Simpson's happy hour!   Yup, that's right.  There used to be something like $2 pints during the Simpson's weekly episode, back when a television once hung from the ceiling corner above the entrance.  It was marvelous!
author: Roland C.

description: 4 stars for atmosphere, 3.5 for food.  Similar to "people don't really go to Hooters for the wings"
author: Kurosh H.

description: Very cozy and warm inside.  Great coffee.
author: Blu n.

description: Meh, Ive had better.  I went there to get a cup of joe and do some work online.  The place is real small, its hard to get a seat, staff was nothing special, and the coffee was just as good as homemade.  I might go back, dunno.
author: Russ B.

description: Order a tea whilst waiting for your table at Burma Superstar.
author: miriam b.

description: This place has character and charm and good food and juices to boot. I don't know about their coffee, but their selection of Mighty Leaf Tea is great. My main gripe is that it's often crowded and awkward to get in and out of the counter area. I go there to eat, drink and leave, wouldn't lounge around for too long at the tiny tables.
author: A Y.

description: First off, this cafe has a cool name.  It's pretty reflective of what all it has to offer - an eclectic selection of coffees and teas from around the world! I came here with a group of friends for some timepass while waiting for a table at Burma Superstar, across the street.  The place is small, inviting and cozy (the cushions are super comfy).  I tried a Mexican hot chocolate and was very pleased with the flavors.  It's a cute lil place to talk, catch up and wait for the delish food across from the street.
author: Megha S.

description: This place has got character.  I only tried one expensive smoothie, which was quite good, so I don't have much to say there yet, but the place intrigues me.  It has this eclectic arrangement of couches and coffee tables which don't match, yet in an interesting it all clicks together.  I dig the look, with the odd furniture, the food / drinks chalkboard, the porch on which to see and be seen.  One bummer is the small number of flies that buzz around the place.  People who want the picture perfect sterile environment will go to starbucks.  Folk who desire more character from their coffee shops will seek out Blue Danube.
author: William C.

description: We usually go on a Tuesday evening, have a couple of fat tires (the beer's only $3.50 a pint), check up on email, and then go sit outside and people watch and peep in on the guy's apartment across the street. He leaves his blinds up and seems totally oblivious that people can see IN windows too. I like the vibe at Blue Danube too plus the Hispanic young man running the counter is a sweetheart.
author: chris m.

description:
Dude, two things:
1) No internet unless you want to pay for it (which I did, and then i still couldn't VPN to my office) so WTF are you supposed to do there?  Socialize w/ trendsters making the scene??  I don't think so.

2) Its packed, always, prbly thanks to a million and one 5 star reviews on yelp.  So you will have to cram your ass into a seat somewhere that was meant for someone with a pant size of 30, not 46. 

It would be one star exept for the beer and wine.  Points (1) and (2) above become irrelevant once you've had few glasses of their (incredibly cheap, nasty, and open-for-way-too-long) wines.

UPDATE:  OK, I bumped from 2 to 3 stars.  This place has pretty good food, I like the sandwiches (ham or turkey).  They are very tasty and come w/ a nice green salad too.  Of course, I wouldn't dare to attempt eating there, so I do take out only.  The staff is competent (both over the phone and in person) -- of course, it's not rocket science.  Hand me my sandwich, take my money, and STFU.  I would prob give 3.5 stars.
author: John K.

description: Good hot chocolate, not too bitter but also not bland and tasteless.  A nice place to relax for a bit while waiting for a table at Burma Superstar.
author: Alured P.

description: Hands down the best sandwiches in all of San Francisco.  They take a minute or two longer than you would expect.  But it is totally worth drinking an iced-tea, doodling in the Blue Danube Sketchbook, and watching the artistic crowd.  The Tuna and the Avocado are my favorites.
author: Sharon C.

description: Order the Black Forest Ham, egg and Cheddar Cheese croissant. Hella bomb...  The Cupcakes are a delight as well. FYI The Sangria F$#k's you up.  Always a cool place to go when you need to get out of the house to kick back read a book or catch up with some friends.  People watching is always fun because BURMA SUPPER STAR, QUICKLY AND GENKKI are all close by. YES its here on Clement street where there are so many bad Asian drivers. FUCKIN GO U DUMB ASIAN DRIVER.
author: Robert M.

description: I love this place.  They make an exceptional white mocha and I've converted my Chinese wife to coffee through the magic of the baristas here.  Anyway, it's crowded sometimes, but I never mind sitting on someone's lap, thus no star deduction.  They charge for wireless, but who cares.  The tables are cool with artworks and they have some journals that I've tagged my name in every time I go (Houzi; Chinese character).
author: Alcides G.

description: COnsistantly good sandos and salads. High Prices though. They only take cash though what Century is this? . And the long wait some times kills the deal.
author: charles p fa t.

description: This coffee shop has great atmosphere: cute and sunny.  It seems to attract only happy chilled out people too. I love the breakfast wraps- steamed egg and a variety of ingredients depending on which one you get.  It would be great if they had free wi fi, then it would be perfect.
author: L C.

description: I don't think I noticed Blue Danube the first couple times I was on Clement, I suppose it can be easily missed amidst the sea of Asian owned stores. I came here to study a couple times while I was visiting in San Francisco, but if I lived in the Richmond, Blue Danube would easily become my neighborhood cafe -- perfect for studying, reading, and lazy Sunday afternoons. Great place to people watch, too. I only ordered a white mocha, their pastries and sandwiches were out of my price range. Friendly staff too, bonus points to the barista that complimented my Scotty (of Star Trek) picture in my wallet.
author: Rose S.

description:
totally not over this place, it's a clement st. staple and i love it. while the coffee isn't noteworthy and the food isn't exactly anything to fall all over yourself for, it's a good and refreshing alternative to the thai and chinese restaurant-heavy neighborhood.

as far as ambiance, it's almost too cozy sometimes that it's hard to grab a seat, and there tend to be lots of stragglers on laptops or with their heads stuck in journals so turn over can be rough.

OMG. and i almost forgot - the bloody mary's are pretty frickin' fantastic as well. i almost want to give danube an extra star just for those. yummm....
author: Kay L.

description: I have lived in the city for 4 years now, and I have not found an overall charming coffee experience as I have at the Blue Danube.  It is quaint with good food and an eclectic crowd that always keeps me coming back.  Would be the best if internet was a better deal, but the Mexican hot chocolate is fanastic.
author: Ally H.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised!
My chai was not too spicy and my currant scone (although unaesthetically presented under some Saran wrap) was actually pretty darn good.
Hooray!
I good use of $6 dollars.
author: montenegra m.

description: I've walked by here several times and tonight decided to stop in for a little pick me up to take home. I want to come back and hang out - it seems so relaxing and all the little details from the art on the wall to the penguins following the nun by the cash register. How could you not love that? They're pastries actually looked edible for a coffee shop, most places have what appears to be over priced Costco pastries or stale pastries in the case. If you live in this area you know good coffee shops are slim pickings. There is Cafe LoCubano which is fine but they never do their dishes and bakery case doesn't look all that appetizing - albeit yummy coffee and comfy atmosphere. Then there is Peets which well is Peets, Starbucks - which is open 24/7 honestly that isn't my first choice, but it has better hours. Now there is Blue Danube which honestly I'd rather walk to Clement and go to Blue Danube because there is lots of personality and tasty coffee!
author: melissa h.

description: Love this place... absolutly adore the owners, Sandy and Jim. Hope you guys are doing well. I used to be in the neighborhood often, almost daily. First of all this place has those triple chocolate cookies, amazing, always fresh and make your mouth water. Second of all, Blue Danube has great soy chai, by far the best I have had at any local shops. Now, lets go to their innoventive menu. The greek breakfast wrap ( I think thats the name of it) is absolutly fantastic, extremely fresh. One other thing I enjoy off their menu is their super delicious mouth watering grilled cheese with tomatoes, on I believe all grain, with the green salad. Oh, and they have this spinach smoothie, The Hulk, great stuff... I know spinach might sound gross, but you will never know the greatness of this smoothie if you don't try it. Basically, everything is fresh and great here. The atmosphere is also extremely relaxing, and its packed on the weekends....The previous owners were also great and sweet, but you guys have really done something wonderful.
author: yana Z.

description: Most amazing coffeehouse ever.  Food is reliably good and healthy (and moderately priced).  Scrumptious breakfasts, spectacular salads, fabulous smoothies (I recommend the Hulk - it may be green, but it's healthy and yummy and I'm hooked).   They also have sangria, cheese plates, pastries, sandwiches, wraps, you name it.  I can always find something I'm in the mood for at Blue Danube (and most of the dishes come with a side salad - which always have just the right amount of dressing and tastes soooo good).  Outside seating I would rate an A+++.  It gets direct sunlight and is great for people-watching (can't get better than Clement St.), reading, and internet (not free internet though).  Only a few blocks from my house so it's hard to stay away.  Also has live music from time to time --- I haven't actually been there for it, but I imagine it's a good time.  Make sure to bring cash.
author: Daniella E.

description: favorite coffee shop in the city. i don't care if they don't take cc. there is a gd bank machine across the street. tasty food. Rosemary chicken is a delight.
author: Boyd W.

description: surprisingly good food for a hole in the wall coffee shop on clement in the midst of asian markets and fish shops. their turkish coffee wakes you up good, and their greek yogurt with fruit & honey is perfect on a sunny morning. but then again, what isnt great on a sunny morning?
author: jodes l.

description: I like this place a lot.  It's a good thing that the internet isn't free, because most people are reading and chatting.  Thank GOD.
author: Christopher H.

description: I love their Mexican Hot chocolate & also greek yogurt. heart the people that work there and I can sit there for hours without feeling in anyway annoyed. The Journals are also awesome to read if you just want to relax.
author: Anna G.

description: depending on my mood, i might call it burma superstar's overflow/waiting room, and thank goodness for its location right across the street from them.  or tonight, i'll say, i wish this place was way closer to home cuz i would absolutely love to hang out there right now.  although i couldn't right now because they close at 10 (11 on the weekend).  it 's a perfectly chill cafe when nothing's going on and has a wider than normal cafe-menu though i think i'll continue to never order off of it because i'm all about sipping yummy drinks here!  beer, wine, and/or coffee!
author: Monk R.

description: this place rocks. i'm addicted to both their almond croissants and the way they do their eggs (try breakfast crossaint w/ eggs, cheese and bacon--yummy!!). very homey, decent coffee, friendly, down-home feel. only thing i don't like is they tend to serve their lattes in bowls. i effin' hate stupid trends like that one and the one w/ the latte in the glass bullshit. can i just have my extremely hot beverage in those things that were made especially for that hot beverage? ever heard of a mug, dudes?
author: Cristabel L.

description: Had a Chai latte here while waiting to be seated at Burma Superstar.  Since I'm not a regular coffee/tea drinker, I normally just head to Starbucks whenever I get a craving since there's normally one close by.  I realize now how inferior my Starbucks Chai latte is.  The one I had at Blue Danube had good but not overpowering Chai flavor and just a hint of sweetness.  It was perfect.
author: Roy L.

description: I don't know what it is about this neighborhood but the danube is sorta like the bermuda triangle of the inner richmond. No seriously, the denizens of this all together quaint coffee shop are as eclectic as they get, mixed in with the crowds that wait for their share of Burmese bliss across the street, you have this strange confluence of artists, writers, students and locals. I realize that writers, students and artists can both be local, but lets face it you just know that a guy with a crazed look in his eyes with a large sketchpad is both local, an artist and perhaps a bit loco. This is why I absolutely love this place... the coffee is good, the teas are savory, the salads filling along with the sandwiches, the beers are cold and the service is friendly. All in all a good stop for Joe that is reasonably priced with outdoor seating for those of you that still want a fag and a cup of joe... bless your hearts, wish I could be right there with ya!
author: Len S.

description: I had the breakfast croissant and it was yummy but my bf got the french toast and it was AMAZING!! I wanted to steal it away from him. I also got a smoothie with was a good portion and pretty tasty. I like the cozy feel of this place. Only downside is that they only accept cash :/ luckily there is a WaMu right across the street.
author: Jasmine M.

description: so coffee is coffee. there. i said it. i drink coffee everyday and pretty much know what sucks. the rest is just coffee to me. i like this place for the ambience, the friendly staff and patrons. good coffee shop food, fair prices. if you're a coffee snob, just brew a cup at home and read your nytimes somewhere else so the rest of us have a place to sit.
author: Shinn Z.

description: get the coffee cake!!!!! to die for! moist melt in your mouth sweet coffee flavor. mmmm i'm gonna get in my car and drive there now.
author: Scarlet S.

description: It's chill and the food and coffee are great.  The atmosphere is very low key and the crowd is good.  Shouldn't get your laptop stolen but then don't blame if it happens!
author: Misti L.

description: This coffeehouse is awesome! I just moved into the area recently and it has since become my regular hangout...unlimited internet for 15/month, and really fresh, good food. The coffee is a little bitter so if you're looking for something based on taste rather than caffeine then it might not be what your looking for. All of the sandwiches that either me or my friends have tried have been amazing. Also, I love the fact that the sandwich plates come with a simple mixed green salad instead of chips which you find at a lot of restaurants (a nice, healthy alternative to some greasier food options). Good baked goods (and cake!) as well. And, if you fancy that you've been working long enough and want to relax with a beer or are just passing time with a drink before dining at Burma Superstar, they have that too (as well as sangria and mimosas!). Besides that, I have to say, whoever chooses the background music makes some good selections...
author: Carmen C.

description: Best Coffee house in the Inner Richmond. Great coffee, nice staff, cool vibe. Nuff said
author: J B.

description: I always want to hang out here more often, but it's busier during the day on the weekends. It's great because they have comfortable seating inside as well as some seating outside for the few sunny days we do get. The owners and the people work there seem to be genuinely nice, and one of the employees introduced me to La Oreja de Van Gogh because he was picking the CDs to play one day. The snacks and drinks aren't bad, but not outstanding. On slow days, it's one of the more comfortable coffee shops in the neighborhood.
author: Tami H.

description: good vibe. real nice owner. the banana honey ginger smoothie is excellent for aiding hang overs. good beer. ya, i like it but a little expensive but it is quality stuff.
author: Meegs P.

description: Decadent french toast.  I'm sure that I would be regular if I lived closer.  Great coffee shop.
author: Jennifer H.

description: love the mexican hot chocolate w/ marshmellows!! - a little sweet, but delicious nonetheless.
author: Jill R.

description: really yummy food and salad. great taste without breaking the bank or feeling fat. the men who work there during the day are not very warm or friendly, but they do their job correctly and calmly. can be a little noisey in the cafe itself, but it is possible to have a quiet chat with a friend or lunch alone or study. comfy couches are a plus!
author: Sarah A.

description: Great food, strong coffee, friendly staff and slow service. Over priced for the food you get but its good quality.
author: R T.

description: Great local hangout for morning coffee or brunch.  They have large windows and comfortable seating areas.  The coffee and food is quite tasty.  I also enjoy the laid back and friendly service as well as the variety of food/drinks you can order.
author: Jenny K.

description: my best friend and i discovered this place in high school.  we come every year during the holidays and order the mint mochas.  they're available year round and are delicious.
author: Onki K.
